Available online 20 May 2022 Review Single atom-based catalysts for electrochemical CO2 reduction Qian Sun Chen Jia Yong Zhao Chuan Zhao * School of Chemistry, The University of New South Wales, Sydney, New South Wales 2052, Australia School of Chemistry The University of New South Wales Sydney New South Wales 2052 Australia School of Chemistry, The University of New South Wales, Sydney, New South Wales 2052, Australia * Corresponding author Electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), powered by renewable energy, emerges as a promising approach against environmental issues and energy crisis by converting CO2 into value-added chemicals. Single atom catalysts (SACs) with isolated metal atoms dispersed on supports exhibit outstanding performance for CO2 electroreduction, because of their strong single atom-support interactions, maximum metal utilization and excellent catalytic activity. However, SACs suffer from agglomeration of particles, low metal loading, and difficulty in large-scale production. In addition, molecular catalysts as another single atom-based catalyst, consisting of ligands molecules connected to metal ions, exhibited similar metal-nitrogen (M-N) active centers as that in metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) SACs, which were highly active to CO2 reduction due to their well-defined active sites and tunability over the steric and electronic properties of the active sites. Nonetheless, molecular catalysts are challenged by generally moderate activity, selectivity and stability, poor conductivity and aggregation. Many works have been devoted to overcoming these issues of SACs and molecular catalysts for efficient CO2RR, but only limited reviews for systematic summary of their fabrication, application, and characterizations, which were highlighted in this review. Firstly, we summarize recent advanced strategies in preparing SACs for CO2RR, including wet-chemistry approaches (defect engineering, spatial confinement, and coordination design), other synthetic methods and large-scale production of SACs. Besides, electrochemical applications of SACs and molecular catalysts on CO2RR are discussed, which involved the faradaic efficiency and partial current density of the desired product as well as the catalyst stability. In addition, ex-situ and in-situ/operando characterization techniques are briefly assessed, benefiting probing the active sites and understanding the CO2RR catalytic mechanisms. Finally, future directions for the development of single atom-based catalysts (SACs, molecular catalysts) are pointed out. Graphical Abstract This review introduces the synthesis of SACs, summarizes their CO2RR applications, discusses the characterization techniques such as in situ/operando skills to reveal the in-depth catalytic mechanism and provides future directions of SACs and molecular catalysts. Keywords CO2 electroreduction Wet-chemistry approach Single atom catalyst Molecular catalyst In-situ characterization 1 Introduction Continuous consumption of traditional fossil fuels (coal, natural gas, oil) has resulted in escalated CO2 concentration in air which is responsible for global climate change [1,2]. To solve the greenhouse issue, many efforts have been devoted to developing techniques for CO2 capture and utilization. Various routes have been investigated to CO2 convert, such as chemical reforming [3], biological [4], electrochemical [5], and photochemical approaches [6]. Among which, electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) [7] has emerged as a promising technique to address environmental issues and energy shortage [8], which can transform CO2 to value-added chemicals and fuels, reliving our strong dependence on fossil fuels. Besides, CO2RR was driven by renewable resources without extra CO2 emission, and the reduction process is easily controlled by potentials and currents in ambient reaction pressure and temperature. However, CO2RR is suffering from stable C=O bond (806 kJ mol−1) in CO2 [9], competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [10], low solubility of CO2 in aqueous electrolytes [8], and selectivity of multi-products [11]. CO2 can be reduced electrochemically to CO, CH4, HCOOH, C2H4, CH3OH, C2H5OH, and etc. through different pathways. Table 1 indicates the CO2RR pathways and HER along with the standard potentials E 0 against the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) in an aqueous medium [11]. The high negative potential (–1.9 V vs. SHE) for the formation of the key intermediate CO2*− (CO2 + e− → CO2*−) resulted in a high overpotential for CO2 electroreduction. Because of the similar thermodynamic potential to CO2RR, HER is an inevitable side reaction. It is still challenging to obtain the desired products with high selectivity attributed to the various reaction pathways. Hence, developing efficient catalysts for CO2RR is significantly demanded. Single atom catalysts (SACs) [12] with isolated metal atoms on solid supports are promising for CO2 electroreduction, due to their advantages of strong atom-support interactions, high metal utilization and catalytic activity [13,14]. The concept of designing SACs for CO2RR dated back to a number of pioneering studies. Assisted by theoretical calculations, Back et al. [15] discovered that the single Ni and Pt atom anchored on defective graphene with double vacancies (Ni@dv-Gr, Pt@dv-Gr) are promising for CH3OH production, while Os@dv-Gr and Ru@dv-Gr preferred CH4 production. Zhao et al. [16] reported a Ni SAC on N-doped porous carbon (Ni SAs/N-C) derived from zeolitic imidazolate framework for CO2-to-CO conversion, which delivered three times higher Faradaic efficiency (FECO) than that of the Ni nanoparticles/N-C, attributed to more low-coordinated surface Ni-N3 active sites facilitating faster electron transfer and easier CO2 •– formation. Followed by this work, Li et al. [17] fabricated Ni-N4 sites using a topo-chemical transformation approach. The exclusive Ni-N4 active sites exhibited particularly high selectivity towards CO, giving a maximum FECO of 99% at –0.81 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). A series of metal SACs were subsequently reported, such as Ru [18], Pd [19], Pt [20], Ni [8], Fe [21], Co [22], Cu [23], Zn [24], and Sn SAC [25], which delivered superior CO2RR performances. Among them, Ni, Fe, and Co based SACs exhibit outstanding CO2-to-CO selectivity [26–28], while Cu SACs are promising for generating multi-carbon hydrocarbons such as ethylene [29], ethanol [30] and propanol [31]. Similarly, several reviews [32,33] summarized the development and applications of these transitional metal SACs for CO2 electroreduction, beyond which, in this work, we systematically discussed the design strategies of both transitional and noble metal SACs, especially their large-scale fabrication. To elucidate the CO2RR catalytic mechanism, advanced in situ/operando characterizations were also highlighted, laying foundations for fabricating efficient catalysts with superior CO2RR performances. Although great achievements have been made by SACs for CO2RR, it still remains some challenges to develop high-loading SACs at large-scale because of the particles aggregation during calcination, and maintain the unique structure of active sites during the preparation process which is intensely connected with metal centers and supports [34]. Many substrates have been explored for developing SACs. Especially, carbon supports (e.g., carbon nanotube [35], graphene oxide [36], metal-organic frameworks-derived nanocarbons [37], and carbon nitride [38]) exhibited advantages on their high electrical conductivity, specific stability, tailored surface chemistry and low cost [34] to develop metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) SACs for CO2RR. Other metal complexes (CeO2 [39], TiO2 [40], MoS2 [41], TiC [19]) were also confirmed as effective supports for preparing efficient SACs. Similar to the SACs with M-N active sites, molecular catalysts composed of ligands molecules bond to metal ions, including covalent-organic frameworks (COFs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) catalysts, and organometallic catalysts [42,43], also exhibited M-N centers to catalyze CO2 reduction. These catalysts displayed controllable tunability over the steric and electronic properties around the active sites by various metal centers, ligands and supports, which facilitated mechanistic studies of the structure-function relationship. It laid foundations for rational design of electrocatalysts for improved CO2RR performances. Nonetheless, molecular catalysts are restricted by aggregation, leaching, demetallation, poor stability and conductivity, which can be addressed by fundamentally investigating the electrode/electrolyte interface and alternating the electronic environment of active centers to develop highly efficient catalysts [42,43]. Commonly used molecular catalysts are transition metal porphyrin and phthalocyanine derivatives. Issacs et al. [44] studied a series of poly-M-aminophthalocyanines (M = Co, Ni, Fe) for CO2 electroreduction. Among which, the Co-polymer was only selective to formic acid, Ni-polymer preferred formic acid and formaldehyde, whereas Fe-polymer exhibited high selectivity to formaldehyde and H2. Some other molecular catalysts were also promising in catalyzing CO2RR. Cobalt and nickel phthalocyanines (CoPc, NiPc) [45], and cobalt tetraphenylporphyrin (CoTPP) [46] exhibited high catalytic activity and selectivity for CO production, while another copper rubeanate metal organic framework (CR-MOF) [47] was highly selective to HCOOH generation. Additionally, molecular catalysts can be deposited on electrodes to prevent leaching into aqueous electrolyte, which could improve the CO2RR performances and even change the reaction mechanisms [48]. Developing electrocatalysts with high selectivity and activity is crucial to realize the implementations of industrial CO2RR and improve the sustainable development of society. Herein, a comprehensive review of recent progresses for CO2RR summarized the fabrication strategies of SACs and highlighted the superior electrocatalytic activities of SACs and molecular catalysts toward CO2 reduction. Besides, ex-situ and in situ/operando characterizations are discussed to probe the active sites, study the CO2 reduction mechanism, and explore the catalyst structure-activity relationship. Future perspectives and challenges for CO2RR are provided as well. 2 SACs design strategy Exploring preparation strategies for SACs has been one of the most significant research topics, which favored the development of CO2RR. However, synthesis of SACs is challenging due to the low-metal loading and aggregated particles during preparation process [49]. In order to develop SACs for CO2RR, various methods have been reported, including physical methods [50], mass-selected soft loading [51], and wet chemistry [52]. Physical deposition such as atomic layer deposition (ALD) has been applied to anchor isolated Pt atoms to graphene nanosheet [50]. ALD exhibits many advantages, such as layer-by-layer and uniform deposition on complexed supports, gas-phase self-limiting reactions, and straightforward growth rate of the deposited materials [53]. However, the catalysts prepared via ALD are limited by low metal loading. The utilization of ALD is difficult due to high costs of equipment and low yields of scalable production [49]. Mass-selected soft loading [51] is another physical deposition method, which is widely employed to prepare metal clusters with precise control over the size and amount of metal clusters. But this technique is not appropriate for practical applications because of its high costs and the scalability issues [49]. The most desirable SACs preparation method is the wet-chemistry approach from a practical and economic viewpoint. In this section, we mainly discuss the wet-chemistry approaches to develop efficient SACs for CO2RR. Besides, other synthetic methods and large-scale preparations of SACs were also highlighted, laying foundations for future industrial CO2RR applications. 2.1 Wet-chemistry Most of the wet-chemistry techniques can be employed to synthesize different SACs (Fig. 1 ) on supports for CO2RR [54]. Main procedures of preparing SACs by wet-chemistry include the following three steps [55]: (1) Impregnation, co-precipitation, deposition-precipitation or ion exchange to load the metal precursors on supports. (2) Drying and calcination to turn the metal-support interaction. (3) Reduction or activation to modify the active sites [56]. In this field, defect engineering [11], spatial confinement [57], and coordination [58] are commonly applied strategies. 2.1.1 Defect engineering Well-controlled defects such as vacancies and unsaturated coordination sites are effective in tuning the electronic properties of active sites [55]. A multiple oxygen vacancy-bound Cu SAC on CeO2 [39] was designed for CO2-to-CH4 electro-conversion. Theoretical calculations indicated that there were three oxygen vacancies around each Cu site, which corresponded well with the structural characterizations demonstrating that the low concentration Cu species (< 5%) atomically distributed with a coordination number ∼5. Apart from the oxygen vacancies around metal atoms supported on metal oxides in the above study, defects on carbon materials were well investigated. Rong et al. [59] prepared a vacancy-defect Ni-N3-V SAC on carbon cloth by removing the oxygen atoms in the N/O mixing coordinated Ni-N3O SAC at high temperature. Ni-N3O SAC was fabricated by pyrolyzing cyanuric acid (CA), 2,4-diamino-6-phenyl-1,3,5-triazine (DPT), and Ni salt. The mixture of CA and DPT melted at 460 °C before pyrolysis, facilitating SACs coating on conductive carbon cloth easily, further heating to 500 °C generated the Ni-N3O SACs within 2D carbon nanosheets. The coordinated O atoms and the connected C atom were removed primarily at 500–800 °C, producing a vacancy-defect Ni-N3-V SAC at 800 °C (Fig. 2(a) ). This facile strategy laid foundations for large-scale synthesis of vacancy-defect SACs for CO2RR. In another study, Cheng et al. [36] investigated unsaturated edge-anchored Ni single atoms on porous and high surface defect-rich microwave exfoliated graphene oxide (MEGO) for CO2RR (Fig. 2(b)). The defected small pores in the catalyst confined Ni atoms to prevent aggregation during high temperature pyrolysis, facilitated efficient contact of the Ni and N precursors to form Ni-N species preferentially, and provided exposure of graphene edges with abundant defects working as active sites to anchor Ni atoms, thereby leading to excellent electrochemical performance for CO2 reduction. Very recently, Xi et al. [60] precisely limited the uncoordinated N Species in the Ni-N4 SAC using the joule heating strategy, with 80% N dopants coordinating with metal elements. The preclusion of the unfavorable miscellaneous N species (graphitic N, pyrrolic N, and pyridinic N) was the key factor to optimize the CO2-to-CO conversion performance, which inhibited HER significantly, thus resulting in remarkable selectivity and unprecedented activity. In addition, most remained N dopants that coordinated with Ni were thermodynamically stable, which enabled an excellent electrocatalytic and chemical stability of the Ni SAC. This strategy was further expanded to develop other metal SACs (Fe, Co, Cu, Zn), indicating its universality for the SACs fabrication. Manipulating the in-plane defects of M-N-C SAC was confirmed effective in regulating the CO2RR performances. Ni et al. [61] improved the activity of intrinsic carbon defects by coupling Fe-N4 single atoms through pyrolyzing carbon-rich carbon nitride (C-g-C3N4) with small amount of Fe salt. The as-prepared Fe SAC with a graphene-like morphology was highly active for CO production, due to the active sites of the intrinsic defects instead of the Fe-N4 center, promoting CO2 reduction with the electron-proton decoupling procedure. Besides, the Fe-N4 coupled intrinsic defect delivered a reduced energy barrier for CO2RR and prohibited HER. This defect engineering facilitated exposure of active sites, fast electron transfer and strong intrinsic activity of defects sites, thus inducing superior CO2RR performances. In the following study, Pan et al. [62] reported a facile and massive fabrication of isolated Fe-N4 sites on hierarchical carbon nanotube (CNT) and graphene nanoribbon (GNR) network (Fe-N/CNT@GNR-x, x is the KMnO4:CNT mass ratio) with different GNR content via adjusting the added amount of KMnO4 in the oxidized CNT solution followed by calcinating with urea (Figs. 2(c)–(e)). CNT was decompressed into CNT@GNR and finally GNR by alternating the amount of KMnO4. Among which, Fe-N/CNT@GNR-2 exhibited four locations to host the isolated Fe-N4 sites, namely CNT, GNR bulk, GNR armchair edge, and GNR zigzag edge. For comparison, Fe-N/CNT and Fe-N/GNR had one (CNT bulk) and three positions (GNR bulk plane, GNR armchair edges, and GNR zigzag edges) to accommodate atomic Fe-N4 sites, respectively. The CNT and zigzag sites promoted CO2 activation and *COOH intermediates formation, while the zigzag and armchair edges facilitated *CO desorption by weakening the *CO adsorption. Fe-N/CNT@GNR-2 delivered outstanding CO2RR performance which originated from its largest active area and sufficient mass transfer. Han et al. [63] utilized F doping to modulate the electronic structure of the Ni-N4 active sites by a one-step polymer-assisted pyrolysis approach (Fig. 2(f)). The developed F-tuned Ni SAC displayed high Ni content (5.92 wt%) and a morphology of ultrathin nanosheet for high surface communication. Therefore, a high FECO over 95% and an outstanding CO evolution rate of 1146 mmol gcat −1 h−1 were achieved. Besides, F incorporation into the Ni-N4 active sites promoted CO2 activation with reduced energy barrier (Fig. 2(g)), and enhanced CO selectivity by favoring *COOH intermediate generation, which was theoretically confirmed by the more positive difference between the thermodynamic limiting potentials for CO2RR and HER than that without F-doping (Fig. 2(h)). Different from the above studies, Wu et al. [64] engineered a polymeric cobalt phthalocyanine network (CoPc) with rich defects using an in situ polycondensation method. This approach facilitated strong binding energy to CO2 and altered the electronic property of the obtained defective polymeric CoPc, leading to superior electrochemical performances. As discussed above, various metal SACs (Cu, Co, Ni, Fe, Zn) were developed successfully by defect engineering. When using this strategy, some challenges need to be overcame. Firstly, the defects should be constructed rationally and successfully, which guaranteed the introduction of defects into the coordination structure of single atoms. Nevertheless, limited characterization techniques present an obstacle to investigate the defect-related catalytic mechanisms. The defects should be well probed to avoid their disappearance when introducing the metal precursors. Compared with other strategies for SACs preparation, the defect engineering introduced defects to modulate the electronic environments around the single atoms. Therefore, the enhanced charge transfer between single atoms and defects could prevent aggregation. In addition, the defect engineering strategy can control the metal loadings by applying different concentrations of defect. The defects on supports not only favor unique atomic structure formation, but also tune the electronic properties of supports, thus improving the overall electrochemical performances of catalysts for CO2RR. 2.1.2 Spatial confinement Single atoms are confined spatially into size-defined pores of MOFs/zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) or porous structures to prevent migration. Zhao et al. [16] developed a ZIF-8 assisted Ni SAC for CO2RR by heating the Ni-ZIF-8 precursor at 1000 °C under Ar. They employed a double-solvent approach to confine Ni2+ within ZIF-8 pores, getting the Ni-ZIF-8 precursor. Which was thermally treated to evaporate Zn atoms and get the Ni SAC (Fig. 3(a) ). This synthetic strategy, based on ionic exchange between Zn nodes and adsorbed Ni2+, successfully developed highly efficient Ni SAC for CO2 reduction. In another study, unsaturated Ni-N sites (NiN2V2) on porous carbon [65] were fabricated by pyrolyzing Zn/Ni bimetallic ZIF-8 at 1000 °C in Ar, which suppressed HER significantly and exhibited high intrinsic activity to CO2RR. Very recently, Wu et al. [66] investigated the effects of a series of porous porphyrinic triazine frameworks (PTF-ZnNi x , x = 0, 5, 20, 100, x refers to molar percentage of Ni-TPPCN monomer) on spatially separating the Ni-N4 sites for efficient CO2-to-CO conversion (Fig. 3(b)). These PTF frameworks were developed by polymerizing different molar ratios of the monomers of [5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-cyanophenyl)porphyrinato]-Ni (Ni-TPPCN) or TPPCN with ZnCl2 existence. Controlling the ratio of Ni-TPPCN and TPPCN monomers gave different distances between the Ni-N4 units separated by in situ formed Zn-N4 units. Because of this strategy achieving successful spatial sites implementation, pyrolyzing PTF-ZnNi5 with Ni-N4 units separated by Zn-N4 moieties at 1000 °C resulted in fully isolated Ni atoms and the obtained sample was denoted as Ni5-PFT-1000. While calcinating PTF-ZnNi x (x = 20, 100) produced porous carbon with Ni NPs presence as the spatial separation of Ni-N4 units were restricted by Zn-N4 existing or not, which afforded Ni migration and aggregation. Therefore, the porous Ni5-PTF-1000 outperformed Ni x -PFT-1000 (x = 20, 100) with higher FECO, larger j CO and turnover frequency (TOF). This work presented a facile spatial separation of Ni sites for superior CO2-to-CO conversion. Apart from the spatial confinement of Ni atoms, several studies reported Fe and Co atoms confined by MOFs or porous structures. Pan et al. [67] prepared M-N-C SACs with well-defined bulk- and edge-hosted M-N4 sites (M = Fe, Co) by calcinating the Fe- or Co-doped ZIF-8 at 1100 °C in N2, respectively (Fig. 3(c)). Fe (or Co) atoms were stabilized via covalent bonds with 2-methylimidazole rather than physically absorbed within the ZIF-8 pores. Zn in ZIF-8 worked as spacers to distribute Fe (or Co) during the high-temperature pyrolysis, avoiding metal clusters formation. Similarly, ZIF-8 was also used to spatially confine Fe atoms [68], generating Fe-N sites which were then anchored on CoPc via impregnation (Fig. 3(d)). In the as-developed catalyst, CoPc promoted CO desorption and the Fe-N sites suppressed HER synergistically, thus achieving superior CO2RR performances. Recently, Adli et al. [69] employed ZIF-8 to confine FeN4 sites for CO2-to-CO conversion. For the FeN4 sites, the extrinsic morphology was alternated by engineering the particle size and Fe doping to optimize the porosity, catalytic surface area and the carbon support graphitization. While the intrinsic activity was controlled by various pyrolysis temperatures which effected the Fe–N bonds length and the local strains. DFT calculations demonstrated the close relationship between the improved intrinsic activity for CO2RR and the optimal local strain of the Fe–N bond. In another study, Zhang et al. [70] confined Fe single atoms into a multiscale carbon foam for CO2-to-CO conversion using a SiO2 template. The carbon foam consisted of graphene nanosheets provided fast electron transfer, on which the coordinated Fe-N4 active sites were responsible for the durable stability over 60 h CO2 electrolysis. Song et al. [71] fabricated a high metal loading Co SAC (3.4 wt%) on porous N-doped 3D hollow carbon (Figs. 3(e)–(f)) derived from ZIF-67 using a ZnO nanosphere template. Calcination at 900 °C contributed to generating the Co SAC with coordinated Co-C2N2 active sites (Fig. 3(g)) on carbon supports, where ZnO nanosphere was reduced and evaporated because of the in situ formed carbon and the low boiling point of Zn (907 °C). Excessive Zn evaporation could prevent Co atoms aggregation and maintain the porous structure. According to the above discussion, common MOF or ZIF-derived SACs (Ni, Fe, Co SACs) are developed by the spatial confinement strategy, which is based on encapsulating isolated metal precursors into the pores of MOFs/ZIF. The key issue of using this strategy is choosing suitable metal precursors and supporting materials with uniform cage/pore size to ensure the confinement of metal species, which is also the main disadvantage of this preparation method. To stabilize metal atoms, high-temperature pyrolysis of MOFs is usually conducted to create N species as anchoring sites or suitable supports are applied to anchor metal atoms by their skeletons. Because of the restriction of metal atoms within the porous support by the spatial confinement strategy, migration and aggregation are significantly suppressed while CO2RR performances are improved by the synergism between signal metal atom sites and shape-selective supports. 2.1.3 Coordination design Rational design of coordination sites to bind metal atoms against agglomeration and migration is promising to synthesis SACs for CO2RR. The M-N coordination sites can effectively prevent metal aggregation due to the strong interaction between metal atoms and the supports. Using carbon materials, SACs with active sites of Ni-N [72], Fe-N5 [73] on N-doped graphene, Cu-N on carbon black [74], Zn-N on graphene [75], and Ni-Fe-N on nitrogenated carbon [76] as well as other M-N sites were successfully prepared and well investigated. A family of M-N x moieties (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) were fabricated by pyrolyzing bipyridine-based coordinated polymers and various transition metals [77]. The fabricated M-N-C exhibited hierarchical structures with interconnected macropores and homogeneous distribution of coordinated M-N sites as well as N-containing carbon lattice (Fig. 4(a) ). A similar series of M-N-C (M = Fe, Co, or Ni) [78] was developed using silica-templated pyrolysis of o-phenylenediamine. These two works demonstrated successful preparation of M-N sites for CO2RR. In the following study, Lu et al. [79] designed a Ni SAC with atomically distributed Ni atoms on N-doped carbon framework by simply pyrolyzing the mixture of dicyandiamide and 2-methylimidazole with Zn/Ni salts (Fig. 4(b)). The developed high metal loading Ni SAC (6.63 wt%) exhibited irregular bamboo-like carbon nanotubes with abundant low-coordinated Ni-N x -C sites, which delivered strong bonding with CO2 •– intermediate and low CO adsorption energy, contributing to excellent performances for CO2RR. Surprisingly, Cheng et al. [80] designed a single Ni atom-dispersed N-doped carbon nanotubes catalyst with extremely high metal loading (20 wt%) using a multi-step pyrolysis of Ni2+ and C2H8N2 at 350, 650 and 700–900 °C. Because of the coordinated Ni-N4 sites, the as-developed Ni SAC exhibited outstanding activity for CO2-to-CO electro-conversion. Yang et al. [72] developed a Ni SAC with atomically distributed and low-valent Ni(I) on N-doped graphene matrix by calcinating amino acid, melamine and Ni2+ in Ar. DFT demonstrated delocalization of the Ni 3d orbital and charge transfer from Ni(I) to the C 2p orbital in CO2, forming CO2 δ− species, which reduced the energy barrier for CO2RR. Very recently, Zhang et al. [81] employed a post-synthetic metal substitution strategy to develop Ni SACs with different N coordination numbers (Ni-N x -C) on N-doped carbon derived from metal-organic frameworks. The Ni-N3-C catalyst outperformed Ni-N4-C for CO2RR with a superior FECO, as the lower Ni coordination number significantly facilitated COOH* formation to promote CO2 reduction. To investigate the CO2 catalysis effect of Ni sites, Kim et al. [82] developed two well-defined coordinated Ni sites of tetraphenylporphyrin (N4-TPP) and 21-oxatetraphenylporphyrin (N3O-TPP) using a modified Lindsey's methods. They concluded that the broken ligand-field symmetry was crucial for CO2 reduction, which subordinated an increased Ni redox potential to yield NiI. Besides, the ligand-field symmetry and strength were associated with the Ni center stability. This work revealed the structure-activity/stability relationship by studying various coordinated Ni-N sites, helping to develop efficient Ni SACs for CO2RR. In another study, Jeong et al. [83] supported a hierarchical flower-like Ni-imidazolate coordination polymers with well-defined Ni atoms on CNT. The obtained Ni SAC exhibited a conductive CNT backbone for fluent charge transfer and a large surface area to expose dense Ni atom active sites for fast mass transfer. The abundantly exposed Ni atom sites accessed CO2 reactants easily, attaining a recorded TOF of 439000 h−1 and a high FECO of 99% at low overpotential of 0.24 V vs. RHE in an alkaline flow cell. The following studies were devoted to Fe SACs fabricated by coordination strategy. Zhang et al. [73] dispersed FeN5 sites in the N-doped graphene matrix by coordinating FeN4 SAC, derived from calcination of cross-linked Hemin and melamine, with N-doped graphene via pyrolyzing excessive melamine and defective graphene (Fig. 4(c)). For comparison, directly heating hemin generated Fe nanoparticles with few single Fe-N x sites. Atomic-resolution STEM-ADF of FeN5 catalyst confirmed Fe atoms distribution in carbon matrix without aggregation into particles. This work indicated successful preparation of Fe SAC with tunable coordination configurations for CO2RR. In another study, Ye et al. [84] created Fe-N active sites on ZIF surface by calcinating ammonium ferric citrate functionalized ZIF-8. Because of the cage-type pore structure of ZIF-8 with large pore cavities (11.6 Å) connected by small pore apertures (3.4 Å), citrate ion was anchored onto ZIF-8 surface instead of its small pores, favorable to the formation of the highly exposed Fe-N active sites. The prepared Fe SAC demonstrated outstanding mass activity to oxygen reduction reaction and CO2RR. A mesoporous nitrogen-doped carbon nanoparticles with isolated Fe atoms (mesoNC-Fe) [85] was prepared for CO2 reduction to CO using the pyrolysis of Fe-containing ZIF-8 with SiO2 template. The SiO2 template was effective in suppressing Fe nanoparticles formation, generating Fe atoms preferentially, and facilitating high surface area and mesopores. The final product of mesoNC-Fe was confirmed with local coordination sphere of Fe in a FePc structure with H2O/OH moieties, realizing high activity towards CO production. Pan et al. [58] employed an N-coordination approach to prepare Co SAC for CO2RR with uniform distribution of Co-N5 sites on hollow N-doped carbon spheres (HNPCSs) derived from polymers. The core@shell SiO2@melamine-resorcinol- formaldehyde polymer spheres (MRFPSs) prepared using a modified Stöber method [86] were pyrolyzed at 700 °C under Ar to obtain SiO2@N-doped porous carbon spheres. After HF etching, the Co-N coordination was constructed to get the final product Co-N5/HNPCSs SAC (Fig. 4(d)), which exhibited good stability over 10 h CO2 electrolysis. The atomic Co-N5 site was the dominating catalytic center to activate CO2, facilitate key intermediate COOH* formation and desorb CO. In another study, Wang et al. [87] regulated the coordination number over Co sites by calcinating Zn/Co bimetallic ZIF at high temperature (Fig. 4(e)). The pyrolysis contributed to Zn evaporation and Co ions reduction from the carbonized 2-methyl imidazole linker. Besides, CoII-imidazolate-CoII linkages decomposed at elevated temperature, resulting in CN fragments release and Co–N bonds decay. Therefore, well-controlled coordination numbers of 4, 3, and 2 were realized by increasing the pyrolysis temperature from 800 to 900 and 1000 °C, respectively. Similarly, Guan et al. [29] varied the pyrolysis temperature to regulate the coordinated Cu-N x sites on carbon nanosheets derived from Cu(BTC)(H2O)3 MOF for CH4 and C2H4 production. Very recently, a study of tuning axial coordination structure over Cd SAC for CO2RR revealed that the catalyst with an optimized CdN4S1 moiety incorporated in carbon matrix exhibited outstanding performance for CO production [88], which was attributed to the intrinsic catalytic activity of Cd atoms and the unique axial coordinated CdN4S1 configuration. According to the theoretical calculations, Cd atom was above the plane of graphene matrix for CdN4 SAC because of the large Cd atomic radius, which was different from other metal SACs (MN4, M = Fe, Co, Ni) with both metal and N atoms being in one plane. Therefore, Cd atom was assumed to connect with the adjacent graphene layers. Further introduction of N or S atom of the adjacent graphene layer into the CdN4 axial positions was conducted to generate CdN5 and CdN4S1. The S introduction afforded a decreased free energy barrier of CO2RR because of the high spin density and charge delocalization of S atom. The CdN4S1 SAC delivered the lowest energy barrier for CO2 reduction due to its well-tuned axial coordination. Different from the coordination engineered SACs with single metal center as above discussion, the following study of SAC with bimetallic centers (Ni-N and Fe-N) revealed that varying the configuration structures of the metal-N sites or applying different potentials facilitated efficient high-temperature CO2-to-CO conversion with controllable molar ratios of CO/H2 (∼1:3 to ∼4:1) [89]. For the SAC with anchored bimetallic Ni-Fe and controllable Ni-N4 and Fe-N4 coordination in a 3D carbon hybrid, the Fe atoms were confirmed as reactive sites and intermediates adsorption sites for CO2 reduction, while Ni atoms were introduced to reduce the high CO* adsorption capacity of Fe atoms, which overcame the issues of decreased stability and CO2RR inactivation by strong CO* adsorption of Fe atoms, thereby alternating the energies barrier and enhancing the stability. This work indicated the synergistic effect of Ni-N4 and Fe-N4 with well-controlled coordination structures for practical application of CO2RR. Another binary Cu-Fe site coordinated with N was distributed on porous carbon derived from ZIF, outperforming its Cu-N-C and Fe-N-C SAC counterparts, because of the synergistic effects of the bimetallic sites [90]. This synergistic effect increased the CO2 adsorption enthalpy and reduced the activation energy, thereby improving the CO2RR performances. Besides the discussed transition metal SACs as above, there were two studies about noble metal SACs fabricated by coordination strategy. He et al. [91] developed a Pd SAC with Pd-N4 sites for CO2-to-CO conversion by pyrolyzing glucose, dicyandiamide and Pd2+. The well-dispersed Pd-N4 active centers not only stabilized and activated adsorbed CO2, but also favored *CO desorption, thereby facilitating CO production and improving CO2RR capability at low overpotentials. Recently, Li et al. [92] fabricated a dual-atom Ag2/graphene catalyst (Ag2-G) with well-defined AgN3-AgN3 active sites for CO2-to-CO conversion by anchoring a binuclear Ag complex on graphene oxide via π–π interaction and subsequently pyrolyzing at 550 °C in N2. For comparison, Ag SAC (Ag1-G) with AgN4 active sites was obtained using a mononuclear Ag complex. The Ag2-G delivered higher intrinsic CO2 activity than Ag1-G, confirmed by its larger CO production turnover frequencies per Ag site (30 vs. 5.1 s−1). Besides, DFT indicated that the dual-atom Ag site facilitated *COOH formation, leading to outstanding stability over 36 h continuous CO2 electrolysis. Coordination strategy has been employed to successfully fabricate different metal SACs (Ni, Fe, Co, Cu, Zn, Mn, Cd, Pd) and several dual-atom catalysts (Ni-Fe, Cu-Fe, Ag-Ag). When using this strategy, appropriate metal precursors should be selected to ensure the formation of uniform coordination sites. In addition, experimental conditions such as pyrolysis temperature would significantly influence the interactions between coordinated atoms and metal atoms. This interaction could incorporate single metal atoms to generate catalytically active centers, which suppressed migration and aggregation. Compared with traditional wet-chemistry methods, the coordination strategy is capable of fabricating SACs with higher stability. Besides, the electronic configurations of active centers are precisely controlled by the coordinated atoms, thereby enhancing the activity and selectivity for CO2RR. Furthermore, highly tunable ligands and metal nodes make it possible to develop dual-atom or multiatom catalysts with multifunctional active centers. 2.2 Other synthesis methods Other than the above discussed synthetic approaches, some novel methods have been designed to prepare SACs for CO2RR. Zhao et al. [93] employed a solid-state diffusion method to directly distribute Ni atoms from bulk Ni foil onto N-doped carbon layer (Fig. 5(a) ), obtaining a hierarchical Ni SAC (Fig. 5(b)). The fabricated Ni SAC exhibited large surface, favorable to accessibility of dissolved CO2 and CO desorption. Besides, the Ni single sites were responsible for CO2 activation. In another study, Yang et al. [94] employed an in situ thermal atomization method to fabricate a Ni SAC on porous N-doped carbon (NC) support (Fig. 5(c)). Because of the assistance of NC support with abundant defects, this strategy not only converted Ni NPs to Ni atoms that were mainly concentrated on NC surface, but also generated numerous pores which facilitated efficient contact of CO2 and Ni active sites. The Ni NPs broke C–C bonds on the surface and drilled into the carbon matrix, leaving pores on the NC surface (Fig. 5(d)). The coordinated Ni-N sites were favorable to mass transfer for CO2RR, delivering excellent activity, selectivity and stability. In the following study, Jiang et al. [95] fabricated a Ni SAC with Ni atoms embedded in graphene shells by electrospinning polymer nanofibers with Ni and N precursors and subsequent calcination. During the cooling down process, the C-Ni alloy formed at high temperature precipitated out and transformed into graphene layers on the Ni metal surface. The isolated Ni atoms exhibited favorable CO2RR over HER. Similarly, a facile and effective electrospinning method was used to design a 3D net-like free-standing and hierarchically porous nanofiber decorated by Co single atoms for efficient CO2-to-CO conversion [96]. Electrospinning was also employed to fabricate a Sn functionalized N-doped porous carbon nanofiber for CO2RR (Fig. 5(e)) [25]. The developed Sn SAC exhibited a porous 3D structure with nanofibers decorated by microspheres (Fig. 5(f)). Because of the porous structure and coordinated Sn- pyridinic N sites, excellent CO production and catalytic activity were achieved. Very recently, a novel method of crosslinking and self-assembly of graphene quantum dots (GQDs) was applied for prepare SACs with high metal loading [97]. Using this strategy, the Ir-SAC achieved a high Ir loading of 41.6 wt%, seven times improvement in comparison to the benchmarks [98]. Besides the development of Ir-SAC, other metal SACs such as Pt- and Ni-SACs with high metal loading of ~32.3 wt% (Pt) and ~15 wt% (Ni) were fabricated successfully. The application of GQDs provided numerous surface anchoring sites for large single atoms loadings because of the small size of GQDs. Besides, the GQDs structure underwent no significant evolution during pyrolysis, which avoided the atoms aggregation by providing a stable and large spacing between the metal atoms. Furthermore, the strong chelation/complexation effect between metal cations and amine groups contributed to not only the uniform distribution of metal cations on GQDs surfaces, but also the GQDs interconnect and their self-assembly into a layered structure. The developed Ni-SACs presented significantly enhanced activity to CO2RR with increased Ni loading. Another trapping-and-exposing strategy was employed to develop a high metal loading (10.8 wt%) Fe-N4 single atoms on carbon support for efficient O2 and CO2 reduction [99]. In detailed, metal ions were trapped by sucrose to prevent Fe3+ migration and agglomeration, followed by introducing the mesoporous SBA-15 template to realize abundant Fe-N4 exposure. Because of the low free energy of the sucrose-Fe3+ chelating reaction, highly dispersed atomic Fe-N4 sites were developed. Surprisingly, a ultrahigh metal loading Cd SAC with isolated Cd-N4 active sites on carbon support was developed using a special gas-migration, trapping, and emitting strategy for efficient CO2-to-CO conversion [100]. In this strategy, the gas-migration and trapping processes (≤ 750 °C) facilitated the ultrahigh Cd loading, while the emitting process modulated the loading content from 30.3 wt% to 1.4 wt%. The as-fabricated Cd SAC with 18.4 wt% metal loading achieved a maximum FECO of 91.4%. Operando infrared spectroscopy identified the existence of the key intermediates *COO−, *COOH, and *CO, confirming the proton-decoupled electron-transfer mechanism of CO2RR. DFT indicated that the Cd-N4 active sites promoted *COOH hydrogenation with a reduced Gibbs free energy, thereby boosting CO2 reduction. To achieve efficient CO2-to-CH3OH conversion (FECH3OH 59.1%), Zhao et al. [101] immobilized Cu atoms onto the MXene by selectively etching the hybrid A layers (Al and Cu) in quaternary MAX phases (Ti3(Al1–x Cu x )C2) because of the various saturated vapor pressures of Al- and Cu-containing products. The obtained SA-Cu-MXene SAC exhibited immobilization of Cu atoms onto MXene with dominant surface functional group (Cl x ) on the outmost Ti layers (Ti3C2Cl x ) via Cu–O bonds. The Cu single atoms with unsaturated electronic structure (Cu δ+, 0 < δ < 2) facilitated the formation of absorbed CHO* intermediate with a low energy barrier, thereby promoting CO2 reduction. More facile methods were employed to construct SACs. Dilan Karapinar et al. [30] directly pyrolyzed the ball-milled dry-phase mixture of ZIF-8, Cu2+, and 1,10-phenanthroline at 1050 °C in Ar, obtaining Cu-N-C SAC with isolated Cu-N4 active sites distributing in amorphous carbon. Cu sites were reversibly converted into metallic Cu nanoparticles during CO2 electrolysis. This work paved the way to novel methods to prepare SACs without metal aggregation for CO2-to-ethanol conversion with high Faradic efficiency up to 55%. Apart from the carbon support, in another study, α-Co(OH)2 support was employed to anchor atomically distributed Ir using a one-step co-reduction of Co2+ and Ir3+ in NaBH4 at 25 °C for 3 h [102]. The prepared Ir SAC showed a 3D spherical structure consisting of graphene-like flexible ultrathin nanosheets. Ir atoms were homogeneously dispersed on the entire α-Co(OH)2 support without Ir nanoparticles formation. This Ir SAC was applied for CO2-to-CO conversion and displayed superior electrochemical performances. 2.3 Large scale synthesis of SACs According to the above discussion, physical approaches for SACs such as ALD and mass-selected loading are restricted by high costs and low yield, which are not favorable to scale-up production. The wet-chemistry method is more desirable to fabricate SACs considering the economic conditions, but some chemical methods are relatively difficult to be applied in large-scale synthesis because of sophisticated operating procedures and sensitive conditions. Recently, more universal preparation methods are designed for SACs. Duan et al. [103] prepared Fe, Co, and Ni-SACs with holey graphene as support. Qu et al. [104] employed a gas-migration method to fabricate Cu, Co, or Ni-SACs on ZIF-8 support with abundant defect sites. However, the synthetic strategy allowing mass production of SACs has proven elusive. Furthermore, migration, aggregation and sintering of small nanoparticles or single atoms on supports is unavoidable to some extent during the preparation process, hindering the industrial applications of SACs. Therefore, developing feasible strategies for large-scale synthesis of SACs with superior electrochemical performances for CO2RR is significantly promising and attractive. A universal “ligand-mediated” method [105] was employed to fabricate different M SACs (M = Ni, Mn, Fe, Co, Cr, Cu, Zn, Ru, Pt, and combinations thereof) for efficient CO2 electroreduction to CO by calcinating carbon black absorbed metal complexes derived from various metal salts and 1,10-phenanthroline (Fig. 6(a) ). Using this method, Ni SAC with 2.5 wt% Ni loading was prepared at large-scale (> 1 kg) successfully. In another study, Zheng et al. [106] also developed a Ni SAC on commercial carbon black at gram scale using a simple and scalable synthetic method by absorbing Ni2+ onto carbon black and subsequently calcinating with urea. Activated carbon could trap Ni single atoms via coordination, which were the active sites for CO2-to-CO conversion (Fig. 6(b)). Similarly, using a facile synthetic strategy, our group fabricated a single Ni atom catalyst with distribution of Ni atoms on multi-walled carbon nanotube (Ni-N-CNT) at gram-scale for CO2RR [107]. The coordinated Ni-N active sites generated during pyrolysis were anchored on CNTs and showed high selectivity to CO formation, while the CNT support provided fast pathways for electron and mass transfer. Therefore, the Ni-N-CNT exhibited a high FECO of 94% and excellent stability. Recently, a universal domino strategy was employed for mass production of single metal atoms on N-doped carbon nanosheets (M-SA/NC, M = Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Mo, Pd and their combinations FeCo, FeNi, FeCoNi) for CO2-to-CO conversion [108]. In this strategy, polyaniline (PANI) was ball-milled with appropriate salts (e.g., NiCl2, NaCl and NaNO3) and followed by pyrolysis. During which, NaNO3 was in-situ decomposed into gases and thus blowing PANI, then the microporous Ni-SA/NC SAC with multiple ultrathin layers were created by O2 etching the carbonized PANI and the metal particles were treated by CO etching (Fig. 6(c)). The as-fabricated Ni-SA/NC was highly selective to CO production with large partial current density (j CO) of 213.2 mA cm−2 and FECO of 96.9% in a flow cell. Rather than conventional Ni atoms, the isolated N atoms in NiN4 species were the active sites for CO2RR, as the adjacent pyrrolic-N promoted electrons shift from Ni 4s orbitals to neighboring N 2s orbitals in NiN4, giving a high N 2s electron density for COOH* formation, and thereby promoting CO production. Anther facile one-pot strategy, two-step pyrolysis of the mixture of polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), melamine, and Ni2+ at 600 and 900 °C, achieved large-scale production of various single atoms (Ni, Fe, Co, Cu, Zn) anchored on F, N co-doped carbon nanosheets [109]. Utilization of PTFE resulted in space isolation of Ni ions and suppression of nanotube generation, thus stabilizing single Ni ions and preventing nanoparticles aggregation. The developed Ni SAC (NiSAs/FN-CNSs) exhibited significantly high selectivity and activity to CO2RR and glycerol oxidation reaction upgrading into formate. When coupled with an interconnected CoSe2 nanostructure anode in flow cell, high current density (100 mA cm−2) with stable FECO (~90%) and FEformate (~90%) over 400 h operation was obtained. In situ attenuated total reflection-infrared spectroscopy (ATR-IR) monitored the CO2RR intermediates, which demonstrated the C=O stretching of *COOH (~1400 cm−1) became stronger upon increasing potential and reached the maximum value at −0.9 V vs. RHE, verifying the rate-determining step of *COOH intermediate formation for CO2RR, consistent with the DFT calculations. This work offered a practically sustainable and economic strategy for CO2-to-CO and glycerol-to-formate conversion, promoting its industrial application. In the following study, Yang et al. [110] prepared isolated Cu atoms decorated through-hole carbon nanofibers at large scale for CO2-to-CH3OH conversion (Fig. 6(d)). Steps of the strategy included restricting Cu ions within ZIF-8 pores by a double-solvent method, embedding into polyacrylonitrile nanofibers via electrospinning, pre-oxidating at 220 °C in air and finally pyrolyzing at 900 °C in Ar. During the pyrolysis, Cu2+ reduction was induced by adjacent carbon species. Cu-N coordination formed through the Lewis acid-base interactions. Attributed to the self-supporting and through-hole structure, the as-developed Cu SAC delivered abundant Cu single atoms, boosting CO2RR with excellent methanol selectivity up to 44%. Another work by Zu et al. [111] reported a kilogram-scale (828.6 g) single atom Sn δ+ on N-doped graphene prepared by a quick freeze-vacuum drying-calcination method (Fig. 6(e)). The fast cooling induced by liquid nitrogen ensured uniform distribution of Sn2+ in graphene oxide ice, and the calcination in mixed gas Ar/NH3 favored N doping into the graphene. The final product exhibited a sheet-like structure with homogeneous Sn atoms dispersing on graphene, contributing to CO2-to-HCOOH conversion with superior stability over 200 h continuous electrolysis, attributed to the positively charged Sn atoms which promoted the stabilization of CO2 •−* and HCOO−* to guarantee CO2 activation and protonation, as well as the N-doping that facilitated the rate-limiting step of formate desorption. Most large-scale produced SACs contribute to generating C1 species including CO, CH3OH, and HCOOH, more efforts should be devoted to preparing efficient catalysts at industrial scale for CO2-to-C2+ conversion. Besides, the large-scale fabrication of SACs is challenged by low metal loadings, making it difficult to sustain high selectivity during long-term stability testing. Additionally, the carbon nanosheets support on electrodes is restricted by gas diffusion limit when piled up layer by layer, reducing the current density for practical applications [106]. Other mostly used carbon precursors such as graphene oxides, carbon nanotubes, and MOFs or ZIFs are not economically viable for large-scale production and include relatively complicated fabrication procedures. In this case, commercially available and low-cost carbon materials such as carbon black should be chosen to develop earth-abundant SACs (Ni, Fe, Co) at large-scale. Besides, exploring more facile methods for massive fabrication of SACs paves the way to future development of industrial CO2RR application. 3 CO2RR application 3.1 M-N-C SACs The SACs developed above presented excellent CO2RR performances with durable stability, high activity and selectivity. In this section, CO2RR applications of SACs, mainly prepared by wet chemistry and some other synthesis methods, will be summarized (Tables 2 and 3 ). Besides, the structure-performance relationship and catalytic mechanisms will be discussed. A series of M-N-C SACs (M = Sn, Co, Fe, Mn, Ni) were investigated for efficient CO2RR in a continuous flow reactor [112]. Co-N-C preferentially facilitated HER, while Mn-N-C and Fe-N-C delivered relatively good CO2RR performances compromised by their high CO* binding energy. Ni-N-C and Sn-N-C exhibited high productivity of 589 L CO m−2 h−1 at −1.39 V vs. RHE and 751 g HCOO− m−2 h−1 at −1.47 V vs. RHE, respectively. Different transition M-N-C SACs (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) [77] were also studied for CO2RR in H-cell. Ni-N-C and Fe-N-C exhibited maximum FECO of 85% and 65% at −0.78 and −0.55 V vs. RHE, respectively, whereas Co-N-C mainly generated H2 with production above 80%. Similarly, Hu et al. [78] discovered that selectivity and activity to CO of M-N-C catalysts was generally ordered as Ni > Fe ≫ Co, and Ni, Fe ≫ Co, respectively. In another study, Pan et al. [67] explored M-N-C SACs with atomically distributed M-N4 (M = Fe, Co) sites for CO2RR. They found that Fe-N-C showed better intrinsic activity for CO2-to-CO conversion than Co-N-C. Both Fe-N4 and Co-N4 were effective in promoting CO2RR and suppressing HER. DFT demonstrated that the edge-hosted M-N2+2-C8 moieties bridging two adjacent armchair-like graphitic layers, rather than the bulk-hosted M-N4-C10 moieties embedded in a graphitic layer, were the catalytically active sites, on which *COOH were dissociated during CO2RR. The M atoms could adsorb *CO, and the C atoms with dangling bonds next to N could adsorb *OH in the C=O bond cleavage. Particularly, Fe-N2+2-C8 favored CO2RR over HER, exhibiting remarkable CO production. In contrast to the catalytic activity and selectivity orders of M-N-C SACs by above studies, Wang et al. [113] discovered experimentally and theoretically that the M-N-C SACs (M = Fe, Co, Ni) with a metal-pyridine N structure were promising for CO2-to-CO conversion with the selectivity order of Ni > Co > Fe and the activity order of Co > Ni > Fe. More detailed investigations on the applications of transitional M-N-C SACs for CO2RR were discussed in this section. 3.1.1 Ni Ni SACs with Ni-N-C structures have attracted a lot of interest attributed to their excellent performances for CO2RR. Yuan et al. [114] distributed Ni atoms on N-doped hollow carbon spheres (SA-Ni/N-CS) using a semi-sacrificial template strategy. The SA-Ni/N-CS exhibited high selectivity towards CO production with a FECO of 95.1% at −0.8 V vs. REH. Besides, superior long-time stability over 24 h electrolysis was achieved with only 1% and 5% decay in current density and FECO, respectively. DFT demonstrated that CO2 activation by SA-Ni/N-CS was the rate limiting step for CO2-to-CO conversion. Recently, He et al. [115] designed a core-shell nanostructured Ni-NC@Ni with isolated Ni sites using a low-temperature chemical vapor deposition method. The Ni-NC@Ni presented a sheet-like open nanostructure, providing effective mass transport and complete active sites exposure, the Ni nanoparticle core facilitated charge transfer because of its good conductivity, and the abundant Ni-N species in the carbon shell (~4.23 at%) worked as active sites for CO2-to-CO conversion. The Ni-N2 sites displayed relatively moderate binding energy to *COOH and *CO compared to the strong *CO adsorption of the metallic Ni sites. Besides, HER was inhibited on the Ni-N2 species. Therefore, the Ni-NC@Ni exhibited maximum FECO of 87.4%, high j CO of 14.8 mA cm−2, and remarkable stability over 150 h electrolysis at −0.78 V vs. RHE. A bifunctional Ni-N-doped-C-supported Cu catalyst [116] was developed by a combined method of firstly preparing N-doped carbon black as reported [117,118], subsequently depositing Cu nanoparticles via deposition precipitation driven by ammonia, followed by pyrolyzing in 5% H2/Ar. Compared to the benchmark carbon black-supported Cu, the fabricated Ni-N-C supported Cu exhibited 2-fold higher C2H4 partial current density (j C2H4) at −1.05 V vs. RHE (C1/C2 = 0.67) and 10-fold higher j CO. Higher intrinsic activity of the Ni-N-C supported Cu contributed to enhanced C2H4 generation, which synergistically favored sequential CO2 and CO reduction. Two Ni SACs were fabricated at large-scale using carbon black as support. Zheng et al. [106] investigated a Ni SAC with isolated Ni atoms on carbon black (Ni-NCB) at gram scale for CO2-to-CO conversion. Ni-NCB displayed a current density over 100 mA cm−2, and FECO nearly 100% at −0.68 V vs. RHE, surpassing the relatively lower current density and FECO using Ni-CB. Besides, Ni-NCB exhibited a specific CO current density of 111 A g−1, TOF of 3.67 s−1 normalized by mass, long-time stability over 24 h electrolysis with 99% and 95% remaining its initial j CO and FECO, respectively, as well as a CO formation rate of 3.34 L h−1 in a 10 × 10 cm2 unit cell. All these superior performances were attributed to the well-distributed Ni atomic sites which facilitated intermediate *COOH generation. Similarly, Yang et al. [105] fabricated a Ni SAC on carbon support with large production (>1 kg) for CO2-to-CO conversion. The Ni SAC with 2.5 wt% Ni loading exhibited high FECO of 98.9% at −1.2 V vs. RHE and long-time stability over 20 h electrolysis, because of the atomically distributed Ni sites. Followed by these two studies, another two jobs on Ni sites modified carbon black (Ni sites supported on nitrogen-doped carbon [119], Ni-N-C [120]) exhibited high activity and selectivity to CO. The Ni sites supported on nitrogen-doped carbon [119] delivered a high FECO of 92.3% at −0.11 V vs. RHE, attributed to the Ni atoms which facilitated *COOH formation and CO desorption. While Ni-N-C [120] achieved higher FECO of 97% at −0.93 V vs. RHE, as the oxygen-containing functional groups provided the carbon surface with improved Ni2+ uptake and the following Ni species stabilization, resulting in high density of NiN4 active sites. CNT was widely utilized as support for SACs preparation. Pan et al. [121] prepared a Ni SAC for CO2RR based on N-doped carbon-carbon nanotube (NC-CNTs), which provided higher electrocatalytic current than the samples supported on NC and CNTs. The Ni SAC on NC-CNTs exhibited a high FECO (> 90%) over 10 h CO2 electrolysis at −0.8 V vs. RHE, and TOF of 12000 h−1. DFT demonstrated that the Ni–pyrrolic N3 sites were more active than Ni–N4 sites for *COOH formation with lower free energy and CO desorption, leading to efficient CO2-to-CO conversion. In another study, Büchele et al. [26] dispersed Ni atoms on N-doped carbon nanofibers through a combined method of depositing Ni colloid or impregnating Ni2+ firstly, subsequently pyrolyzing and finally acid etching to get the NiCNP- and NiIMP-based catalysts, respectively. NiIMP-based SAC calcinated at 650 °C exhibited high FECO of 82% at −0.6 V vs. RHE because of the Ni-N active sites. Followed by a FECO of 79% for NiIMP-based catalyst calcinated at 950 °C with co-existence of Ni-N sites and evident Ni nanoparticles. In contrast, pyrolyzed NiCNP-based catalysts with mixed Ni atoms and nanoparticles only showed a low FECO (< 45%). Especially, the NiCNP-based catalyst pyrolyzed at 950 °C increased its selectivity toward CO from 38% to 62% by suppressing HER upon repetitive exposure to reaction conditions within five cycles of potentiostatic electrolysis. Besides, acid washing could remove Ni nanoparticles, as well as decreasing the Ni atoms amount and activity simultaneously, which indicated the activity prohibition by acid etching. A Ni SAC on N-doped carbon nanotubes derived from C2H8N2 with high metal content of 20 wt% (NiSA-N-CNTs) was developed and used for CO2RR [80]. The NiSA-N-CNTs exhibited a low onset potential of −0.31 V vs. RHE in CO2-saturated KHCO3, whereas Ni nanoparticles supported on carbon nanotubes (Ni-CNTs) and on nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (Ni-N-CNTs) showed similar activities in N2 and CO2-saturated KHCO3. Moreover, NiSA-N-CNTs delivered high CO formation rate of 4.00 × 10−3 mmol cm−2 min−1 at −0.55 V vs. RHE, two orders of magnitudes higher than that of Ni-CNTs and 6-7 times larger than that of N-CNTs and Ni-N-CNTs. The j CO by NiSA-N-CNTs was 23.5 mA cm−2, 95, 9 and 4 times as high as that by Ni-CNTs, N-CNTs, and Ni-N-CNTs, respectively. High FECO values of 89.0% (at −0.55 V vs. RHE) and 91.3% (at −0.7 V vs. RHE) were achieved by NiSA-N-CNTs. Besides, an outstanding TOF of 11.7 ± 0.2 s−1 at −0.55 vs. RHE was observed for NiSA-N-CNTs, 3 and 93 times greater than that of Ni-N-CNTs and Ni-CNTs, respectively. NiSA-N-CNTs was also stable over 12 h CO2 electrolysis. This work indicated the effectiveness of isolated Ni atoms in activating CO2-to-CO conversion without obvious aggregation and demetallation during the electrolysis. Followed by this study, two Ni SACs with Ni atoms on carbon nanotube derived from ZIF were investigated for CO2 reduction. Lu et al. [79] studied the CO2RR performance of a high metal loading (6.63 wt%) Ni SAC with homogenously distributed Ni atoms on N-doped carbon nanotubes (Ni SAs/NCNTs) derived from ZIF-8, which showed maximum FECO of 97% at −0.9 V vs. RHE, high current density of 57.1 mA cm−2 at −1.0 V vs. RHE, a TOF of 1176 h−1 at −1 V vs. RHE, and durable stability over 30 h electrolysis at −0.75 V vs. RHE with little decay in FECO and j CO. In contrast, Ni/ZIF and Ni/DCD prepared by calcinating the mixture of Ni salt and ZIF-8 or dicyandiamide exhibited inferior performances. Ni/ZIF delivered similar FECO to Ni SAs/NCNTs at potential lower than −0.7 V vs. RHE but a greatly decreased FECO at potential higher than −0.8 V vs. RHE. Both Ni/DCD and the sample N-C fabricated by pyrolyzing ZIF and DCD only exhibited low FECO < 10% at the tested potential range (−0.5 to −1 V vs. RHE). In addition, Ni SAs/NCNTs showed a Tafel slope of 127 mV dec−1, smaller than that of Ni/ZIF (410 mV dec−1), Ni/DCD (636 mV dec−1), and N-C (442 mV dec−1), indicating its faster reaction kinetics. In the Ni SAs/NCNTs system, the low-coordinated Ni-N x sites encapsulated into N-doped carbon nanotubes allowed for the formation of *CO2 •– intermediate, hence, further improving the CO2RR performances. Hou et al. [122] constructed Ni SAC on N-doped carbon nanotubes (Ni/NCTs) derived from metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) using a self-sacrificial template method by calcinating the ZnO@ZIF-NiZn core-shell nanorods. The obtained hierarchically porous Ni/NCTs exhibited nearly 100% selectivity towards CO over a wide potential range from −0.6 V to −1.0 V vs. RHE, high current density of 34.3 mA cm−2 and a TOF of 9366 h−1 at −1.0 V vs. RHE, as well as durability over 20 h without obvious decay in FECO and current density at −0.8 V vs. RHE. These excellent activity and selectivity were attributed to the porous carbon nanotubes as they provided facilely accessible CO2 and electrolytes to Ni active sites. And the Ni-N4 centers facilitated *COOH generation, thus boosting CO2-to-CO conversion. In the following study, Zhu et al. [123] developed rod-like nanoporous Ni SAC with different ratios of Ni atom/Ni nanoparticles on N-doped carbon nanorods using a reported template-free synthetic method [124], which was used for controllable CO production. In general, larger ratio of CO/H2 was observed with increasing the Ni atom/nanoparticles ratio from 1:4.9 to 1:0, which was controlled by changing the HCl etching time (2 to 48 h), generating CO with variable CO/H2 ratios (1:9 to 19:1). Moreover, Ni SAC with 1:0 ratio of Ni-N sites/Ni NP delivered superior FECO of 95.2% over potential range from −0.6 to −0.8 V vs. RHE, and durability over 8 h electrolysis with constant current density (> 15 mA cm−2) at −0.65 V vs. RHE. Some studies were devoted to Ni SACs on 2D carbon materials for CO2RR and attracted much interest. Jiang et al. [95] embedded Ni atoms in graphene shells (NiN-GS) for CO2RR using an electrospinning method. The NiN-GS catalyst showed a high FECO of ∼93.2% with current density of ∼20 mA mg-1 at −0.7 V vs. RHE, corresponding to a TOF of ∼8 s−1 for Ni active site. In addition, good stability of 20 h with remaining 80% of the initial FECO at 0.7 V overpotential was obtained. DFT revealed that Ni active sites not only facilitated CO2 activation and *COOH formation, but also suppressed the HER side reaction. Ma et al. [125] prepared ultrathin Ni and N-co doped carbon nanosheets (Ni-N-CNSs) by in-situ pyrolyzing Ni-citric acid and melamine at 900 °C. Ni-N-CNSs delivered a porous structure with high surface area, abundant mesopores and isolated Ni atoms. As for CO2RR, Ni-N-CNSs achieved extremely high FECO of ∼100%, j CO of 121.4 mA mg−1, CO formation rate of 37.7 μmol mg−1 min−1, and stability over 25 h electrolysis. DFT demonstrated the strong bonding force between Ni sites and CO2 molecules, which is one of the reasons for the enhancement in activity and selectivity toward CO. Yang et al. [72] employed a Ni SAC (A-Ni-NSG) with Ni atoms on N-doped graphene to catalyze CO2RR by calcinating the mixture of amino acid (L-alanine or L-cysteine), melamine and Ni2+. The catalyst delivered high FECO of 97% at −0.5 V vs. RHE, specific current of 350 A gcatalyst −1, TOF of 14800 h−1 at an overpotential of 0.61 V, and excellent long-time stability with retaining 98% of its initial j CO (∼22 mA cm−2) after 100 h electrolysis. These superior performances came from the catalytically active site of monovalent Ni(I) atomic center with a d 9 electronic configuration. Bi et al. [126] dispersed isolated Ni atoms on N-doped graphene by annealing the mixture of g-C3N4 and glucose using an ion-adsorption strategy. The constructed Ni2+@NG SAC with isolated NiN4 moieties was active to CO2RR, which achieved a maximum FECO of 92% at –0.68 V vs. RHE and j CO of 30 mA cm−2 at –0.88 V vs. RHE, much higher than that of N-doped graphene (< 10 mA cm−2). Besides, relatively constant current density over 20 h CO2 electrolysis at –0.58 V vs. RHE was achieved by Ni2+@NG. For comparison, Fe3+@NG and Co2+@NG SACs promoted CO2 reduction with lower selectivity of 85% and 65%, respectively. DFT revealed that the NiN4 active centers facilitated *COOH and *CO intermediate formation, thus boosting high activity for CO production. Liu et al. [127] fabricated a family of M-N-C SACs (M=Fe, Ni, Co, Cu, etc.) for CO2RR using layered montmorillonite template. The prepared M SACs exhibited a hierarchical structure with large surface area. Among which, Ni SAC achieved a high FECO above 90% over the potential range from –0.6 to –1.1 V vs. RHE and 30 h stability with great FECO (> 95%) at –0.9 V vs. RHE in H-cell, as well as significantly increased current density and high FECO above 80% over potential range from –0.7 to –1.1 V vs. RHE in flow cell. While the Fe-SAC displayed outstanding ORR activity with half wave potential of around 0.85 V vs. RHE, superior to that of the Pt/C catalyst (0.84 V vs. RHE). These excellent electrochemical performances originated from the M-N active sites. Similarly, Zhao et al. [128] fabricated a series of metal SACs (Ni, Co, Fe, Cu, Ag, Pd, diatomic Ni/Cu) on 2D supports (graphene, boron nitride, and molybdenum disulfide) using a facile and novel seeding method. The as-prepared Ni SAC with isolated Ni atoms on graphene oxide delivered superior CO2RR performances with 96.5% CO production, TOF of 325.9 h−1 at –0.63 V vs. RHE, and long-term durability over 50 h electrolysis, because of the atomically distributed Ni sites. In another study, Ni atoms were stabilized on conductive reduced graphene oxide (RGO) by tris(2-benzimidazolylmethyl)amine (NTB) ligand aggregation [129], because of the strong interactions between NTB and the GO sheets by π–π interactions and with nickel ions by ligation. The obtained Ni-N-RGO SAC realized a high FECO of 97% at –0.8 V vs. RHE, due to the abundant Ni-N4 active sites on graphene which provided a high activation energy for proton reduction. Additionally, two other studies were devoted to Ni-N sites embedded in graphene for CO2-to-CO conversion. Su et al. [130] constructed coordinated Ni-N sites on graphene by calcinating Ni-pentaethylenehex- amine and GO. The as-fabricated Ni-N-Gr SAC reached a high FECO of 90% at –0.7 to –0.9 V vs. RHE, a 5 h stability at –0.65 V vs. RHE, and a TOF up to 2700 h−1 at –0.7 V vs. RHE, which originated from the coordinated Ni-N active sites. Cheng et al. [36] investigated a Ni SAC with Ni atoms on microwave exfoliated graphene oxide (Ni-N-MEGO, ∼6.9 wt% Ni loading) for CO2-to-CO conversion. Ni-N active sites anchored along the nanopores edges in Ni-N-MEGO resulted in a high FECO of 92.1% with current density of 53.6 mA mg−1 at –0.7 V vs. RHE, and durability over 21 h at –0.55 V vs. RHE with 29.1% decrease in the initial current density and relatively stable FECO (∼89%). The following two studies investigated Ni SACs fabricated by vacancy defect which exhibited outstanding electrochemical performances for CO2 reduction. Jiang et al. [8] constructed Ni-NG SAC with atomic Ni dispersed into graphene nanosheets by incorporating Ni2+ into GO firstly and a subsequent calcination with ammonia at 750 °C. Ni-NG SAC obtained a high FECO of 95% at –0.68 V vs. RHE and remarkable durability over 20 h electrolysis with stable current density (∼12 mA cm−2) and ∼90% CO selectivity in H-cell. When applied in flow cell, Ni-NG exhibited scaled current density (50 mA cm−2) over 8 h CO2 electrolysis, higher selectivity to CO (∼97%), suppressed HER (∼4%), and recorded TOF (∼2.1 × 105 h−1) at 2.78 V. In Ni-G catalyst, Ni atoms coordinated with C vacancies (Ni@vacancies) to form active sites (Ni@SV, Ni@DV) for CO2 reduction. DFT revealed that Ni@SV, Ni-N@SV and the Co-N-C motifs favored COOH* formation, and Ni atomic sites exhibited lower CO desorption barriers but higher H* adsorption energy than Co atomic sites, which clarified the higher selectivity towards CO using Ni-NG rather than Co-NG. In another example, Rong et al. [59] employed a vacancy-defect Ni-N3-V SAC on carbon cloth to catalyze CO2 reduction. The catalyst exhibited a high FECO over 90% at –0.9 V vs. RHE, an extremely high current density of 65 mA cm−2, a record TOF of 1.35 × 105 h−1, and good long-time stability over 14 h with retaining 95% of the initial current density. Both experimental results and DFT calculations indicated that Ni-N3 active sites were effective in boosting CO2RR by lowering the energy barriers for the intermediate COOH* formation and CO desorption. This work indicated the effectiveness of vacancy-defects in tuning the electronic properties and coordination situations of SACs, enhancing their activity. Apart from the Ni atoms distributing in nanospheres, nanofibers, and 2D carbon materials as discussed above, 3D supports were also widely employed to restrict Ni active sites. A Ni, N co-doped carbon SAC derived from polyacrylonitrile (Ni-PACN) was fabricated using a combined method of polymerization, oxidation, and calcination [131]. The obtained Ni-PACN with a flower-like superstructure showed a nearly 100% FECO over a potential range from –0.7 to –1.1 V vs. RHE, while the Ni-free catalyst (PACN) made negligible contribution to CO production. Besides, the j CO of Ni-PACN increased with Ni loading up to 2 wt% and plateaued at 14 mA cm−2 with higher Ni loadings, indicating that higher Ni loading (> 2 wt%) leaded to Ni nanoparticle aggregation instead of creating additional active sites. The coordinated Ni-pyrrolic N sites with a distorted square-planar geometry, similar to that of Ni porphyrin, were the active centers for CO2 reduction. In another study, Ni SAC derived from graphene aerogel (NiSA-NGA) [132] was constructed using impregnation of Ni2+ into GO wrapped melamine and subsequent calcination at 900 °C. NiSA-NGA exhibited a structure of GO sheets wrapped on the melamine foam skeleton with uniformly distributed Ni atoms. The NiSA-NGA with ≈2.6 wt% Ni loading showed a high FECO of 90.2%, and durability over 6 h electrolysis with constant current density around 5 mA cm−2 and stable FECO above 80% at –0.8 V vs. RHE. In addition, NiSA-NGA facilitated CO2 reduction at a very low potential (–0.4 V vs. RHE). DFT indicated that the coordinatively unsaturated Ni-N x (x = 1, 2, 3) sites exhibited lower free energies for *COOH formation than Ni-N4, thus promoting CO2 electroreduction. He et al. [133] designed a Ni SAC on N-doped winged 3D-graphene carbon nanofiber (NiSA-NWC) and used as electrocatalyst for CO2RR. NiSA-NWC reached maximum FECO above 95% over 2 h CO2 electrolysis at –1.6 V vs. Ag/AgCl, 30% higher than that of the standard Ni nanoparticles on the same support (NiNP-NWC). Besides, NiSA-NWC showed a Tafel slope of 134 mV dec−1 by CO partial current, lower than that by NiNP-NWC (199 mV dec−1), indicating NiSA-NWC favored CO2 reduction with faster rate. These excellent performances originated from the dominated singular Ni1+ electronic states and restricted H atom adsorption sites. A flexible self-supported hierarchical Ni SAC (H-CPs) with 1D carbon nanotube perpendicular to 2D N-C layer was developed using a solid-state diffusion strategy [93], which was used as electrocatalyst for CO2 reduction. H-CPs (acid etched freshly prepared carbon papers (F-CPs)) exhibited a high j CO of 60.11 mA cm−2 at –1.2 V vs. RHE in H-cell, seven times higher than that of F-CPs prepared without acid washing. Besides, H-CPs achieved high FECO above 90.8% over a wide potential range from –0.7 to –1.2 V vs. RHE, suggesting strong prohibition of HER by the Ni atomic sites. In addition, remarkable durability over 40 h was achieved at –1 V vs. RHE. When applied in flow cell, j CO was increased to 91.1 mA cm−2 at 3.0 V cell voltage. DFT indicated that NiN4, NiN2, and NiN facilitated COOH* formation, while NiN3 slightly preferred HCOO* pathway for CO production. Moreover, chemical adsorption of H* was stable on NiN4 rather than NiN x (x = 1, 2, 3) because of its high positive adsorption energy (1.52 eV). In conclusion, all four NiN x moieties favored CO2-to-CO conversion over HER. Gong et al. [134] constructed Ni SAC using a general host-guest cooperative protection strategy via introducing polypyrrole into bimetallic MgNi-MOF-74. Various N coordination number in the NiSA-N x -C SAC was controlled by calcination temperature. Especially, NiSA-N2-C exhibited a high FECO of 98%, good stability over 10 h and TOF of 1622 h−1 at –0.8 V vs. RHE, surpassing that of NiSA-N3-C and NiSA-N4-C. DFT demonstrated that the low N coordination number (2) to Ni site favored COOH* generation, thereby promoting superior activity to CO production. The following two studies were devoted to application of bimetallic Zn-Ni MOFs for SACs preparation. Ma et al. [135] designed a Ni-N-doped porous interconnected carbon (NiNPIC) catalyst by calcinating the Zn-Ni bi-metal MOFs. Because of the cross-linked hierarchical porous structure, NiNPIC exhibited large surface area with abundant Ni-N sites and facilitated fast mass/electron transfer. Thus, high FECO (95.1%), large current density (10.2 mA cm−2), long-term stability (over 24 h electrolysis at –0.65 V vs. RHE), and a CO formation rate of 542 μmol m−2 s−1 at –0.54 V vs. RHE were achieved. Similarly, Yan et al. [65] fabricated a porous carbon with coordinated Ni-N active sites and high Ni loading of 5.44 wt% by pyrolyzing bimetallic Zn-Ni MOFs. As for CO2RR, this Ni SAC delivered a FECO of 92.0%–98.0% over a wide potential range from –0.53 to –1.03 V vs. RHE, a durability over 720 min at –0.63 V vs. RHE, a high TOF of 10087 ± 216 h−1, and a maximum current density of 71.5 ± 2.9 mA cm−2 at –1.03 V vs. RHE. DFT demonstrated that the unsaturated Ni-N sites (NiN2V2, NiN3, NiN3V) favored CO2 reduction over HER. In the following study, Yang et al. [94] directly converted Ni nanoparticles into Ni single atoms on porous N-doped carbon (NC) surface using an in situ thermal atomization method, obtaining the SE-Ni SAs@PNC catalyst, which achieved high FECO (> 90%) and low FEH2 (< 10%) at potentials from –0.6 to –1 V vs. RHE, higher than NC and Ni NPs@NC (FECO < 1 %) (Fig. 7(a) ). Besides, SE-Ni SAs@PNC exhibited maximum TOF of 48 842 h−1 (Fig. 7(b)) and j CO of 16.42 mA cm−2 at –1.1 V vs. RHE as well as durable stability over 60 h electrolysis at –1 V vs. RHE without obvious decay in activity and structure change. Additionally, SE-Ni SAs@PNC showed superior FECO of 88% and TOF of 47805 h−1, outperforming another Ni SAC with Ni atoms dispersing over entire NC matrix (70%, 5273 h−1). These excellent performances originated from the single Ni atoms facilitating intermediate CO2 − formation and the NC porous support providing fast mass transfer and diffusion. In another example, Guo et al. [136] developed a Ni-N co-doped ordered mesoporous carbon (Ni-NOMC) using a SBA-15 template pyrolysis of N-rich pitch and Ni2+. The fabricated Ni-NOMC achieved high FECO above 90% with greatly suppressed HER over a wide potential range from –0.75 to –1.20 V vs. RHE, and good stability over 10 h electrolysis. This outstanding activity was attributed to the Ni-N active sites, and the ordered mesoporous structure which synergetically improved CO2 activation, facilitated fast mass transfer and provided abundant active sites. Ni atoms were uniformly dispersed into a 3D porous carbon using a silica spheres template pyrolysis of 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium dicyanamide and Ni2+ [137]. The prepared Ni-SA-NC achieved over 99% selectivity to CO at –0.8 V vs. RHE with a high current density above 50 mA cm−2 at –1.0 V vs. RHE in H-cell. Remarkably, when applied in a membrane electrode assembly cell, much higher j CO of 380 mA cm−2 at 3 V (2.77 V when iR compensated), and long-time stability over 9 h with constant current density (> 140 mA cm−2 at 2.6 V) and stabile FECO (99%) were obtained. DFT revealed that Ni-N4 active sites favored COOH* generation, thereby facilitating highly selective CO production. A similar high j CO of 308.4 mA cm−2 and FECO of 88% at –1.0 V vs. RHE over 120 h electrolysis were achieved in flow cell using a Ni atom decorated hierarchically porous carbon membrane catalyst [138]. This membrane, prepared by electrospinning and following pyrolysis, exhibited a structure with interconnected nanofibers and hierarchical pores, which provided abundant Ni-N4 active sites for CO2 reduction. A slightly lower j CO of 200 mA cm−2 and a stable FECO around 85% over 20 h electrolysis were obtained by a porous Ni-N-C SAC in flow cell at an industrial current density up to 700 mA cm−2 [139]. This Ni-N-C SAC was constructed by calcinating polyaniline, Ketjen600EC, and Ni2+. DFT revealed that the coordinated Ni-N x motifs were active sites for CO2 reduction. Besides, the Ni-N-C can be tested at acidic, neutral, and alkaline electrolytes, respectively. 3.1.2 Fe Different from Ni-N-C SACs, Fe-N-C SACs usually displayed high catalytic selectivity and activity at relatively lower potentials. Chen et al. [27] designed a Fe and N co-doped porous carbon nanosphere (Fe-N-PC, ∼50 nm) with Fe single atoms and few Fe clusters, using SiO2 as the template and protecting shell. The Fe-N-PC with 3.9 wt% Fe loading achieved a high FECO of ∼90% and j CO of 11.44 mA cm−2 at –0.49 V vs. RHE. In contrast, at the same potential, the Fe-N-PC with poisoned Fe-N x by SCN− showed a decrease in current density and FECO (69.2%) but an increase in FEH2 over the potential range from –0.35 to –0.68 V vs. RHE. Interestingly, the electrode after rinsing delivered an activity as it originally was, because of the recovery of the Fe-N4 sites. Synergetic effect between Fe atom and ortho-C of N atoms contributed to the improvement in reaction activity. Besides, DFT calculations revealed that amorphous Fe clusters facilitated CO desorption with low free energy on the Fe-N4-C active sites, thus leading to high activity for CO2 reduction. In another study, Zhong et al. [140] investigated a Fe and N doping porous carbon nematosphere (FeNPCN) for CO2-to-CO conversion. FeNPCN was prepared using a combined method of dopamine polymerization triggered by Fe species and subsequent carbonization, which delivered a 3D hierarchical nematosphere morphology, favorable to mass transport. Besides, FeNPCN achieved a high FECO of 94% and long-term stability over 12 h at –0.5 V vs. RHE. Controllable H2/CO ratios (0:1, 1:1, 2:1, 3:1) were realized by using various potentials, which would be further applied for HCOOH production, Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, CH3OH production, and CH4 synthesis, respectively. DFT indicated that the high activity of FeNPCN originated from C and N hybrid coordination with Fe atoms. In the following study, Cheng et al. [21] developed a novel Fe-N-C SAC nanofiber featuring Fe x N nanoparticles encapsulated within Fe and N co-doped carbon layers (Fe x N@Fe-N-C) for CO2RR by electrospinning, carbonization, acid-leaching, and nitridation under NH3. Fe x N@Fe-N-C delivered a 100% selectivity, a high FECO of 95%, a current density of 4.71 mA cm−2 at –0.53 V vs. RHE, and a long-time durability over 24 h electrolysis. DFT indicated that the Fe x N core helped the active center (Fe-N4-C) to grow as Fe-N5-C, which facilitated CO intermediate desorption, triggering the catalytic performance.
