A bifunctional Fe SAC with single Fe atoms on bamboo carbon nanotube (FeN x /C) [141] was reported as efficient electrocatalyst for both ORR and CO2RR. FeN x /C delivered excellent ORR activity at onset potential of 1.03 V vs. RHE and remarkable durability over 20000 cyclic voltammetry cycles without onset potential decay. Additionally, FeN x /C exhibited increased FECO from 85% to 90% and declined FEH2 from 1.4% to 0.3% at –0.6 V vs. RHE after introducing 5 × 10−3 mol/L SCN− to poison FeN x and hence, clarifying the active sites for CO2 reduction. FeN x showed better activity than C–N in Fe3C for CO2-to-CO conversion while an opposite trend was observed in ORR. Pan et al. [62] anchored Fe atoms on carbon nanotube and graphene nanoribbon (GNR) networks to get the Fe-N/CNT@GNR SAC. Because of the hierarchically mesoporous structure providing high electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) and fast mass transport, and Fe-N4 active centers at the CNT and GNR basal plane and edges favoring CO2 activation and stabilizing *COOH formation, Fe-N/CNT@GNR achieved stable FECO of 96% with a current density of 22.6 mA cm−2 at –0.76 V vs. RHE, superior to that of the Fe-N/CNT. Similar porous structure effect, providing abundant Fe-N4 sites, high specific surface area and large ECSA, was also observed by using a Fe SAC characteristic of coordinated Fe-N4 active sites within carbon nanorods for CO2RR, which was developed by calcinating sea urchin-like FeOOH-polyaniline composite [142]. The Fe SAC exhibited superior performances with a FECO of 95% and a current density of 1.9 mA cm−2 at –0.64 V vs. RHE. 2D carbon materials such as graphene oxide was employed as supports for anchoring Fe SACs. Zhang et al. [73] developed a Fe SAC with FeN5 sites embedded in the N-doped graphene for CO2-to-CO conversion, which exhibited a high FECO of 97% at –0.46 V vs. RHE, much higher than that of hemin (79%), FeN4 (67%), and melamin-graphene (31%) (Fig. 7(c)). Besides, FeN5 catalyst delivered much larger j CO than the other three materials. It also possessed a durable stability over 24 h CO2 electrolysis with only 2% current density decay and a constant FECO at –0.46 V vs. RHE. These excellent catalytic performances were attributed to atomically dispersed FeN5 active sites and the graphene support which provided enlarged specific surface area and enhanced conductivity. DFT demonstrated that FeN5 sites not only exhibited much lower free energy change of the key step (0.77 eV for CO2 → *COOH) than FeN4 sites (1.35 eV for *CO → CO+*), but also connected with *CO via a relatively weak binding strength (0.54 eV) than FeN4 sites (1.35 eV), thus facilitating rapid CO desorption from FeN5 and realizing high CO selectivity. Another Fe SAC with FeN4 sites was prepared by pyrolyzing the Fe-, N-, and C-containing precursors [143], which displayed a current density of 7.5 mA cm−2 and a FECO of 91% at –0.6 V vs. RHE. Besides, the Fe SAC exhibited a long-term stability over 6 h electrolysis with unchangeable current density (6 mA cm−2) and CO production rate (25 nmol s−1). In this study, the FeN4 active sites were responsible for triggering excellent CO2RR performance. Similarly, FeN4 sites on N-doped graphene (Fe/NG) developed by absorbing Fe3+ on graphene oxide and a subsequent calcination in Ar/NH3 [144]. During the pyrolysis, Fe atoms were immobilized by N doping via Ni–N interactions, generating the Fe/NG SAC. The Fe-N4 sites facilitated COOH* formation as well as CO2 adsorption and activation. Because of the synergetic effect between Fe-N4 moieties and N-doping, Fe/NG SAC delivered highly efficient activity for CO production. For instance, Fe/NG SAC calcinated at 750 °C (Fe/NG-750) exhibited maximum FECO of ~80% and stability over 10 h at –0.6 V vs. RHE, while Fe/NG-700 displayed slightly lower selectivity, indicating more active sites formation at 750 °C. Both lower (650 °C) and higher (800 °C) calcination temperatures resulted in negligible activity to CO2RR. Followed by this study, Zhu et al. [145] directly annealed hemin-doped polyaniline to distribute isolated Fe atoms on N-doped carbons nanosheet to get the Fe-SA/NCS-X SAC for CO2RR. The catalyst calcinated at 700 °C exhibited a high FECO of 87% at –0.45 V vs. RHE, and durable stability over 10 h, originating from the synergistic effect between the graphitic N species and the Fe-N4 active sites which reduced the energy barrier for *COOH formation, thus boosting CO2-to-CO conversion. Another Fe-SA-900 SAC was developed by introducing Fe into a N-C framework via a facile thermal pyrolysis at 900 °C [146]. The Fe atoms promoted water dissociation, thus providing protons for CO2 reduction, while the pyrrolic-N-C sites in the anchoring N-doped carbon nanosheets synergistically promoted CO2 reduction by facilitating CO2 adsorption and electron transfer. Therefore, the Fe-SA-900 SAC obtained a high FECO of 90% at –0.58 V vs. RHE, surpassing that of Fe-NP-900 featured by Fe NPs. Recently, Li et al. [147] constructed isolated FeN4 sites with a confined pyrolysis strategy using Fe-doped graphitic carbon nitride template fabricated by a simple adsorption method. The obtained FeN4/C SAC displayed a sheet-like structure, providing abundant active sites for CO2-to-CO conversion. While the FeN4 sites lowered the energy barrier for COOH* formation, therefore, leading to good stability over 24 h and maximum FECO of 93% at –0.6 V vs. RHE, much higher than that of the bare N-doped carbon (N/C, 46%) and Fe-doped g-C3N4 (Fe/C, 23%). Besides, the FeN4/C exhibited 35 and 17 times higher current density than that of N/C and Fe/C, respectively. The following two studies were devoted to distributing Fe atoms on 3D supports for CO2RR. Ye et al. [84] employed a Fe SAC with Fe-N active sites anchored on ZIF-8 surface to catalyze CO2RR. The C-AFC©ZIF-8 SAC, fabricated by pyrolyzing the ZIF-8 with ammonium ferric citrate (AFC) confined on the surface, delivered a maximum FECO of 93% at –0.43 V vs. RHE and a higher j CO than that of the pyrolyzed AFC functionalized ZIF-8 (AFC©ZIF-8), the calcinated ZIF-8 (C-ZIF-8), and pyrolyzed physical mixture of AFC and ZIF-8 (C-AFC/ZIF-8, Fig. 7(d)), for the reason of more exposure of Fe-N active sites. Zhang et al. [70] constricted Fe atoms within a multiscale carbon foam using a SiO2 template to get the Fe SAC for CO2RR. In this catalyst, the macro-pores enabled mass transport, the graphene nanosheets facilitated electron transfer, and the Fe atoms that confined in carbon matrix coordinated with four N atoms which worked as active sites for CO2-to-CO conversion. All these factors aforementioned worked together leading to a high FECO of 94.9% at –0.5 V vs. RHE and remarkable durability over 60 h CO2 electrolysis. 3.1.3 Co Compared with Ni-N-C and Fe-N-C SACs, Co-N-C usually displayed relatively lower selectivity and activity. Well-controllable morphology and structure is promising to enhance CO2 reduction performances. Pan et al. [58] investigated a Co-N5/HNPCSs SAC by coordinating Co and N based on N-doped carbon spheres. The obtained Co SAC with Co-N5 active sites delivered high selectivity for CO2RR with FECO of 99.2% and 99.4% at –0.73 and –0.79 V vs. RHE, respectively, which was 15.5-fold higher than that of CoPc. Besides, Co-N5/HNPCSs exhibited a current density of 6.2 mA cm−2 at –0.73 V vs. RHE, much higher than that of CoPc (0.4 mA cm−2). The remarkable stability was confirmed by the stable j CO and FECO after 10 h electrolysis at –0.73 V vs. RHE. As demonstrated in the DFT of Co-N5/HNPCSs, ΔG (free energy change from CO2 to adsorbed COOH*) of the first proton-coupled electron-transfer step was improved by 0.31 eV, and CO desorption free energy was increased by 0.16 eV in respect to those of CoPc, thus leading to higher catalytic activity than CoPc. This study demonstrated that Co-N5 was the catalytic site to activate CO2, generate COOH* and desorb CO simultaneously. A bifunctional Co SAC with high metal content of 3.4 wt% on N-doped porous hollow carbon spheres derived from ZIF-67 (Co-HNC) was reported as an effective catalyst for CO2RR [71]. The Co-HNC showed high CO + H2 formation rate of 425 mmol g−1 h−1 (–1.0 V vs. RHE), nearly 100% total FE (> –0.7 V vs. RHE), stable FECO of 35% (> –0.8 V vs. RHE), and durable stability over 24 h electrolysis with negligible decay in current density. For comparison, solid nitrogen-doped carbon embedded with Co nanoparticle (Co NP-SNC) prepared by pyrolyzing ZIF-67 exhibited inferior performances with a half CO + H2 formation rate of that for Co-HNC. The superior performances of Co-HNC were attributed to Co-C2N2 moieties and N functional groups (pryidinic and graphitic N) which were active for CO production and HER, respectively. Besides, the hollow porous structure enabled fast mass and electron transfer as well as exposure of abundant active sites, thereby promoting CO2RR significantly. Recently, a Co single atom decorated N-doped graphitic carbon shell-encapsulated cobalt nanoparticle (Co@CoNC) [148] was investigated as electrocatalyst for CO2-to-CO conversion. Co@CoNC exhibited dual active sites with Co-coordinated modified carbon shell and Co-N4 sites for CO2RR and HER, respectively. Different CO/H2 ratios (2:1, 1:1, 2:3) over a wide potential range from –0.5 to –0.8 V vs. RHE was controlled by the annealing temperatures (Fig. 7(e)). For instance, pyrolysis at 800, 900 and 1000 °C resulted in FECO of 36%, 45%, and 61% at –0.7 V vs. RHE (Fig. 7(f)), correspondingly, the FEH2 decreased from 59% to 43% and 40%. Besides, the 900 °C calcination temperature also contributed to good stability over 12 h at –0.5 V vs. RHE. In another study, controllable CO/H2 ratios of 0.23–2.26 with high total current density above 74 mA cm−2 at –1.0 V vs. RHE, FECO of 45%–55% and promising stability over 7 h were realized by CoNi-NC SAC with different Co/Ni ratios [149]. For comparison, Ni-NC and Co-NC SACs exhibited favorable activity to CO production (> 56 mA cm−2 at –1.0 V vs. RHE) and HER (> 58 mA cm−2 at –1.0 V vs. RHE), respectively. DFT indicated that Ni-N4C and Co-N4C sites selectively promoted CO2 reduction and HER. These two works demonstrated rational design of SACs for high CO production with tunable CO/H2 ratios. A 3D net-like porous nanofiber with Co single atoms (CoSA/HCNFs) [96] was developed using a combined method of electrospinning, subsequent annealing and final acid washing. The CoSA/HCNFs achieved a high FECO of 91% with current density of 67 mA cm−2, and stability over 50 h electrolysis at –0.9 V vs. RHE in H-type cell, as well as higher FECO of 92% with current density of 211 mA cm−2 in flow cell. The 3D hierarchically porous structures provided fast electron/mass transport, while Co-N4 active sites on carbon surface facilitated *COOH formation by lowering Gibbs free energy, thus leading to high selectivity and activity. In the following study, Wang et al. [87] designed a series of Co-N x (x = 2, 3, 4) SACs confined in ZIF and discovered that the Co-N2 achieved the highest current density of 18.1 mA cm−2 at –0.63 V vs. RHE, about 2.0, 7.3, and 23.3 times higher than that of Co nanoparticles, Co-N3, and Co-N4, respectively. In addition, Co-N2 SAC exhibited maximum FECO up to 95% at –0.68 V vs. RHE, much higher than that of Co nanoparticles (< 7% at tested potential range), Co-N3 (63% at –0.53 V vs. RHE), and Co-N4 (4.2% at –0.83 V vs. RHE). Moreover, Co-N2 showed recorded TOF values of 18200, 23200, 25500, and 33000 h−1 at –0.63, –0.68, –0.73, and –0.78 V vs. RHE, respectively, which were significantly higher than that of Co-N4 (84 h−1 at –0.83 V vs. RHE). Co-N2 also delivered durable long-time stability over 60 h electrolysis at –0.63 V vs. RHE without detectable decay in current density and FECO. The low-coordination number of 2 facilitated intermediate CO2 −* formation by providing faster electron transfer and lower required energy to generate CO2 −* on Co-N2 than Co-N4. And Co-N2 exhibited stronger CO2 −* adsorption, leading to higher CO2RR activity than Co-N3, Co-N4, and Co nanoparticles. This work indicated the significance of regulating the coordination number on Co-N active sites for improving the CO2RR performances. 3.1.4 Cu Generally, Cu SACs were mainly used for producing multi-carbons or hydrocarbons besides few studies for CO generation. For example, the Cu-N2/GN [150] with isolated Cu atoms on graphene matrix was selective to CO with maximum FECO of 81% and excellent stability over 10 h at low potential of –0.50 V vs. RHE, attributed to improving *COOH formation via the unsaturated Cu-N2 active sites which promoted CO2 adsorption and facilitated fast electron transfer from Cu-N2 sites to *CO2 by their short bond lengths. Recently, a higher FECO of 98% and outstanding stability over 40 h were attained by a Cu SAC with highly exposed isolated Cu-N4 sites embedded in microporous carbon frameworks derived from MOF [151]. This Cu SAC developed using a one-step thermal activation strategy exhibited a rhombododecahedral shape morphology. Theoretical calculations indicated that the active sites of edge-hosted Cu-N4edge were with d-band center much closer to the Fermi level. Hence, *COOH formation was facilitated with a lower energy barrier than the bulk-hosted Cu-N4bulk sites. Besides, the edge-hosted Cu-N4 moieties with optimized local coordination environment and electronic properties exhibited strong interaction with *COOH and facilitated *CO desorption, thereby enhancing CO generation. Different from these two studies on CO production, many Cu SACs were designed for generating multi-carbons or hydrocarbons. A Cu SAC with atomic Cu distributing on through-hole carbon nanofibers (CuSAs/TCNFs) [110] was investigated as electrocatalyst for CO2-to-CH3OH conversion, which generated pure liquid CH3OH with high selectivity of 44% and gas CO with a production of 56% at –0.9 V vs. RHE (Fig. 7(g)). For comparison, another catalyst CuSAs/CNFs with 1/3 ZIF-8 amount used in CuSAs/TCNFs preparation exhibited similar CH3OH and CO distribution with a maximum FECH3OH of 41% at –0.9 V vs. RHE, while TCNFs only produced CO and H2. Moreover, CuSAs/TCNFs showed a methanol formation rate of 68.4 μmol m−2 s−1, higher than that of CuSAs/CNFs (17.7 μmol m−2 s−1). CuSAs/TCNFs was also stable over 50 h electrolysis at –0.9 V vs. RHE with constant C1 partial current density of ∼90 mA cm−2 and without obvious decay in FEC1. Attributed to the interconnected network and through-hole structure, CuSAs/TCNFs exposed abundant Cu active sites favoring CO2 diffusions. The Cu-N4 moieties facilitated COOH* intermediate formation, which was converted to *CO easily. Further reduction of *CO generated CH3OH rather than CO because of higher binding energy of *CO to Cu atoms. In the subsequent study, Cu-N x sites were distributed on carbon nanosheet as an effective electrocatalyst for CH4 and C2H4 production [29]. Altering the pyrolysis temperature at 800–1100 °C resulted in different Cu-N x sites. Catalyst annealed at 900 °C was denoted as Cu-N-C-900, which produced CH4 as the main product with a maximum FECH4 of 38.6%, a current density of 14.8 mA cm−2 and excellent stability of 10 h at –1.6 V vs. RHE, while Cu-N-C-800 displayed a FEC2H4 of 24.8% and a current density of 6.84 mA cm−2 at –1.4 V vs. RHE, higher than that of CH4 generation (13.9%, 3.83 mA cm−2). The distance between neighboring Cu-N x species was small enough for C2H4 production at high Cu concentration (4.9% mol) and large enough for CH4 generation at low Cu concentrations (< 2.4% mol), respectively. DFT indicated that the two neighboring Cu-N2 sites favored C2H4 formation, while the isolated Cu-N4, adjacent Cu-N4, and isolated Cu-N2 sites tended to form CH4. Similarly, Cu-N4 sites were atomically distributed on carbon black for CO2-to-CH4 conversion [74], which was developed by calcinating Cu salt, 3-amino-5-hydroxypyrazole, and carbon black. The Cu SAC pyrolyzed at 400 °C containing 5 wt% Cu loading produced CH4 with high selectivity of 42% and a j CH4 of ~100 mA cm−2 at –1 V vs. RHE. Besides, high FEmethane/ethylene ratio of 4:1 was reached. As the Cu-N4 sites disfavored C–C coupling, thus C2H4 formation was greatly suppressed. Jiao et al. [152] discovered that Cu confined in g-C3N4 (Cu-C3N4) could produce C2H5OH, C2H6 and C2H4 with higher selectivity than CH4 and CH3OH, attributed to its unique dual active centers. For comparison, Cu-N/C sample exhibited quite low selectivity to CH4 and HCOOH. Besides, Cu-C3N4 was stable over 18 h at –1.6 V vs. Ag/AgCl. The g-C3N4 molecular scaffold not only worked as additional active center to synergistically cooperated with Cu during different stages of CO2 reaction, but also uplifted Cu's d-orbital position toward the Fermi level, thus resulting in stronger intermediates adsorption and smaller energy loss toward CO2 hydrogenation. Recently, the 2D g-C3N4 material was employed to support Cu atoms for formate production [153]. Because of the Cu atom confinement in the structural cavities of g-C3N4 and strong Cu-N interaction, Cu atoms were stabilized by g-C3N4, favoring the CO2 conversion into formate. Great progresses have been achieved by Cu-N-C SACs for efficient CO2RR, although it is still in debate whether the Cu-N-C sites are stable under CO2RR conditions. While many Cu-N-C SACs [29,74,110,150,151] presented stable Cu-N sites during CO2 reduction process, several Cu single atom based catalysts [154–156] presented were reported to undergo transformation from atomic Cu into copper clusters which work as active species for CO2RR under reaction conditions. Intriguingly, this conversion is reversible by removing the reduction potential [154]. In situ UV-vis [156] confirmed the conversion of Cu single site into metallic Cu clusters at –0.94 V vs. RHE, and the formation of Cu(I) at –0.64 V vs. RHE. Further investigations by in situ XAS and DFT indicated that the unique CuN2O2 active sites had intrinsic CO2RR activity other than the in situ generated Cu clusters. Therefore, high FECH4 (78%), j CH4 (40 mA cm−2) and stability over 6 h were achieved. Similarly, reversible reconstruction of metal sites was observed in the Cu-N-C SAC [30] with coordinated Cu-N active sites in N-doped carbon matrix derived from ZIF-8. The Cu SAC with 0.5 wt% Cu loading produced ethanol with a high FEethanol of 55 % and a stable current density of 12 mA cm−2 at –1.2 V vs. RHE in 0.1 mol/L CsHCO3. Besides, total FE of ethanol and ethylene reached up to 80%. Importantly, it is noticed that the isolated Cu-N4 active sites were reversibly converted into Cu nanoparticles during CO2 electrolysis, which recovered to the initial atomic Cu sites after electrolysis. Some other SACs also have been confirmed undergoing significant structural evolutions under reaction conditions. For example, Fe3+ reduction into Fe2+ and Fe2+ reduction into Fe1+ were detected for Fe3+-N-C SAC [157] and Fe-PANI SAC [158] at –0.5 V and –0.9 to –1 V vs. RHE, respectively. Besides, similar Ni–N bond expansion in NiN4 sites [72] and Sb–N bond expansion in Sb-N-C SAC [159] were probed, while the In–N bond in In δ+-N4 atomic interface [160] shortened at –0.65 V. More detailed structural evolution of SACs would be discussed in Section 4.2.7 about Operando XAS for in situ monitoring the structure changes of active sites during CO2RR. 3.1.5 Others Besides the above discussed M-N-C SACs (M = Ni, Fe, Co, Cu), some studies have been devoted to other M-N-C catalysts for efficient CO2RR, such as Bi SAs/NC [161], Zn-N4 [24], Sn-N [25], Sb-NC [162], Y1/NC [163], Sc1/NC [163], Ni/Fe-N-C [76], Cu/Fe-NC [164], NiFe-diatomic site catalyst [165], CoNi-N-C [149], Mo@NG [166], In δ+-N4 atomic interface [160] and InA/NC [167]. Zhang et al. [161] designed a Bi SAs/NC with Bi-N4 sites on porous carbon networks derived from MOF by pyrolyzing the mixture of Bi-MOF precursor and dicyandiamide at 1000 °C in Ar. The Bi SAs/NC showed a maximum FECO of 97% and a current density of 3.9 mA cm−2 at –0.5 V vs. RHE, as well as long-time stability within 4 h electrolysis. Besides, TOF of Bi SAs/NC reached up to 5535 and 10118 h−1 at –0.39 and –0.58 V vs. RHE, respectively. DFT indicated that Bi-N4 sites were responsible for activating CO2 and facilitating intermediate COOH* formation by lowering energy barrier, thus boosting CO selectivity. Because of the M-N active sites, other materials such as Zn-N4 [24], Sb-NC [162], Y1/NC [163] and Sc1/NC [163] were active for CO2-to-CO conversion with high selectivity of 95%, 82%, 88.3% and 81.3%, respectively. Higher FECO of 98% at –0.7 V vs. RHE was achieved using a novel isolated diatomic Ni/Fe-N-C reported by our group [76]. The Ni/Fe-N-C SAC exhibited robust durability over 30 h electrolysis with only 1% decay in FECO. The dual Ni-Fe centers decreased energy barrier for COOH* generation and CO desorption, enabling high selectivity and activity for CO2RR. Very recently, a bifunctional diatomic Ni-Fe sites on N-doped graphene, fabricated by pyrolyzing amino acid, Fe2+, Ni2+ and melamine, delivered excellent catalytic performances for both CO2RR and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [165]. For the CO2-to-CO conversion, high production of 94.5% and current density of 50.4 mA cm−2 at 690 mV overpotential were achieved, while a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of 310 mV was obtained for O2 evolution, much better than that of the Ni-SAC and Fe-SAC. Besides, outstanding stability over 30 h were achieved for both CO2RR and OER by the Ni-Fe sites. When applied in the rechargeable metal-CO2 batteries, the Ni-Fe sites significantly outperformed Cu-N2/GN with maximum power density of 1.36 mW cm−2 at 8.5 mA cm−2, and outstanding rechargeability with 180 galvanostatic discharge (5 mA cm−2)-charge (2 mA cm−2) cycles. The superior activity came from the orbital coupling of the Fe active center and Ni atoms, which changed the orbital energy level, resulted in unique electronic states and higher iron oxidation state, and lowered the binding energy to the intermediates, thereby boosting CO2RR and OER. Similar to the above two studies of Ni-Fe double sites for CO2RR, Zhang et al. [168] also applied a Ni/Fe-N-C catalyst with Ni and Fe active sites for achieving a maximum FECO of 98% at a low potential of 390 mV vs. RHE, outperforming the Ni-N-C and Fe-N-C SACs. Besides, promising durability over 30 h with stable current density of –5.6 mA cm−2 and >90% remaining the initial FECO was achieved at –0.5 V vs. RHE. This quasi-double-star catalyst with optimized structure of Ni7/Fe3-N-C was developed by pyrolyzing the Ni and Fe co-doped Zn-based MOFs. DFT indicated that the neighboring Ni and Fe active sites synergically facilitated COOH* formation and CO* desorption with lower reaction barrier than Ni-N-C and Fe-N-C SAC, and prohibited HER significantly. These studies confirmed the importance of double metal active sites in boosting CO2RR performances. Very recently, Ding et al. [169] developed a dinuclear Ni2 site on N-doped carbon using a Ni2(dppm)2Cl3 dinuclear-cluster-derived strategy. The obtained Ni2 site consisted of two Ni1-N4 moieties shared with two nitrogen atoms. Operando synchrotron X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) revealed an oxygen-bridge adsorption on the Ni2-N6 site to form an O-Ni2-N6 structure with enhanced Ni-Ni interaction during CO2RR. DFT demonstrated that the O-Ni2-N6 structure outperformed Ni-N4, Ni2-N6, and N-G models with significantly lower energy barrier for CO2 activation. Therefore, the dinuclear Ni2 site achieved a high FECO > 94% at 150 mA cm−2 in flow cell, ∼1.3 fold higher than that of Ni1/NC developed using Ni(dppp)2 (dppp = 1,3-bis(diphenylphosphino)propane), and ∼10.6 fold higher than that of the reference NC catalyst. In addition, maximum j CO of 141 mA cm−2 at –1.25 V vs. RHE, and high stability over 50 h CO2 electrolysis –0.6 V vs. RHE were attained. This work confirmed the development of dinuclear sites to efficient CO2 reduction. Sn SAC with high selectivity to HCOOH and CO before and after acid etching was investigated [25], which was developed using an electrospinning-pyrolysis method. The Sn SAC calcinated at 1000 °C (Sn-CF1000), featured by uniformly distributed Sn atoms on N-doped porous carbon nanofiber, displayed a maximum FEHCOOH of 65% in 0.1 mol/L KHCO3 at –0.8 V vs. RHE. Besides, a high FEHCOOH of 62% with current density of 11.0 mA cm−2 was achieved in 0.5 mol/L KHCO3, superior to state-of-the-art Sn-based catalysts [170]. In addition, long-time stability with 24 h electrolysis at –0.8 V vs. RHE was obtained with slow increase of current density from 16.6 to 19.3 mA cm−2, stable FEH2 (16%) and FECO (26%) in the first 20 h, and negligible change in FEHCOOH. Interestingly, the acid etched Sn-CF SAC sample (AD-Sn/N-C1000) achieved maximum FECO of 91% with a current density of 1.75 mA cm−2 at –0.6 V vs. RHE, much higher than that of N-C1000 prepared by annealing pure N-doped carbon fibers (64%, 0.2 mA cm−2). Moreover, AD-Sn/N-C1000 was stable over 24 h electrolysis at –0.6 V vs. RHE with constant current density (1.55 mA cm−2) but slight decrease in FECO (91% to 84%). These outstanding properties originated from the active Sn sites on N-doped carbon facilitated HCOOH and CO formation via HCOO* and COOH* intermediates. And the porous structure, enabling fast mass transport, was another factor. Another Sn SAC with homogeneous Sn atoms on N-doped graphene [111] showed a low onset overpotential (0.06 V) for HCOOH, a large TOF up to 11930 h−1 at –1.8 V vs. saturated calomel electrode (SCE), a high FEHCOOH of 74.3% at –1.6 V vs. SCE, and a durable ultrastability over 200 h electrolysis. The Sn δ+ sites stabilized CO2 •−* and HCOO−*, facilitating CO2 activation and protonation to further reduction to HCOOH. Besides, N-doping favored the rate-limiting formate desorption step by lowering the Sn-HCOO−* bonding strength and HCOO−* desorption energy. In the following study, scarce Mo single atom was distributed on ultrathin N doped graphene derived from g-C3N4 to get the Mo@NG SAC [166], which achieved a HCOOH yield of 747 mmol gcatal −1 h−1 at –1.4 V vs. RHE, superior to that of N doped graphene (230 mmol gcatal −1 h−1). Besides, Mo@NG displayed a higher current density (105 mA cm−2 at –0.6 V vs. RHE) and FEHCOOH (~28% at –1.4 V vs. RHE) than N doped graphene. These remarkable performances were owed to Mo single atoms as they provided fast charge-transfer and active N sites (pyrrolic atoms and pyridinic N), therefore, promoting CO2 adsorption and reduction. Recently, Jiang et al. [159] discovered that Sb-N4 moieties anchored on N-doped carbon delivered a high FECOO- of 94% and good stability over 10 h electrolysis without obvious decay in current density but slight decrease in FECOO- to 85% at –0.8 V vs. RHE, which originated from the positively charged Sb δ+-N4 (0< δ < 3) active sites. This study also demonstrated the rational design of other main group single M-N4 sites (Sb, In, Sn, Bi, etc.) for CO2RR. Replacing traditional metal-N4 moieties with different coordination configuration is effective in tailoring the SACs performance for CO2RR. Ni et al. [171] constructed an Sn SAC with a special Sn-C2O2F coordinated structure, which achieved a maximum FECO of 95.2% and a cathodic energy efficiency of 70.7% at –0.75 V vs. RHE, as well as decent stability over 100000 s without decay in current density and FECO at –0.85 V vs. RHE in H-cell. When applied in an alkaline flow cell, high FECO over 90% and maximum current density of 186 mA cm−2 were obtained. In contrast, the reference Sn SAC with ordinary Sn-N4 site facilitated formate formation predominantly, delivering a maximum FEHCOO- of 45.7% at –0.95 V. DFT calculations revealed that the C and O coordination in the atypical Sn-C2O2F structure optimized the adsorption of *COOH intermediates and exceptionally high-energy barrier for *H formation and O-bound CO2 adsorption, while the Sn-bonded F atom significantly prohibited the HER, thereby promoting CO2-to-CO conversion. 3.1.6 Noble metal-N-C Noble metal-N-C SACs based on Au, Ag and Pd are highly effective to CO2-to-CO conversion, because of their strong binding with *COOH but weak binding with *CO. Many noble metal SACs are investigated theoretically [19,172–175], only limited works are devoted to experimental studies. For instance, Li et al. [92] investigated a dual-atom Ag2/graphene catalyst (Ag2-G) with well-defined AgN3-AgN3 active sites for CO2RR. The Ag2-G catalyst delivered a total current density of 44.3 mA cm−2 at –1.0 V vs. RHE and an onset potential of –0.25 V, much higher than that of Ag nanoparticles-GO (Ag NPs-G), pure graphene oxide (G), and the Ag1-G SAC prepared using a mononuclear Ag complex. Both Ag1-G and Ag2-G favored CO2 reduction while Ag2-G was observed more effective. The Ag2-G showed a high FECO of 93.4% (Fig. 7(h)), a current density of 11.87 mA cm−2, a TOF per Ag site of 30 s−1, and excellent stability over 36 h electrolysis at –0.7 V vs. RHE, while Ag1-G exhibited a moderate FECO of 79 % and a TOF per Ag site of 5.1 s−1 at –0.7 V vs. RHE. In contrast, Ag NPs-G and G showed inferior catalytic performance. DFT demonstrated that the AgN3-AgN3 active sites in Ag2-G were more effective than the AgN4 active sites in Ag1-G because of the stronger *CO2 adsorption and lower energy barrier for *COOH formation. Besides, AgN3-AgN3 active sites could stabilize *CO2 by concomitantly interacting C and an O atom in CO2 with two Ag atoms, promoting *COOH formation and leading to higher CO production. Very recently, Sui et al. [176] engineered the Ag1-N3 sites on porous concave N-doped carbon (Ag1-N3/PCNC) for CO2-to-CO conversion, which achieved low onset potential of –0.24 V vs. RHE, maximum FECO of 95% and decent durability over 40 h continuous CO2 electrolysis at –0.37 V vs. RHE, superior to most reported Ag catalysts [177–179]. The Ag1-N3 sites had sole linear-adsorbed CO and thus facilitated *CO species desorption for high CO selectivity. In the following study, He et al. [91] studied a Pd SAC with Pd-N4 sites distribution on carbon support for CO2RR. The Pd-NC was selective to CO at the test potential range (–0.2 to –0.8 V vs. RHE) with a maximum FECO of 55% at –0.5 V vs. RHE, 2.5 times higher than that of the commercial carbon-supported Pd with 10 wt% Pd loading (Pd/C) (22% at –0.5 V vs. RHE). In contrast, Pd/C showed lower FECO of 2%–33% at the potential ranging from –0.3 to –0.8 V vs. RHE and the metal-free NC sample prepared without adding Pd salt delivered low FECO of 8%-30%. Moreover, Pd-NC exhibited j CO of 0.244 and 2.20 mA cm−2 at –0.4 and –0.8 V vs. RHE, respectively, which were 3.8-9.0 and 3.9 times higher than that of Pd/C. The reference NC sample made almost no contribution to current density. Additionally, Pd-NC displayed a mass activity of 373.0 mA mg−1 Pd at –0.8 V vs. RHE, higher than that of Pd/C (28.5 mA mg−1 Pd). Both Pd-NC and Pd/C were stable over 3 h long-time electrolysis at –0.6 V vs. RHE with almost constant FECO and current density, and Pd-NC outperformed Pd/C with higher current density and FECO (Fig. 7(i)). DFT indicated that the Pd-N4 sites were active for CO production without palladium hydride formation occurring in CO2RR by Pd nanoparticles. Pd-N4 sites stabilized *HOCO intermediate, producing CO even at low potentials with FECO of 4.9% and 8.3% at –0.2 and –0.25 V vs. RHE, respectively. 3.2 SACs on other supports Apart from the carbon-based M-N-C SACs, single atoms on other supports (metal, alloy, metal oxide, metal hydroxide) also exhibited superior electrochemical performances for CO2 reduction (Table 3). Our group [219] anchored Sn atoms on Cu support using a simple sequential reduction process of Cu2+ and Sn2+, and we discovered that the isolated Cu-Sn atomic interfaces achieved a high FECO of 98% and a j CO of 100 mA cm−2 in an alkaline flow cell at overpotentials of 30 and 340 mV (Fig. 8(a) ), respectively. Besides, robust stability over 20 h continuous CO2 electrolysis with remaining 97% of initial j CO and unchanged FECO at −0.75 V vs. RHE in H-cell was obtained. DFT revealed the crucial role of the bonding geometry of isolated Cu-Sn surface alloy in absorbing the key intermediates (COOH* and CO*) to promote CO2RR. Similarly, other single atom alloys such as Cu-Al [216] and Cu-Ag [217] also contributed to superior CO2RR performances, giving high FEC2H4 (80%) and FEC2H5OH (41%), respectively, because of the regulated metal-metal interfaces and electronic configuration over the active sites. Recently, Au atoms were dispersed on tensile-strained Pd NPs by a MOF-confined reduction approach for effective CO2-to-HCOOH conversion [214]. The obtained M-AuPd achieved a remarkable FEHCOOH over 99% and excellent stability, as well as a 26- and 31-fold enhanced partial current density and mass activity to that of the commercial Pd/C (Fig. 8(b)). Normally, Pd catalyst is vulnerable to CO poisoning because of its intrinsic high affinity to CO, leading to fast deactivation during CO2RR. On the contrary, for the M-AuPd catalyst with well-controlled incorporated Au, the tensile strain facilitated intermediates stabilization on Pd surface, while the isolated Au atoms preferentially destabilized CO* without influencing other adsorbates, thereby breaking the conventional COOH* versus CO* scaling relationship and promoting CO2 reduction. The Cu-atom-pair catalyst (Cu-APC) [192] with Cu single atoms anchored on Pd10Te3 alloy nanowire containing 0.1 wt% Cu loading displayed not only a long-term stability over 180 minutes, but also a high FECO of 92% at −0.78 V vs. RHE, 6.57 times higher than that of the undoped nanowires (14%), this improvement in CO2 reduction can be reasoned by the stable Cu1 0-Cu1 x+ pair structures with adjacent Cu1 0 and Cu1 x+ adsorbing CO2 and H2O, respectively, hence promoting CO2 reduction and suppressing HER effectively. Similar Cu0-Cu+ sites [209], derived from the well-dispersed cupric oxide supported on copper phyllosilicate lamella, contributed to a high FEC2H4 of 51.8% at −1.1 V vs. RHE over 6 h continuous CO2 electrolysis (Figs. 8(c), (d)). The Cu0 promoted CO2 activation and facilitated the following electron transfer, while Cu+ exhibited strong *CO adsorption to further boost C–C coupling (Fig. 8(e)), giving the outstanding performances. Wang et al. [39] reported a Cu SAC on mesoporous CeO2 nanorods for CO2RR. They discovered that every Cu site enriched by three oxygen vacancies worked as the active centers to promote CO2 reduction into CH4. The catalyst with 4% Cu species delivered a maximum FECH4 of 58% at −1.8 V vs. RHE (Fig. 8(f)) and an excellent stability with retaining > 40% initial FECH4 after 8000 s electrolysis (Fig. 8(g)), because of the synergetic effect of Cu active sites, the multiple oxygen vacancies and the CeO2 framework. Very recently, Han et al. [211] constructed atomically Sn sites on defective CuO catalysts for CO2-to-CH3OH conversion. A high FECH3OH of 88.6%, a current density of 67.0 mA cm−2 and remarkable stability over 36 h in a H-cell were achieved. These superior performances came from the cooperation of the Sn atoms sites, adjacent oxygen vacancy and CuO support, which leaded to higher double-layer capacitance, enlarged CO2 adsorption capacity and lowered interfacial charge transfer resistance. This catalyst facilitated CO2 activation by promoting *COOH dissociation with lower energy barrier to generate the key intermediate *CO, which could be further reduced to methanol on the Cu species with high selectivity. Sun et al. [102] reported a Ir SAC with uniform Ir atoms distributing on α-Co(OH)2 support for CO2-to-CO conversion. The Ir SAC with 1.7 wt% Ir loading (IrAC-1.7) achieved a maximum FECO of 97.6% with a current density of 18.6 mA cm−2 at −0.66 V vs. RHE, while Ir nanoparticles (Ir NPs, 2 nm) or α-Co(OH)2 made negligible contribution to CO2 reduction activity (Fig. 8(h)). Moreover, IrAC-1.7 exhibited a high TOF of 38290 h−1 at an overpotential of 0.55 V and a durable long-time stability over 24 h electrolysis at −0.66 V vs. RHE without decay in FECO and current density because of the strong interaction between Ir and Co sites. Additionally, IrAC-1.7 not only delivered the smallest Tafel slope, but also the largest ECSA which was 2.0, 2.9, 5.3, and 23.4 times higher than that of IrAC-1.1, IrAC-0.6, IrAC-0.3, and Ir NPs, respectively (Fig. 8(i)). Therefore, IrAC-1.7 showed faster CO2 reduction rate and higher FECO. These superior electrochemical performances originated from the Ir active sites for strong CO2 adsorption and activation, stabilization of intermediate CO2 •–, and their synergistic effect with the Co(OH)2 support. 3.3 Molecular catalysts Molecular catalysts are promising for CO2RR attributed to their advantages of well-defined active sites, well-characterized reaction pathways, and chemically modifiable structures with precisely tunable steric and electronic properties. Different molecular catalysts such as COFs or MOFs catalysts, and organometallic catalysts [42,43] are usually used for practical applications for the following two reasons: (1) The elimination of the catalyst diffusion to the electrode promotes the mass transport. (2) There is no need to separate the catalysts from the products afterward, thus, it reduces separation costs and increases catalyst lifetime. In this part, we summarized different molecular catalysts and discussed their applications for CO2RR (Table 4 ). 3.3.1 MOF/COF catalysts MOFs and COFs were attractive catalysts for CO2RR because of their high surface area, tunable porosity, diversity in metal and functional groups, confinement effects and periodic metal arrangements [9]. Some MOFs and COFs promoted uniform metal active sites, which facilitated effective CO2RR. There were some MOF catalysts with superior CO2-to-CO conversion performances. Wang et al. [220] employed ZIF-8SO4 prepared using ZnSO4 to catalyze CO2RR. The catalyst exhibited a maximum FECO of 65% in 0.5 mol/L NaCl at −1.8 V vs. SCE (Fig. 9(a) ), which slightly dropped to 60% after 1 h electrolysis (Fig. 9(b)). The total current density of CO2RR remained steady over the 4 h electrolysis. Discrete Zn nodes were the active centers for CO production. Besides, NaCl outperformed other electrolytes such as NaHCO3 and NaClO4, because of the small hydrated radius and facile anion exchange of Cl−. Another cobalt-porphyrin MOF, Al2(OH)2TCPP-Co (TCPP-H2 = 4,4′,4″,4‴-(porphyrin- 5,10,15,20-tetrayl)tetrabenzoate) [221] was developed for CO2RR by assembling the catalytic linker units cobalt-metalated TCPP into a porous MOF thin film, which delivered high selectivity towards CO with a FECO of 76% over 7 h electrolysis at −0.7 V vs. RHE, and a turnover number (TON) of 1400. In situ spectra electrochemical measurements revealed the catalytically active centers Co(I) came from Co(II) reduction during CO2RR. In the following study, iron tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin (FeTCO2PP) incorporated into MOF-525 (Fe_MOF-525) was used for CO2 electroreduction [222], which exhibited an electroactive Fe sites surface concentration of 6.2 × 10−8 mol cm−2, ∼3 orders of magnitude higher than that of the FeTCO2PP monolayer on the same flat fluorine-doped tin oxide electrode. Besides, Fe_MOF-525 achieved a total FE approximately 100% with 54 ± 2% and 45 ± 1% for CO and H2, respectively. After adding the weak Brönsted acid (1 mol/L 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol) into the nonhydroxylic electrolyte, Fe_MOF-525 showed an increased current density and stability. Moreover, higher CO production was achieved with TONCO of 1520 after 3.2 h electrolysis at −1.3 V vs. NHE. FECO reached 41±8% with a total FE ∼100%. These outstanding catalytic performances were attributed to the MOF porous structure enabling feasible solvent, reactant, and electrolyte accessibility to the Fe catalytic sites, as well as the metalloporphyrinic linkers working as electrocatalysts and redox-hopping-based conduits to deliver reducing equivalents to active sites that did not directly contact the underlying electrode. Cu-MOFs are promising for multi carbons or hydrocarbons production. Cu-MOF (HKUST-1) was investigated for CO2-to-C2H4 conversion [223], exhibiting a recorded FEethylene of 45% with the current density of 262 mA cm−2 at −1.07 V vs. RHE. Undercoordinated Cu sites in HKUST-1 was promoted by distortion of the symmetric paddle-wheel Cu dimer to the asymmetric motif by separating the benzene tricarboxylate moieties via calcination at 250 °C. The low Cu-Cu coordination number of 9.5 ± 0.9 in the Cu-MOF improved the selectivity to C2H4. In another study, Wu et al. [224] reported a copper(II) porphyrinic MOF nanosheets (Cu2(CuTCPP)) for CO2RR, which exhibited a high total FE of 85.2% at −1.55 V vs. SCE with 68.4% and 16.8% for HCOOH and acetate, respectively. Besides, maximum current densities of 3.5 and 1.0 mA cm−2 at −1.6 V vs. SCE, as well as high TOF of 2037 and 148 h−1 at −1.55 V vs. SCE were achieved for HCOOH and acetate, respectively. These superior electrochemical performances originated from the synergistic effect between the porphyrin-Cu(II) complex which enhanced the activity and the cathodized reconstruction of Cu2(CuTCPP) nanosheets where Cu(II) carboxylate nodes changed to CuO, Cu2O and Cu4O3 via intermediates Cu(HCOO)2 and Cu(OH)2 during CO2RR and hence, leading to superior electrochemical CO2 reduction performance. Recently, Qiu et al. [225] developed a PcCu-Cu-O MOF with 2,3,9,10,16,17,23,24- octahydroxyphthalo-cyaninato)copper(II) (PcCu-(OH)8) ligands and the square-planar CuO4 nodes for CO2-to-C2H4 conversion. PcCu-Cu-O outperformed CuPc with a much higher FEC2H4 (50% vs. 25%), a j C2H4 of 7.3 mA cm−2 and durability over 4 h at −1.2 V vs. RHE in 0.1 mol/L KHCO3. This improvement in performance was attributed to the synergistic effect between the CuPc unit and the CuO4 unit, as the CO-producing site (CuO4 site) promoted CO migration and dimerization with *CO intermediate adsorbed on the C2H4-producing site (CuPc), resulting in a lower C−C dimerization energy barrier. Similar to MOFs, covalent organic frameworks (COFs) with structural linkages connected covalently also exhibited outstanding catalytic performances for CO2RR. A model framework COF-367-Co using cobalt porphyrin as building blocks for a COF was reported [226], which showed a high FECO of 90% with current density of 5 mA gcatalyst −1 and TON values up to 290000 (9400 h−1 at pH 7 at −0.67 V vs. RHE). X-ray absorption data indicated that the COF-367-Co can influence the catalytic cobalt centers electronically and sterically. This was similar to the behavior of redox noninnocent ligand in molecular systems [227], which was supposed to give high selectivity and activity. Porphyrin active sites could be electronically modified using COF to deliver high selectivity and activity for CO2RR. COF-366-Co was functionalized to produce a series of derivates with different electron withdrawing groups, including COF-366(OMe)2-Co, COF-366-F-Co and COF-366-(F)4-Co [228]. Compared with the j CO of 45 mA mg−1 at −0.67 V vs. RHE for COF-366-Co, COF-366(OMe)2-Co and COF-366-F-Co exhibited higher current densities of 46 and 65 mA mg−1, respectively. However, COF-366-(F)4-Co displayed the lowest current density since its high hydrophobicity resulted in the poor accessibility of electrolyte to active sites (Fig. 9(c)). Another catalyst COF-300-AR containing amine linkage was investigated for CO2RR [229]. In comparison to the bare Ag electrode, COF-300-AR decorated Ag electrode exhibited significant FECO increase from 13% to 53% and from 43% to 80% at −0.7 and −0.85 V vs. RHE, respectively. In this catalyst, COFs provided porous structure which enabled molecular diffusion to the electrode surface and the amine groups facilitated carbamate intermediates formation, therefore, promoting CO2 reduction to CO. In the following study, a rhenium tricarbonyl complex bearing 2,2′-bipyridine (2,2′-bpy) ligands [230] was reported for CO2RR. The Re(5,5′-diamine-2,2′-bpy)(CO)3Cl complex containing Re(2,2′-bpy)(CO)3 fragments in COF delivered excellent electrochemical performances with a FECO of 99% and a TON of 100800 at −2.57 V vs. Fc0/+. Besides, COF-2,2′-bpy-Re was obtained by integrating Re-2,2′-bpy fragments into a COF containing 2,2′-bpy moieties using a post-metallation method, which was then composited with carbon black and polyvinylidene fluoride on glassy carbon electrodes. The composite with 29.38 wt% Re was highly selective to CO with a FECO of 81% at −2.8 V vs. Fc0/+ but with only 30 mins stability during the electrolysis, because of the inhibited mass transport and substrate diffusion. Very recently, Han et al. [231] reported two 2D polyimide-linked phthalocyanine COFs (CoPc-PI-COF-1, CoPc-PI-COF-2) for efficient CO2 reduction with high FECO of 87%−97% from −0.6 to −0.9 V vs. RHE. While CoPc-PI-COF-1 outperformed CoPc-PI-COF-2 with higher j CO of 21.2 mA cm−2 at −0.90 V vs. RHE, attributed to its higher conductivity. Additionally, CoPc-PI-COF-1 achieved extraordinary TON (277000) and long-term stability (40 h) at −0.70 V vs. RHE. This work indicated the potential of porous COF for CO2RR applications. 3.3.2 Organometallic catalysts Organometallic complexes exhibited high selectivity and catalytic activity for CO2RR. Their electronic structure and catalytic activity can be well controlled by the metal center, ligands, and support. Many organometallic complexes have been fabricated successfully, such as iron 5, 10, 15, 20-tetrakis (2′, 6′-dihyfroxylphenyl)-porphyrin (FeTDHPP) [232], CATpyr-CNT [233], Co-TPP-CNT [234], CoFPC (perfluorinated cobalt phthalocyanine) [235], Cu-Pc [154] and other complexes summarized in Table 4 were effective catalysts for CO2RR. Earlier studies about metal phthalocyanines (MPcs) for CO2RR indicated that the most active catalyst was CoPc, and then NiPc [233,236,237]. Other metal centers such as Fe, and Cu were somewhat active, but Mn, Cr, and Sn displayed little or almost no activity. Furuya et al. [238,239] investigated the impact of metal centers in MPcs for CO2RR using gas-diffusion electrodes (GDEs) in 0.5 mol/L KHCO3. They discovered that Co, Pd, Cd and Ni primarily produced CO, Fe and Zn also generated CO as main product. Sn and Sb preferred HCOOH formation, Al, Zn and In exhibited some selectivity towards HCOOH. Ti and Cu contributed to CH4. But these MPcs were challenged by strong competitive HER, except for NiPc and CoPc which delivered high FECO of 100% and 98%, respectively. Besides the selectivity, catalytic activity is also significant. FePc and CoPc outperformed NiPc with better activity toward CO, because of their lower potentials (−1.4 to −1.2 V vs. SHE) than that of NiPc (−0.45 V vs. SHE). Therefore, CoPc is one of the most promising catalysts for CO2RR. Similarly, Mahmood et al. [240] also applied MPcs (M = Co, Mn, Cu, Zn) on GDEs in sulfate buffer (pH = 2). They discovered that CoPc exhibited the highest selectivity towards CO with a FECO of 100% and current density of 22 mA cm−2 at −1.5 V vs. SHE. Other MPcs produced small amounts of HCOOH. CO2 was electrochemically reduced to CO at the Co2+ active center via a cobalt(I) phthalocyanine intermediate. Different from this mechanism, HCOOH formation was not because of the metal phthalocyanines but the underlying GDEs prepared at 300 °C in N2 and 105 kPa. Liu et al. [180] fabricated a model Ni SAC with Ni-N4 active sites on conductive carbon support using a two-step method. Ni-N active centers (nickel(II) 2,9,16,23-tetra(amino)phthalocyanine (Ni-TAPc)) was constructed firstly and then linked to CNT. The obtained Ni SAC achieved a high FECO of 99%, a TOF of 100179 h−1, a j CO of 32.3 mA cm−2 and ultrastability over 100 h electrolysis at −0.65 V vs. RHE. Ni+ was confirmed as the active site for CO2-to-CO conversion. According to molecular orbital theory, the highest occupied molecular orbital in Ni 3dx 2–y2 outperformed Ni 3dz2 with better overlapping C 2p* orbital in CO2, thus *COOH formation being the rate-determining step for CO2 reduction. Based on the above earlier jobs, Zhu et al. [241] fabricated CoPc stabilized by carbon paper, which revealed high TOF of CO approaching ∼100 s−1 with low loadings < 2 × 10−11 mol cm−2 at −0.73 V vs. RHE in 0.1 mol/L NaHCO3 (Fig. 9(d)). This would increase to 400 s−1 at the same potential in 1 mol/L NaHCO3. The observed high TOF came from more accessible CoPc active sites by improved catalyst dispersion at lower loadings, which was related to the oxygen-functionalized support and a solvent with high CoPc solubility. Moreover, a maximum FECO of 96% was obtained with the highest loading at −0.73 V vs. RHE which dropped to ∼80% at low loadings (Fig. 9(e)), probably because of the exposure of the underlying carbon paper which was selective to H2. For the CO2RR mechanism by CoPc, after the first irreversible reduction of Co2+ to Co+, the rate-limiting step was well-tuned from electron transfer to concerted proton-electron transfer by changing the bicarbonate concentrations from low (< 0.3 mol/L) to high (> 0.3 mol/L), leading to faster CO2RR. In another study, CoPc was grown on CNTs to obtain the core-sheath organic-inorganic hybrid material for CO2RR [242], which showed a high FECO (∼90%), high current density (∼50 mA cm−2 at −0.6 V vs. RHE), and excellent durability (> 24 h). These excellent performances came from the CoPc catalytically active sites and CNT support which offered good electrical conductivity. Effects of metal centers for CO2RR were also investigated using porphyrins. Noriyuki Sonoyama [243] investigated the CO2RR performance of metal-centered tetraphenyl porphyrins (MTPPs) in 0.5 mol/L KHCO3. They found that FeTPP and CoTPP were the most promising catalysts for CO2RR, delivering high FECO of 80.9% and 97.3% at 20 atm, respectively. CuTPP and ZnTPP showed lower selectivity to CO at 1 atm, the FECO reached up to 50.5% and 65.8% at 20 atm, respectively. NiTPP only exhibited 12% FECO at 20 atm, much lower than that of NiPc. While MnTPP, MgTPP and H2TPP showed almost no activity. Moreover, CuTPP displayed 22% FEHCOOH at 20 atm. Recently, Tuo et al. [244] anchored Fe TPP on aminated carbon nanotube to get the Fe-N/CNT SAC. The axial Fe-N/CNT achieved excellent stability over 10 h and maximum FECO of 95.47% at −0.6 V vs. RHE, slightly higher than that of planar Fe-N/CNT (91.89%). DFT indicated that the axial coordinated Fe-N active sites favored *CO desorption and suppressed HER, thus increasing the CO selectivity. In another study, Lu et al. [245] constricted a Ni porphyrin based covalent triazine frameworks (NiPor-CTF) using a conventional ionothermal method in molten ZnCl2. The prepared NiPor-CTF was highly active for CO2-to-CO conversion, which exhibited a high FECO of > 90% over wide potential range (−0.6 to −0.9 V vs. RHE), a maximum FECO of 97% with a high current density of 52.9 mA cm−2 at −0.9 V vs. RHE, and durability over 20 h electrolysis. NiN4 centers were confirmed as the active sites for CO2 reduction both experimentally and theoretically. To study the effect of metal centers for CO2-to-HCOOH conversion, Birdja et al. [246] catalyzed CO2RR using metalloprotoporphyrins (MPPs). They declared that In, Sn and Rh were the most active for generating HCOOH, with InPP achieving high FEHCOOH of 70% at −1.9 V vs. RHE in phosphate buffer (pH = 9.6). Ni, Cd, Pd and Cu displayed little HCOOH production, while Cr, Mn, Co, and Fe were inactive to HCOOH formation. Besides the HCOOH production by MPPs, cobalt protoporphyrin [247] was immobilized on pyrolytic graphite electrode to obtain CoPP-PG for CO2-to-CO/CH4 conversion, which exhibited higher FECH4 than FECO with H2 as the main product in 0.1 mol/L perchlorate (pH = 1) at 1 atm CO2. In addition, a maximum FECO of approximately 40% was achieved at −0.8 V vs. RHE, 1 atm CO2 and pH = 3. Lower FECH4 at pH = 3 originated from the slower reduction of CO to CH4 at pH = 3 than that at pH = 1. Given higher CO2 pressure of 10 atm, FECO reached up to 60% at −0.6 V vs. RHE and pH = 3. The pH-dependent electrochemical performance was elucidated by a mechanism in which CO2 was catalyzed by CoPc via stabilization of the intermediate CO2 •−, which worked as Brønsted-base and abstracted a proton from H2O. Further CO-to-CH4 conversion was slow because of the weak CO-catalyst binding and preference of CO reduction at more acidic conditions. An intriguing phenomenon of metal-center exchange was observed during CO2RR using the MO x /iron phthalocyanine (FePc) catalyst with metal oxide (FeO x , CoO x , and NiO x ) incorporated into FePc supported on graphene [248]. Near edge X-ray absorption fine structure (NEXAFS) spectroscopy confirmed the replacement of Fe center by Ni and Co. NiO x /FePc gave a maximum FECO of 86.2 ± 3.2% at −0.40 V vs. RHE and a FECO about 60% with largest current density of 11.6 ± 1.2 mA cm−2 at −0.7 V vs. RHE. While CoO x /FePc showed lower FECO of 80.0%−84.5% at −0.4 to −0.7 V vs. RHE with maximum current density of 24.0 ± 1.1 mA cm−2 at −0.7 V, much higher than that of FePc (FECO: 26.2 ± 5.1%, current density: 3.1 ± 0.6 mA cm−2 at −0.7 V vs. RHE). Besides, NiO x /FePc and CoO x /FePc achieved better stability and activity than FeO x /FePc and FePc, with CoO x /FePc delivering the highest polarization performance. This work indicated that the co-existence of electrochemically substituted metal Pc (e-MPc, M = Co, Ni) and the replaced FeO x nanoparticles near e-MPc could promote high selectivity and excellent activity for CO2RR. Another important phenomenon of restructuring-induced catalytic activity for CO2RR was observed by the CuPc supported on CNT [154]. CuPc achieved a high FECH4 of 66% and current density of 13 mA cm−2 at −1.06 V vs. RHE, while HKUST-1 and [Cu(cyclam)]Cl2 gave much lower FECH4 of 27% and 15%, respectively. In-situ and operando XAS indicated that copper(II) phthalocyanine experienced structural and reversible oxidation state changes Cu2+-Cu+-Cu-Cu+-Cu2+ induced by the applied potential, forming ~2 nm metallic copper clusters, which activated CO2 reduction to CH4. For comparison, HKUST-1 and [Cu(cyclam)]Cl2 exhibited irreversible transformation to Cu dendrites. Similar to this study, Cu nano clusters probably formed in a crystalline CuPc catalyst [155] which delivered a FEC2H4 of 25% at −1.60 V vs. Ag/AgCl. The crystallinity of CuPc was effective in selectively producing C2H4, as the C−C coupling to generate C2H4 was mediated by two metal centers. Different ligands such as porphyrins [243], bipyridines [249], cyclams [154], protoporphyrin [246] and phthalocyanine [240] have been investigated for developing heterogeneous molecular catalysts for CO2RR. CuPc was used to catalyze CO2RR [250], which exhibited current densities of 13.2, 8.4 mA cm−2 and TOF of 4.3, 1.8 molecules site−1 s−1 for CH4 and C2H4 at −0.976 V vs. RHE, respectively. This unprecedentedly catalytic performance originated from the built-in hydroxyl groups in the porphyrin ligand and the active Cu(I) center. Janina et al. [249] reported an aminophenethyl-substituted [Re(2,2′-bipyridine)(CO)3Cl] catalyst ([Re(NH2-bpy)]) grafted on nanoporous colloid-imprinted carbon (CIC) electrode. The obtained CIC|[Re(NH2-bpy)] electrode was active for CO production with high FECO of 92 ± 6%, TONCO of 6, and a Re-based TON about 900 at −2.2 V vs. Fc+/Fc in acetonitrile (ACN), but unstable under CO2 with declining complex-related redox properties over time by CVs collected in wet ACN. Moreover, the glass carbon|[Re(NH2-bpy)] electrode exhibited decreasing Re complex related signals by XPS. Therefore, the instability originated from weak electronic connection of the carbon support and the Re complex, such as broken C-N bonds or bonds in the proximity thereof, resulting in electrode deactivation as the Re complex leached into solution. Different from this weakly immobilized material, o-phenylenediamine [251], [RuII(dmbpy)2(phenda)]2+ [251], [RhIIICp*(phenda)Cl]+ [251] and Re(phen)(CO)3Cl [48] were immobilized electronically onto graphitic electrodes, obtaining graphite-conjugated catalysts (GCC-phenazine, GCC-Ru, GCC-Rh, GCC-Re). Electron transfer was detected at the GCCs when the interfacial reaction was ion-coupled because of the conductive pyrazine linkages, which significantly reduced the potential drop between the electrode and the GCC metal active sites. Electrons transferred at the metal sites via inner-sphere pathways crossing the electrical double layer. Therefore, electron transfer occurred when there was strong binding between the metal sites and the graphitic support, and no outer-sphere electron transfer was detected. Besides, the potential drop between the GCC active site and solution existed and caused ions transfer between them. Applied potential was altered to modulate the driving force for ions transfer (Fig. 9(f)). Given a sufficiently negative applied potential, protons driven by electric field crossed the double layer and bonded N sites on phenazine in protic electrolyte. This substrate activation was also applied for GCC-Rh in halide electrolyte [251] and GCC-Re in alkaline aqueous [48]. Zhang et al. [46] developed cobalt-2,3,7,8,12,13,17,18-oc- tacyano-phthalocyanine based complexes anchored on CNTs (CoPc-CN/CNT) to activate CO2RR. The catalyst performed a high FECO of 98% with a current density of 15.0 mA cm−2 at −0.63 V vs. RHE and a TOF of 4.1 s−1 at an overpotential of 0.52 V in 0.1 mol/L KHCO3. Besides, CoPc-CN/CNT exhibited better selectivity, activity and stability than CoPc, because of the uniform distribution of CoPc molecules on highly conductive CNT and introduction of electron-withdrawing cyano groups which facilitated the formation of Co+ active sites from Co2+ reduction. Another catalyst perfluorinated cobalt phthalocyanine (CoFPc) [235] showed not only higher FECO (93% at −0.8 V vs. RHE) and current density than CoPc, but also superior stability over 12 h electrolysis. Electron-deprived CoFPc by the inductive effect of fluorine substituents was less prone to CO poisoning and more selective to CO2RR than CoPc. Substituent effect was investigated more comprehensively using cobalt porphyrin and its derivates [252] containing different aromatic substituents, such as neutral porphyrins (Cobalt tetraphenylporphyrin (CoTPP), cobalt tetramethoxyphenylporphyrin (CoTMPP), cobalt tetrabromophenylporphyrin (CoTBPP), cobalt tetrachlorophenylporphyrin (CoTCPP)) and cationic porphyrins (cobalt tetra-(N-methyl-2- pyridyl)porphyrin (CoTMpyp2), cobalt tetra-(N-methyl-3- pyridyl)porphyrin (CoTMpyp3), cobalt tetra-(N-methyl-4- pyridyl)porphyrin (CoTMpyp4), and cobalt tetra-(4-N,N,N- trimethylanilinium)porphyrin (CoTMAP)). Among them, CoTPP with catalyst loading of 1 × 10−8 mol cm−2 delivered a high FECO above 80% at −0.6 V vs. RHE. Lower catalyst loading (< 2 × 10−9 mol cm−2) gave a stable TOFCO (∼1.5 s−1) at −0.6 V vs. RHE, corresponding to a TON of 4500 during the 50 min CO2RR. This indicated the effectiveness of low catalyst loading in mitigating aggregation. These superior performances originated from the through-bond inductive effect of substituents on increasing electron density of the catalytic Co active center, thereby facilitating CO2RR. This also applied for other neutral porphyrins (CoTMPP, CoTBPP and CoTCPP), while cationic peripheral substituents (CoTMpyp2, CoTMpyp3, CoTMpyp4, and CoTMAP) not only maintained the inductive effect of substituent but also additionally promoted CO2-to-CO conversion by electrostatically stabilizing the intermediate of the rate-determining electron transfer to CO2. Moreover, DFT indicated that log(TOFCO) of these CoPc derivates linearly related to the Hammett constants and TOFCO increased with stronger electron-donating property of the substituents, corresponding well to the experimental results. Recently, Wu et al. [253] reported a heterogenous catalyst zinc(II) 5,10,15,20-tetramesitylporphyrin (ZnTMsP) for CO2RR, which achieved a high FECO of 95% at −1.7 V vs. SHE in 0.1 mol/L TBAP6/DMF/H2O, much higher than that of ZnTPP (FECO 28%) in an aqueous electrolyte. In situ and operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy confirmed that the Zn(II) center was redox-inactive but essential to bind the reaction intermediates. The porphyrin ring as the redox mediator was reduced and further reacted with CO2, thereby resulting in high FECO. This work demonstrated the effect of the macrocyclic porphyrin ring on catalytic performance for CO2 reduction. Other ligands such as phthalocyanine, pyrazole (Pz), 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole (DAT) and tris[(2-pyridyl)methyl] amine (TPA) were employed to modify Ag catalyst [254]. The modified catalysts exhibited higher j CO (~95 mA cm−2 at −1.8 V vs. Ag/AgCl) than that of Ag while AgTPA/C and Ag/C delivered similar poor kinetics for CO production. Besides, compared to AgTPA/C and Ag/C, other three catalysts (AgDAT/C, AgPz/C, AgPc/C) showed much higher FECO, with AgDAT/C delivering the highest FECO above 90% at potential < −1.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl. The three N-based organometallic complexes could effectively improve the activity and selectivity for CO2RR for the following two reasons: (1) Morphology (shape and/or size) of the Ag particles were changed by DAT, Pz and Pc. (2) The N-containing ligands coordinated with Ag, enabling electron transfer. In another study, alkoxy substitutions to CoPc significantly mitigated phthalocyanine aggregation on the graphene sheets [255]. Thus, the catalyst showed higher current density (197 A mg−1 at −0.89 V vs. RHE), FECO (77% at −0.59 V vs. RHE) and effective TOFCO (∼5 s−1 at −0.59 V vs. RHE) than the unmodified CoPc. Besides, excellent stability over 30 h electrolysis with effective TOFCO about 6 s−1 and TONCO of 6.7 × 10500 were achieved. Followed by these two studies, Ma et al. [256] constructed pyrrolidinonyl nickel phthalocyanine (PyNiPc) molecular catalyst immobilized on CNT for CO2RR using a built-in pyrrolidone group-assisted assembly strategy. This catalyst achieved almost 100% FECO over wide potential range from −0.68 to −0.93 V vs. RHE with controllable CO/H2 ratios up to 640. Moreover, long-time stability over 10 h electrolysis at −0.67 V vs. RHE and prominent TOF of 1.3 × 104 h−1 at −0.93 V were obtained. Introduction of pyrrolidone groups promoted dispersion and catalysis. Besides, the intrinsic Ni-N4 active sites in PyNiPc molecular and interfacial PyNiPc-CNTs synergistic effect contributed to superior CO2RR performances. Apart from the effects of metal centers and ligands, different heterogenous supports have been investigated to study their effects in CO2 electrolysis, such as metals (Au [257,258], Cu [259]), carbon supports (graphite [48], CNT or carbon black [234], carbon nanotube [35], carbon fibers [260], graphene oxide [36], metal-organic frameworks-derived nanocarbons [37], and carbon nitride [38]), G-quadruplex nanowires [261], zinc-indium sulfide [262], and polymers (poly(4-vinylpyridine) [263], poly(4-vinylpyridine)-polystyrene [264], poly(2-vinyl pyridine) [265], poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly-sty- renesulfonate [266] and didodecyldimethylammonium bromide [266]). Different carbon supports were studied [266] for CO2-to-COOH conversion catalyzed by InPP immobilized on basal-plane pyrolytic graphite (PG), glassy carbon (GC), and boron-doped diamond (BDD), respectively. PG substrate gave the highest FEHCOOH and j HCOOH, while GC showed the least selectivity. Compared with GC and BDD, PG substrate delivered higher normalized total current density, higher normalized j HCOOH, larger ECSA, more porous structure facilitating mass transport, larger amount of the effective porphyrin and stronger suppression of HER. Similar trends have been seen in RhPP and SnPP for HCOOH production. Besides, the PG substrate was pretreated using electrochemical reduction, H2 and O2 plasma, respectively. The O2 plasma treatment resulted in higher FEHCOOH and j HCOOH, because of the introduced oxygen functionalities (hydroxyl, carbonyl, carboxylate) giving a surface with more polarity and hydrophilicity, as well as stronger adsorbate-substrate interaction. The anodized PG achieved lower initial FEHCOOH but significantly improved stability, attributed to carbon surface destruction and thick graphite oxide formation with large surface area. Both H2 and cathodic pretreated PG exhibited dramatically reduced activity, selectivity, and stability for HCOOH, because the generation of C−H bonds and decrease in O/C ratio by the interaction between H2 and surface oxides favored HER over CO2-to-HCOOH conversion. This study indicated improvement of CO2RR by modifying substrate and its chemical functionality, as well as the catalyst chemical environment. Several studies were devoted to absorbing molecular catalysts using CNT as supports, including CoTPP [234], CoPP [267], CoPc [46], and CoCh [268]. They all achieved higher FECO and j CO than that without CNT supports, attributed to high surface area and electrical conductivity of CNT. Zhang et al. [46] immobilized CoPC on CNT to get a hybrid CoPc/CNT electrocatalyst for CO2-to-CO conversion. The CoPc/CNT exhibited high FECO of > 92% over wide potential range from −0.59 to −0.63 V vs. RHE and long-term stability over 10 h at −0.63 V vs. RHE, while CoPc on carbon fiber paper (CFP) only showed a lower FECO of ~68% and faster decay (Fig. 9(g)). Besides, CoPc/CNT delivered much higher CO generation rate than that of CoPc on CFP, indicating its higher activity and selectivity towards CO. Compared with CoPc supported on GO and carbon black, CoPc/CNT also exhibited higher FECO and j CO, because of better π−π interactions and greater electrical conductivity afforded by CNT. Similarly, strong π−π interactions between CNTs and cobalt chlorin (CoCh) complex [268] contributed to higher CO production than that of CoCh anchored on GO. In the following study, strong π−π interactions between CNTs and iron porphyrin via pyrene groups [233] resulted in almost constant current density over 3 h CO2 electrolysis, and a FECO of 97% with CO/H2 ratio up to 96:4 at −1.03 V vs. NHE, higher than that of the catalyst without pyrene groups. Another iron porphyrin/reduced graphene oxide frameworks (FePGFs) was fabricated by interconnecting 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-trime- thylammoniumphenyl)porphyrinato iron(III) pentachloride via π−π stacking and electrostatic interactions [269], which delivered a high FECO of 97.0% and durability over 24 h electrolysis at −0.59 V vs. RHE. When deposited on CFP, the obtained FePGF/CPF achieved a higher FECO of 98.7% with current density of 1.68 mA cm−2 over 10 h electrolysis at −0.59 V vs. RHE (Fig. 9(h)). The porous graphene framework provided fast electron transfer, facile accessibility to electrolyte and CO2, and structural stability, while the Fe porphyrins facilitated CO2 stabilization using a push-pull mechanism between the Fe centers. Intriguingly, a novel 2D scaffold of a hybrid graphdiyne/graphene (GDY/G) heterostructure was employed to anchor the monodispersed CoPc for efficient CO2RR [270]. The as-obtained catalyst achieved high FECO of 96% with j CO of 12 mA cm−2 at −0.9 V vs. RHE in H-cell and a FECO of 97% with j CO of 100 mA cm−2 in flow cell, respectively, as well as remarkable stability over 24 h. These distinguished electrocatalytic performances originated from the strong GDY-CoPc electronic coupling, high surface area, abundant active centers, and the synergistic effect of graphene providing fast electron conductivity. Another support, G-quadruplex nanowires (GQ wire) assembled by guanine tetranucleotides, was used to host CoPc for CO2-to-CO conversion [261]. The CoPc on GQ wire achieved 2.5 times higher FECO and better stability over 5 h at −2.1 V vs. RHE than CoPc. Besides, the CoPc on GQ wire also delivered higher double-layer capacitance than the CoPc on DNA supports (single-stranded polyA, polyT, and a duplex dp(AT)) (Fig. 9(i)). This high selectivity and activity originated from the GQ nanowire providing efficient electron propagation and the CoIIPc active complex distribution along the GQ nanowire. Similarly, FePc and [RuII(bpa)(NH3)2](PF6)2 were deposited on GQ wire, the obtained catalysts were highly selective towards CO and HCOOH, respectively. Another polymer support of poly-4-vinylpridine (P4VP) was used to immobilize CoPc to obtain the CoPc-P4VP catalyst for CO2RR [271]. Because of the coordination between pyridine residues and CoPc, and the secondary sphere effects by uncoordinated pyridine residues, the CoPc-P4VP exhibited a high FECO ∼90%, a 3.23-fold higher j CO than that of CoPc (2 vs. 0.62 mA cm−2), a TOF of 4.8 s−1 and stability over 2 h at −0.73 V vs. RHE. In the following study, Chen et al. [262] grew CoPc on ZnIn2S4 (ZIS) nanosheets to obtain a hybrid CoPc-ZIS catalyst for CO2-to-CO conversion. Attributed to the strong coordination between Co active sites and dangling S created by Zn-defects introduction, CoPc-ZIS exhibited not only a durability over 15 h, but also a high FECO of 93% and mass current density 266 mA mg(CoPc) −1 at −0.83 V vs. RHE, which were 2 and 40 times higher than that of CoPc at same tested conditions. Some metal oxides such as TiO2 and SnO2 were employed as supports for heterogeneous molecular catalysts. Wang et al. [272] stabilized a Ru complex on TiO2 layer (∼0.5 nm). This TiO2 layer was fabricated by ALD, which enabled Ru complex loading via phosphonate-surface bond. The catalyst realized controllable H2/CO ratios from 1.5 to 5.6 at -0.96 to −1.16 V vs. NHE, and achieved a TON of 308 for CO after the first 900 s electrolysis. In another study, SnO2 or TiO2 nanoparticles were used to anchor cofacial Fe tetrapentafluorophenyl porphyrin dimer via a phosphonic-acid linker [273]. By loading more amount of Fe complex on SnO2 or TiO2, average j CO of 3.0 and 2.5 mA cm−2 over 5.5 h CO2 electrolysis was obtained at an overpotential of −0.51 V vs. RHE, respectively, much higher than that of Fe complex on fluorine-doped tin oxide electrode (FTO) (0.25 mA cm−2), probably because of the catalysis rate controlled by the charge diffusion in the SnO2 and TiO2 film. But they achieved much lower TOF than that of Fe complex on FTO (53.4 and 2.4 s−1 vs. 245 s−1), because of their poor electrical conductivity. In addition, Fe complex on SnO2 gave a high FECO of 90% at −1.2 V vs. NHE. 3.4 Influence of electrolytes and electrolyzers for CO2RR 3.4.1 Influence of electrolytes For the above discussed CO2RR applications of various SACs (molecular catalysts), most studies were performed in aqueous electrolytes (KHCO3, KOH, NaHCO3, CsHCO3, and etc.), some works were conducted using ionic liquid as electrolytes. Several factors of electrolytes including concentrations, pH, species (aqueous or ionic liquid), buffer capacity, and etc. made significant contributions to the CO2RR performances. Compared with aqueous NaHCO3, the KHCO3 electrolyte achieved better CO production during CO2RR catalyzed by ZnN x /C SAC [24], because K+ outperformed Na+ with providing more accessible protons to buffer the increased pH near the cathode surface and enhance the concentration of dissolved CO2 in the electrolyte. In another study, Han et al. [289] studied the effects of electrolyte concentrations on the CO2RR performance catalyzed by a Zn SAC. Both partial current density and the yield rate for CH4 increased with KHCO3 concentration, this can be elucidated by the relationship between electrolyte buffer capacity and local interfacial pH. The CO2-to-CH4 conversion needs 8 protons transfer, thus, the partial current density of this reaction is proportionally related to proton activity. Higher KHCO3 concentration resulted in larger bulk pH, while the higher buffer capacity lowered the interfacial pH near catalyst surface (pHlocal) during the interfacial protons consumption. Therefore, the pHlocal increased upon lower KHCO3 concentration, because of the decreased local concentration of protons. This conclusion was consistent with previous studies [93,290]. Beyond the electrolyte concentrations, Varela et al. [187] studied the effects of electrolyte pH on selectivity and explore the role of proton concentration for CO2RR catalyzed by a Fe-N-C SAC. Both CH4 and H2 formation is related to the pH, while CO production was independent on pH, which demonstrated that the rate-limiting step for CO generation was the decoupled electron-proton transfer. The FeN x centers stabilized the intermediate (Fe-N-C)-CO2 −, which would be protonated to *COOH and further reduced to CO. Besides, different pH values selectively influenced the formation of CO or H2, which allowed to regulate the CO/H2 ratio. Intensive CO2RR studies were conducted using aqueous electrolytes and achieved superior electrochemical performances, however, aqueous electrolyte suffers from issues of low CO2 solubility [8], and serious HER side reaction [10]. Compared with aqueous electrolytes, ionic liquids (IL) exhibit many advantages of high CO2 solubility [291–293], enhanced CO2 transfer [294], improved selectivity [295], suppressed HER, and co-catalyst effect [296], which are favorable to the CO2RR [297–300]. For instance, Feng et al. [301] investigated the activity of Mn-C3N4/CNT SAC in CO2-saturated IL electrolyte (1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([Bmim] [BF4]/acetonitrile (CH3CN)-H2O). Maximum FECO of 98.3% with j CO of 18.6 mA cm−2 were achieved at an overpotential of 0.42 V. Besides, maximum j CO of 29.7 mA cm−2 was obtained at an overpotential of 0.62 V, higher than that using the KHCO3 electrolyte. This improved performance originated from the high CO2 solubility in [Bmim][BF4] to alleviate the resistance of mass transfer, and the favorable CO2 adsorption via the [Bmim-CO2]+ complex formation to lower the activation energy for CO2RR. Many other works were also devoted to CO2RR in IL electrolytes, which achieved outstanding performances. However, the bulk IL electrolytes are challenged by high viscosity and poor ionic conductivity of ILs which resulted in sluggish mass transfer and high energy consumption [302–304]. Besides, ILs are relatively costly which are not economic and practical for large quantity utilization for CO2 reduction. To overcome these issues, our group recently confined [Bmim][PF6] IL at single Ni sites to boost CO2-to-CO conversion [296]. The nanoconfined ILs contributed to high FECO (> 98%), enhanced current densities (66.1 mA cm−2), and robust stability (> 50 h), because of the alternated CO2-Ni sites interactions and the creation of solid/liquid interface with high CO2 concentration. Theoretical calculations showed a positive shift to the Fermi level of the d-band center of Ni atoms with IL existence, giving a significantly reduced energy barrier from 1.49 to 0.80 eV for the rate-limiting step (CO2(g) → COOH*). 3.4.2 Influence of CO2RR electrolyzers To date, many types of electrolyzers have been designed for CO2RR. For example, H-cell, flow cell and MEA mainly operate at low temperatures below 100 °C even down to room temperature [305–309]. In these devices, CO2 can be reduced into multi-products including C1, C2, and C3 species. The discussed single atom based catalysts (SACs, molecular catalysts) in Section 3.1−3.3 were mainly performed in H cell, flow cell and MEA, which presented different CO2RR performances. In this section, influence of electrolyzers for CO2RR will be pointed out. Many studies on CO2RR were performed in H-cells [29,65,92], because of its facile operation and adaptability to different structured electrode materials, benefiting fast and economic assessment of the catalyst activity. A typical H-cell is composed of Pt anode and working cathode separated by ion exchange membrane, a reference electrode (SCE, Ag/AgCl, Hg/HgO), and aqueous electrolyte such as KHCO3. Water was oxidized via oxygen evolution in the anodic chamber, while CO2 saturated the electrolyte in the cathodic chamber, the dissolved CO2 transferred to the catalyst surface and was reduced into multi-products (CO, CH4, HCOOH, CH3OH, C2H5OH, etc) [305]. Specific CO2RR products with high selectivity and partial current density were obtained in H-cells by effective single atom based catalysts. However, CO2RR is restricted to relatively low current densities (< 100 mA/cm2) because of the low CO2 solubility in aqueous solution. Other issues including the HER side-reaction, limited mass transfer, and non-scalable property hindered the practical applications of H-cells. In addition, during CO2RR process, K+ goes across the cation exchange membrane (Nafion membrane) from anode to cathode, which decreases the anolyte pH and increases the catholyte pH, thus affecting the selectivity, current density and stability [290]. In this case, efficient catalysts should be designed to solve the issues in H-cell. For example, some Ni SACs have achieved high CO production with large CO partial current density [106,149]. Besides, Sn1/Vo-CuO-90 [211] and CuSAs/TCNFs [110] SACs exhibited high partial current density for CH3OH, while Mo@NG SAC [166] contributed to large j HCOOH values. Flow cells are designed to meet the high reaction rates for practical CO2RR. To mitigate the low CO2 solubility in electrolytes [310], electrodes with catalysts on gas diffusion layer (~50 nm) are employed in flow cells [311]. This promotes CO2 transfer to the catalyst surface through the gas diffusion layer and be reduced at the solid-liquid-gas triple phase boundary. Circulated electrolytes in flow cell play significant roles in buffering the pH change and keeping a stable concentration [306]. Alkaline electrolytes (KOH) can be used in flow cells, which enhanced the overall energy efficiency of CO2RR by promoting oxygen evolution reaction [306]. In addition to these progresses, flow cells are challenged by salt accumulation, flooding, CO2 and liquid products crossover [312]. To tackle these critical issues and achieve desirable CO2RR performance, the following strategies are effective: efficient catalysts design [216], optimization of experimental conditions (CO2 humidity, flow rate, partial pressure, periodically updated electrolyte) and the electrodes wetting properties [313]. Membrane electrode assembly (MEA) belongs to two-electrode system, thus, CO2RR in MEA is controlled by the cell voltage. Various membrane can be applied in MEA, including bipolar [314], anion-exchange [308], and cation-exchange membranes [309] (BPMs, AEMs, CEMs). Among which, BPMs facilitated water dissociation into H+ and OH−, which transferred to cathode and anode, respectively [315], Sustainion AEM [316] promoted anions (OH−, CO3 2−) flow from cathode to anode, while Nafion CEM [317] enabled cations flow from anode to cathode. The catalyst layer on gas diffusion electrodes contacts the polymer membrane in a zero-gap manner. Compared with flow cells, no catholyte exists in MEA, thus, the ohmic losses are greatly reduced and the cathode catalyst resists to be contaminated by the impurities in catholyte. This enables higher Faradaic efficiency and stability. In addition, it's facile to get high-concentration liquid products because of the little diffusion of gas and liquid products. Normally, MEA enables CO2RR measurements at industrial-scale current densities. Besides, some MEA cases are designed at large scale (25 cm2) beyond the lab scale devices [307]. But MEA devices suffer from membrane and gas stream hydration, cathode acidification, and competitive HER. To enhance the CO2RR performance in MEA, some strategies can be considered: exploring effective catalysts with durable stability and ultra-high activity, applying solid electrolytes [318], designing all-solid-state MEA system [319], and optimization of the humidified CO2 [309,320].
