Several works were contributed to evaluating CO2RR performances in different electrolyzers [108,212], which verified the potentials of flow cell and MEA for implementation of industrial CO2RR in the future. 4 Characterization techniques Intensive investigations on the preparation of single atom-based catalysts and their CO2RR performances have triggered the development of various characterization techniques for the catalyst morphology and coordination configurations around the single metal atoms. Identifying the geometric and electronic environments of SACs is essential to investigate the relationship between structure and activity. The geometric structure directly provides evidence to distinguish the isolated atoms and their coordination configuration, while the electronic environment gives information about electronic orbits and oxidation states. Many characterization techniques are playing crucial roles for SACs development, such as Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and some other techniques. Among which, aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC HAADF-STEM), XAS, XPS, and Mössbauer spectroscopy have been widely employed to study SACs. However, they cannot directly track the evolution of active sites or intermediates during CO2RR process. Different from which, the in situ/operando characterizations provided in-depth insights into active sites, reaction intermediates, and complex reaction kinetics, helping us to understand the active sites property and reaction mechanism. “In situ” was defined by collecting the catalyst spectra under the conditions related to catalytic operation, or in the same environment as it has been treated or pretreated without the temperature pretreatment. “Operando” was described as “in situ” measurement of an operating catalyst at true reaction conditions with evaluating both structure (active sites, intermediates) and activity/selectivity simultaneously [321]. Real-time characterization on single atom based catalysts is significantly favorable to identify electronic configurations of active sites and investigate the catalytic mechanism, laying foundations for designing more efficient catalysts which exhibit outstanding CO2RR performances. 4.1 Ex-situ characterizations 4.1.1 HAADF-STEM HAADF-STEM characteristic of high resolution offers visual observation of distribution and position of single atoms on supports. Typical HAADF-STEM images of Fe-N-C and Ni-N-C SAC verified uniform distribution of abundant Fe and Ni atoms as bright spots on porous amorphous carbon framework [322]. Similarly, several other studies also employed HAADF-STEM to confirm the existence of single atoms on supports [189,190]. AC HAADF-STEM was powerful to probe the dual-atomic-site structure by presenting two atoms with different contrast. For example, Jiao et al. [197] employed AC HAADF-STEM to detect the Fe1-Ni1-N-C catalyst derived from incorporating Fe and Ni atoms into MOF by a Zn-assisted atomization strategy, which was used for CO2-to-CO conversion. The Fe1-Ni1-N-C catalyst presented distribution of isolated Fe and Ni atoms and most of the bright spots were in pairs as circled by red boxes (Fig. 10(a) ). The inserted 3D atom-overlapping Gaussian-function fitting mappings also exhibited the existence of Fe-Ni atom pairs. The distances of atom pairs were detected to be close to ∼4.1 Å, confirming the formation of Fe-Ni atom pair in the Fe1-Ni1-N-C catalyst. However, it's difficult to distinguish dual atom catalysts with two different metal elements with similar molecule weight, because of similar brightness in AC HAADF-STEM image [323]. Electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) was effective in distinguishing two elements in the dual atom site. For example, EELS confirmed the formation of Fe-Ni single atom pair in the Fe1-Ni1-N-C catalyst [197]. In another study, EELS also verified the bright dual dots for Ni and Cu atoms, indicating the formation of neighboring N x Ni/CuN x sites [324]. Similar studies were devoted to EELS on probing the dual-atom active sites for CO2RR [168,323]. 4.1.2 XPS XPS is commonly used to determine the surface electronic structure of the material by characterizing the chemical and compositional properties of solid surface. As a surface-sensitive quantitative spectroscopic technique, XPS is able to measure the surface elemental composition in the parts per thousand range, which is effective in analyzing SACs. For example, Chen et al. [189] utilized XPS to determine the chemical and electronic state of the Fe1N4-O1 site with axial Fe-O coordination, which was developed by a fast-pyrolyzing and controllable-activation strategy. The carbonaceous O,N-codoped support graphitized at 400 °C under N2 (CON400) and the carbonaceous N-doped support graphitized at 600 °C under 5% H2/Ar (CN600) were constructed to anchor iron porphyrin (FePor) with a tetracoordinate planar Fe1N4 center and extra axial coordination sites, further calcination at 100–600 °C resulted in a series of Fe-CON400-x (x = 100, 200, 300, 400) samples and Fe-CN600-400. The XPS peak quantification demonstrated that the Fe-CON400-x catalysts exhibited increasing Fe-O atomic content (0 at%–0.21 at%) upon higher calcination temperature. The Fe-CON400-400 sample presented an atomic ratio of ~4 for Fe–N to Fe–O, while FePor-400 and Fe-CN600-400 both displayed no detection of Fe–O bonds, because of the instable adsorbed oxygen molecules, which was essential to the O species and its content for the Fe–O bond formation. Besides, the N 1s XPS spectrum demonstrated the Fe atom-pyridinic N bond in FePor-400 as well as the Fe atom-pyrrolic N/pyridinic N bond in Fe-CN600-400. Similarly, Guo et al. [193] analyzed the compositions and chemical states of the Sn SAC with atomic SnN3O1 sites on N-rich carbon matrix (Sn-NOC) using XPS for efficient CO2RR, which was fabricated by pyrolyzing SnO2 and N-rich carbon matrix (NC) at high temperature. The N 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 10(b)) of Sn-NOC exhibited characteristic peaks for pyridine N (398.4 eV), pyrrole N (400.1 eV), and graphite N (401.4 eV), as well as a distinct Sn–N bond (∼399.0 eV) which indicated the coordination of Sn and N atoms. The O 1s XPS spectra was dominated by C=O (531.1 eV), C–O (532.1 eV), and Sn–O (530.7 eV), suggesting Sn trapped by O atom. The Sn 3d spectra revealed a Sn 3d 5/2 peak at 486.5 eV (Fig. 10(c)), between 484.5–485.5 eV (Sn0) and 486.3–487.3 eV (Sn4+), which demonstrated the chemical state of 0 < δ < 4 for Sn. Theoretical calculations showed that the SnN3O1 sites, different from the classic Sn-N4 sites for generating HCOOH and H2, promoted *COO and *COOH formation and suppressed HCOO*, thereby excessively produced CO. 4.1.3 Mössbauer spectroscopy Mössbauer spectroscopy has been applied for probing the materials' structure and electronic properties since the discovery of [191] Ir in 1958 [325]. Mössbauer spectroscopy was deconvoluted into singlet, doublets, and sextet components. Among which, doublets can be observed for SACs, involving low (D1), intermediate (D2), and high (D3) spin state, assigned to the M−N x sites [326]. Chen et al. [327] investigated the chemical state of Fe species in the mesoporous carbon nanoframes with atomic Fe−N x sites derived from pyrolyzing Fe-doped MOF at 900 °C (FeSAs/CNF-900), which was bifunctional catalyst for oxygen and carbon dioxide electroreduction. The 57Fe Mössbauer spectrum of FeSAs/CNF-900 included two doublets (D1 and D2) (Fig. 10(d)), corresponding to low-spin (LS) and intermedium-spin (MS) Fe-N x moieties, respectively. While Mössbauer spectrum of the catalyst calcinated at 1000 °C exhibited two doublets, one singlet and two sextets for Fe−N x (30.18%), γ-Fe (5.16%), and α-Fe (50.80%)/iron carbide (13.86%), respectively, attributed to the Fe-based nanoparticles. In another study, 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy determined the Fe content and speciation for a series of Fe-N-C catalysts, namely Fe4.0d, Fe1.0w, Fe1.0d, Fe0.5d, and Fe0.5d-950 [143]. Where the subscript 4.0, 1.0, or 0.5 was the Fe content (wt%) in the precursor before calcination. The final letter w (wet) or d (dry) indicated applying a wet impregnation step or not before milling ZIF-8, Fe2+, and phenanthroline. These samples were fabricated by calcination in Ar at 1050 °C except the fifth one developed with a second calcination step of Fe0.5d in NH3 at 950 °C. Mössbauer spectroscopy indicated the existence of crystalline Fe for all samples except Fe0.5d, and the existence of Fe atoms (square-planar LS FeIIN4, MS FeIIIN4 species) in the N-doped carbon matrix for all catalysts but Fe4.0d. The Fe1.0w spectrum exhibited two sextets of α-Fe and iron carbide Fe x C, one singlet of γ-Fe, and the two doublets D1 and D2. For comparison, the Fe1.0d spectrum delivered much more intense doublets, indicating the difference between the wet and dry homogenization methods. While the Fe0.5d spectrum only included D1 and D2, attributed to the decreased formation of the crystalline Fe by lowering the Fe content. In the case of Fe0.5d-950, an additional doublet D3 (crystalline Fe2N or Fe2+x N nanoparticles) accounting for only 3% of the total intensity was observed. The Fe4.0d spectrum was only fitted with Fe x C and without observable amount of FeN4 species. 4.1.4 XAS XAS, including XANES and EXAFS, is powerful to determine electronic states, coordinated and geometric structure of active sites. XANES was sensitive to the valence states of the absorbing atom, while EXAFS is commonly used for identifying coordination configurations and geometric structure of the probed atom. XAS has been widely employed on SACs for CO2RR. For example, Yang et al. [72] investigated Ni-N4 sites in Ni SACs using XAS measurements. Ni K-edge XANES indicated that the intensity of pre-edge peaks (~8,334 eV) assigned to 1s → 3d transition for atomically dispersed Ni on N-doped graphene developed without and with introducing a sulfur precursor (A-Ni-NG, A-Ni-NSG) was higher than that of Ni(II)Pc, because of the 1s → 4p transition by mixing the 3d and 4p orbitals in the distorted D4h symmetry. Besides, A-Ni-NG and A-Ni-NSG showed lower intensities of peak B (1s → 4p z transition) than that of Ni(II)Pc. These transitions represented the square-planar M-N4 moieties, demonstrating Ni atoms with distorted D 4h symmetry in A-Ni-NG and A-Ni-NSG. According to EXAFS, A-Ni-NG and A-Ni-NSG displayed a main peak of Ni-N (1.45 Å) but without detection for Ni-Ni peak (2.15 Å). Many important reactions have confirmed the active sites of monovalent Ni(I) atoms [328–330] because of the partially occupied 3d x2–y2 orbital with high reactivity, but the Ni(I) complexes are thermally unstable, which generated Ni(0) and Ni(II) compounds disproportionately [330,331]. Ni(I) atoms formation in A-Ni-NG and A-Ni-NSG originated from the pyridinic N and S with lower electronegativity than the pyrrolic N in Ni(II)Pc. DFT results also verified the atomic Ni-N sites in A-Ni-NSG were the key factor for the high intrinsic CO2RR activity with maximum FECO of 97% and durability over 100 h. Besides, A-Ni-NSG before and after 100 h CO2 electrolysis exhibited well-dispersed Ni atoms and identical Ni 2p 3/2 XPS peaks (∼854.5 eV), suggesting the excellent chemical stability of Ni atoms. Similarly, Fan et al. [121] performed XANES and EXAFS to characterize the electronic structure and coordination environments of Ni atoms in the N-doped porous carbon decorated with Ni single atoms on CNTs surfaces (NC-CNTs (Ni)). The Ni K-edge spectrum of NC-CNTs (Ni) was between the Ni0 and Ni(II) lines, indicating electron transfer to adjacent N atoms. While the oscillation EXAFS curve of NC-CNTs (Ni) showed a main Ni-N peak at 1.40 Å, distinct from that of CNTs and Ni metal, demonstrating Ni coordinated to N in a porphyrin-like moiety. Fitted coordination number for Ni-N was between two and three, in accordance with the DFT calculations which suggested the stabilization of *COOH by coordinated Ni-N3 active sites with lower free energy than Ni-N4, thus promoting CO2-to-CO conversion. Recently, Yang et al. [96] studied the active sites of cobalt single atoms on a free-standing carbon nanofibers (CoSA/HCNFs) using XAS. Co K-edge of CoSA/HCNFs located between Co foil and Co3O4, indicating a Co valence state between 0 and +3 (Fig. 10(e)), while EXAFS spectra showed a slight shift of the main peak at 1.5 Å (Co–N) to 1.54 Å (Co–O) and no detection of the Co–Co peak (2.2 Å). Fitted EXAFS indicated a coordination number of 4 for Co–N configuration (Fig. 10(f)), similar to the Co-N4-C structure in CoPc. Confirmed by XANES and EXAFS, the Co-N4 existed in the CoSA/HCNFs, which lowered the free energy for *COOH formation, resulting in high selectivity to CO. In some other studies, XANES and EXAFS were employed to probe the coordination conditions and electronic structure of SACs for CO2RR, such as Ni-N4 [8,70], Co-N4 [332] and Fe-N4 [144,190]. Among which, to explore the origin of high CO selectivity (> 90%) over broad potential from –0.3 to –0.8 V for the FeN4/graphitic nitrogen atomic interface, Liu et al. [190] performed XAS to compare the electronic structures and coordination configurations of two Fe-N-C catalysts (H2-FeN4/C, N2-FeN4/C), which were fabricated by pyrolyzing the Fe-containing ZIF precursors under H2 and N2, respectively. The Fe K-edge XANES revealed the Fe valence states around Fe(II) for both H2-FeN4/C and N2-FeN4/C with a lower valence state for the former, likely ascribed to the reduction of H2. XANES Fe L-edge spectra also confirmed similar valance and spin states for both samples. The Fourier-transformed (FT) k2-weighted EXAFS spectra of H2-FeN4/C was dominated by the Fe-N peak (∼1.80 Å), similar to the Fe-N peak in FePc (iron(II) phthalocyanine) and shorter than Fe-C (∼1.91 Å) in ferrocene (Fe(Cp)2), while N2-FeN4/C presented a peak at ∼1.83 Å closer to that of Fe-N. Wavelet transform (WT) of χ(k) spectra (Fig. 10(g)) indicated that the maximum intensity of the [χ(k), χ(R)] centers for both samples were closer to that of Fe–N bond. Fitted EXAFS and DFT calculations verified the atomically dispersed Fe-N4 actives sites in both catalysts for CO2RR. The above technologies are effective in elucidating the single atom distribution, structural and electronic information of SACs. Nonetheless, each technology has its own insufficiency. For instance, the HAADF-STEM only characterizes local region of the catalyst, XPS, XAS and Mössbauer spectroscopy as bulk technologies provide comprehensive analysis of all the sites in the catalysts. Based on these characterizations, DFT calculations play significant roles in understanding the insights of the CO2 reduction mechanism. More precise characterizations to monitor the real-time CO2RR process should be employed concurrently to reveal the structure-activity relationship. 4.2 In situ/operando characterizations 4.2.1 In situ environmental transmission electron microscopy (ETEM) In situ environmental transmission electron microscopy (ETEM) was employed to track the formation of a Bi-N-C SAC with Bi-N4 sites on porous carbon networks developed from calcinating a Bi-MOF and dicyanamide (DCD) for CO2RR [161]. Transformation of Bi-MOF to Bi-N-C SAC was detected by ETEM at 23–600 °C and 1.45 mbar Ar pressure. During this pyrolysis, Bi-MOF was reduced into Bi nanoparticles (NPs). At temperature above 450 °C, the Bi NPs in the marginal position disappeared faster than that in the central location of Bi-MOF-derived nanobundles. DCD was decomposed and released NH3, which promoted Bi NPs atomization and N doping. The Bi-N-C SAC after 4 h electrolysis well maintained the crystal structure, surface state, morphology and Bi atoms distribution of the freshly fabricated Bi-N-C SAC, which indicated its outstanding stability for CO2RR. Besides, the Bi-N-C SAC was highly active to CO production with a FECO up to 97% and a TOF of 5535−1, as the dominating Bi-N4 active center simultaneously promoted CO2 activation and facilitated intermediate COOH* formation with a low free energy barrier. Very recently, Zhang et al. [333] revealed the evolution process of Ag NPs to single atoms using in situ ETEM and in situ XRD. They developed the Ag SAC using a temperature-induced surface reconstruction process with the conversion of MnO2 (211) to (310) lattice plane being the driving force to confine Ag atoms for generating the Ag1/MnO2 SAC. ETEM was employed to monitor the atomization of Ag species during 50-400 °C under air atmosphere. The particle number decreased steadily upon increasing temperature, which was accompanied by a significant decrease in diameters except 250 and 300 °C because of the largest Ag particles in the MnO2 port. Ag NPs disappeared at 350 °C. Further study by AC-HAADF-STEM demonstrated that the AgNP/MnO2 calcined at 350 °C in air exhibited co-existence of Ag clusters and single atoms on surface. In situ XRD clarified the structural evolution during Ag NPs atomization, which showed a gradually decreasing Ag(111) peak at ca. 38.1° upon increasing temperature, corresponding well to the Ag NPs size decrease detected by ETEM. And the (310) peak intensity in AgNP/MnO2 became stronger over time. Besides, induced by the introduced Ag atoms, the pristine Ag1/MnO2 surface reconstructed with establishing the optimal structure of Ag–O4 in MnO2 (311) lattice plane. The obtained Ag1/MnO2 exhibited a high FECO of 95.7% and excellent stability over 9 h for CO2RR. After stability testing, Ag1/MnO2 still exhibited isolated Ag atoms and preferentially exposed the (310) lattice plane, which suggested its relevant stability during CO2 reduction. Theoretical results indicated that the Ag single sites possessing high electronic density close to Fermi Level worked as the active sites to boost CO2 reduction. 4.2.2 In situ UV-vis In situ UV-vis could characterize the properties of redox species during CO2RR. Nikolay Kornienko et al. [221] measured the UV-vis absorbance of the [Al2(OH)2TCPPCo] MOF film at different potentials. The spectra exhibited typical peaks at 422 and 530 nm in open-circuit states, featuring Soret band (S0 → S2) and Q band (S0 → S1), respectively. The peak intensity increased at lower wavelengths, because of the Co(I) back-donation into the porphyrin system. When changing the potential from 0 to –0.7 V vs. RHE, the Co(II) Soret band intensity decreased at 422 nm, which was accompanied with the Co(I) Soret band increase at 408 nm. Similar UV-Vis results were also detected for COF-366-Co [226]. These two studies demonstrated the reduction of Co(II) to Co(I) during CO2 electrolysis, which were the redox-accessible catalytic centers. In another study, in situ UV spectra of CoFPc on fluorine-doped tin oxide at –0.5 V vs. RHE, compared with that at CO2-saturated bicarbonate, displayed a red shift, weaker Q-band (S0 → S1), and strong band at 475 nm for metal-to-ligand charge transfer, corresponding to Co(I)Pc formation. The reduced Co(I)Pc was reversibly converted to the original Co(II) state [235]. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves displayed a 0.2 eV negative shift of Co(II)/Co(I) redox from CoPc to CoFPc, indicating that the fluorine substituents mitigated the molecule reduction to Co(I), thereby accelerating the potential rate-limiting step of CO2 coordination to Co(I) atom. Apart from these Co-based redox specie, Lu et al. [334] elucidated the active sites in immobilized fluorinated iron porphyrin (5,10,15,20-tetrakis(pentafluoro- phenyl) porphyrin Fe(III) chloride (FeF20TPP)) for CO2-to-CO conversion using operando UV-vis. Compared with the UV-vis spectra of FeF20TPP at open circuit potential (OCP, 0.9 V vs. RHE) in CO2 saturated 0.5 mol/L NaHCO3 which presented a porphyrin Soret-band peak at 410 nm, the spectra at –0.2 V vs. RHE displayed a peak at 433 nm and a decreased peak at 410 nm, indicating the reduction of Fe(III) to Fe(II). Varying the potential from –0.2 to –0.8 V vs. RHE, the peak at 417 nm decreased simultaneously. Similar results were detected under Ar atmosphere, which demonstrated that CO2 in electrolyte was not the prerequisite for these peaks. The UV-vis spectra for the control experiment using phosphate buffer solution without CO2 showed a peak at 430 nm and no detection of shoulder peak upon increasing applied potential. This indicated that the peak at 417 nm did not simply evolve from Fe(II) reduction but probably from Fe(II) ligated by CO considering their strong affinity. These results suggested that the active sites of Fe(II) species accommodated CO during CO2RR as Fe(II)-CO adducts which were the predominant molecular species. Cai et al. [156] utilized in situ UV-vis to identify the origin of the excellent CO2RR performances by the single-atom Cu-embedded carbon dots (Cu-CDs) (FECH4 of 78%). Decreasing the potentials from OCP (0.86 V vs. RHE) to –1.64 V vs. RHE, no shift in the in situ UV-vis spectra of Cu-CDs to that of CDs was observed, which indicated that the single Cu sites in Cu-CDs were intrinsically active for CO2-to-CH4 conversion. This is different from the in situ UV-vis spectra of CuPc with reducing CuPc absorption at –0.64 V and increasing B-bands absorption of Pc at –0.94 V, which were assigned to the Cu(I) and Cu(0) formation, respectively. This indicated the conversion of single-site Cu in CuPc into metallic Cu clusters which worked as active centers for CO2RR. Interestingly, this conversion was reversible by releasing the reduction potential. Further in situ experiments and DFT revealed that the unique CuN2O2 active sites in Cu-CDs were promising in enhancing the energy barrier of CH4 and H2 and finely altering the electronic structure of Cu active sites. Therefore, Cu-CDs exhibited good stability with maintaining 96% of the initial FECH4 after 6 h CO2 electrolysis, while CuPc presented obviously decreased FECH4 after stability testing. In addition, Cu-CDs after long-term testing still remained atomically dispersed Cu. 4.2.3 In situ Raman Operando Raman spectra was collected to probe the state change of Ni in nickel(II) 2,9,16,23-tetra(amino)phthalocyanine (Ni-TAPc) during CO2RR [335]. Two peaks at 182 and 244 cm−1 assigned to isoindole deformation and Ni-N vibration were detected. The Ni-N vibration peak shifted to lower wavenumbers upon increasing the applied potential to more than 0.57 V (vs. RHE) under Ar (Fig. 11(a) ), which demonstrated a weakened metal-nitrogen bond, because of the Ni2+ reduction to Ni+ by adding one more electron to the Ni3d orbital. While under CO2, the Ni-N vibration peak maintained its original shape and energy position, no shift was observed with varying the cathodic potential from OCP to 0.37 V vs. RHE (Fig. 11(b)). These results confirmed the reduction of Ni in Ni-TAPc during CO2-to-CO conversion, and the role of in-situ-generated Ni+ that worked as authentic active sites for CO2 activation and reduction. Ni-TAPc was linked to CNT by C–C coupling to promote charge transfer and improve the catalytic center stability, giving an ultra-durable stability over 100 h CO2 catalysis at –0.65 V vs. RHE in 0.5 mol/L KHCO3 in H-cell. In the following study, in situ Raman was employed to identify the binding energy of the CO2RR intermediate on the catalyst surface [336]. For the catalysts investigated in this work, Zr-fcu-MOF-BDC (UiO-66) was used as a starting material. The BDC (1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) organic linker was functionalized with a NH2 − for stronger interaction with CO2 and obtaining Zr-fcu-MOF-NH2BDC, while replacing 1,4-BDC with 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-NDC) achieved better CO2 capture via physisorption by decreasing pore size and pore-aperture size and obtained Zr-fcu-MOF-NDC. The Zr ion in the hexanuclear cluster was changed by Y ion to get the Y-fcu-MOF-NDC and study the Lewis acidity effect on CO2RR activity. Compared with the Raman spectra of these four MOFs, the Ag incorporated MOFs (Ag/MOFs) exhibited distinguished MOFs Raman peaks. No Raman peak difference for all the Ag/MOFs was detected upon the applied potential in 0.5 mol/L KHCO3 (Figs. 11(c) and (d)), which confirmed the superior stability of MOFs during CO2RR. While a clear Raman shift from 1800 to 2200 cm−1 assigned to the *CO binding mode was observed. No peak in this range was observed for Ag/Zr-fcu-MOF-BDC (Fig. 11(e)), which can be explained by *CO desorption. The Ag-CO binding energy is generally low. On the contrary, Ag/Zr-fcu-MOF-NH2BDC exhibited broad peaks around 2100 cm−1 for C≡O stretching of COatop molecules (Fig. 11(f)), while Ag/Zr-fcu-MOF-NDC displayed narrow peaks at 1950 cm−1 for C≡O stretching of CObridge molecules. These *CO Raman peaks were explained by the enhanced local CO2 concentration near Ag through the MOF modification by NH2 − and the pore size confinement by NDC. This local CO2 concentration increase promoted CO2RR and suppressed HER simultaneously. The binding modes of *CO was manipulated by Zr-fcu-MOF-NH2BDC and Zr-fcu-MOF-NDC, and the control of COatop/CObridge was the key for CO selectivity. No *CO Raman peaks were observed for Ag/Y-fcu-MOF-NDC which exhibited lower Lewis acidity than Zr-based MOFs, indicating that the intermediate binding control was effective when well-prepared Lewis acidity environment existed. 4.2.4 In situ FTIR In situ FTIR is sensitive to monitor the adsorption behavior of CO on various active sites, including vibration frequencies and intensities, which reveals CO2 reduction pathways. Hou et al. [122] utilized in situ FTIR to identify possible intermediates and CO2 reduction mechanism catalyzed by Ni/NCTs-50 SAC at –1.2 V vs. RHE in 0.5 mol/L KHCO3. The in situ FTIR spectra exhibited a peak at 1400 cm−1 corresponding to the C=O stretching of *COOH, which achieved the maximum intensity at 540 s, then decreased to equilibrium. Therefore, *COOH formation was the rate determining step for CO2RR. Possible reaction pathway was as the following: CO2 was activated by Ni/NCTs-50 via a proton-coupled electron transfer, forming the *COOH intermediate, which processed another proton-electron transfer to generate *CO. Finally, CO was desorbed. Similarly, Ma et al. [256] employed in situ attenuated total reflectance-Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) to investigate the CO2RR reaction pathways over PyNiPc/CNT. The in situ ATR-FTIR spectra (Fig. 12(a) ) exhibited peaks at ∼1370 and ∼2057 cm−1 at –0.78 V vs. RHE in 0.5 mol/L KHCO3, corresponding to *COOH and *CO formation, respectively. Moreover, the *CO peaks existed after *COOH, and the *CO peak became stronger over time, which indicated that *CO was derived from *COOH. Additionally, PyNiPc/CNT showed a Tafel slope deviating greatly from the expected value (118 mV dec−1), demonstrating a fast electron pre-equilibrium before the rate-determining *COOH formation (Fig. 12(b)). Followed by this study, Qin et al. [337] investigated the specific interactions between the CO2RR intermediates and the Fe-N-C SAC using in situ ATR-FTIR. They concluded that the Fe centers in Fe-N4 moieties supported on the complete graphitic layer were poisoned by strongly adsorbed CO, which were not the real active sits for CO production. Theoretical calculations indicated that the Fe-N4 moieties embedded in a defective graphitic layer displayed balanced binding energies of adsorbed COOH and CO species, contributing to high CO selectivity (93.5% at –0.5 V vs. RHE) and fast reaction rate. Interestingly, assisted by in situ ATR-FTIR, Wang et al. [200] discovered that, in a porous Ni SAC with isolated Ni-N4 sites and nanostructured ZrO2 (ZrO2@Ni-NC) fabricated by a post-synthetic coordination coupling carbonization strategy, the Ni-N4 species were the real active sites to promote CO2-to-CO conversion, while ZrO2 significantly accelerated the *CO− protonation to *COOH intermediate, thereby reducing the energy barrier of this rate-determining step and improving the catalytic performance. Three positive peaks of adsorbed H2O (1650 cm−1), *COOH intermediate (1430 cm−1), and *CO3 2− (1395 cm−1) were detected in the ATR-FTIR spectra of ZrO2@Ni-NC. Among which, the H2O and *CO3 2− peaks became stronger upon accelerating the CO2 reduction reaction, indicating that HCO3 − was the proton donor to facilitate *CO3 2− formation and H2O molecules accumulation. For comparison, a slight change of the H2O peak was observed for the Ni-NC catalyst, because of the proton donor of H2O to balance H2O generated during CO2RR. Therefore, introducing ZrO2 nanoparticles altered the proton donor from H2O to HCO3 −, boosting the protonation process and enhancing the reaction kinetics. ZrO2@Ni-NC performed high FECO (98.6% at –0.3 V vs. RHE) and stability (12 h at –1 V) in H-cell, as well as superior FECO (96.8% at –1.85 V vs. RHE) and stability over 180 min in flow cell. Zhu et al. [276] employed ATR-FTIR to investigate the possible reaction pathway and intermediates of the CO2-to-CH4 conversion catalyzed by the complex [Cu4ZnCl4(btdd)3] (Cu4-MFU-4 l, H2btdd = bis(1H-1,2,3-triazolo-[4,5-b], [4′,5′-i]) dibenzo-[1,4]-dioxin). The absorption peaks of O−H deformation (1260 cm−1), C–O bond stretch (1331 cm−1), and symmetric (1400 cm−1) and asymmetric vibrations (1526 cm−1) were detected (Figs. 12(c) and (d)), confirming the existence of *COOH intermediate. The peak of the *CH3O intermediate (1166 cm−1) emerged as an indicator of the *CO intermediate existence, as *CH3O evolved from *CO. Interestingly, the C=O stretching of *CHO peak (1670 cm−1) exhibited obvious red shift and widened shape, because of the strong nonclassical hydrogen bond between CHO and the neighboring aromatic hydrogen atoms from the ligand. A similar red shift was also detected for *COOH peak (1526 cm−1), indicating the effects of the hydrogen bonding in stabilizing the key CHO intermediate. Therefore, *CO hydrogenation to *CHO was dominant rather than the CO species desorption. Remarkably, no *CO intermediate peak was observed because the *CO conversion was not the rate-determining step. Thus, *CO was consumed rapidly and difficult to be observed. Based on these results, theoretical calculations confirmed the trigonal pyramidal Cu(I)N3 active sites and their strong coordination, as well as the synergistic effect of neighboring aromatic H atoms via hydrogen-bonding, contributed to stabilizing the key intermediates and suppressing HER, thereby giving high FECH4 of 92%/88% and j CH4 of 9.8/18.3 mA cm−2 at –1.2/–1.3 V (vs. RHE). In another study, in situ ATR-FTIR was employed to monitor the reduction of the [MnBr(2,2′-bipyridine)(CO)3] complex anchored to CNT during CO2RR [288]. At potentials more negative than –0.7 V vs. SHE, the ATR-FTIR spectra exhibited major peak differences in respect to the reference spectrum recorded at 0 V vs. SHE. Bands at 1968, 1921, 1870, and 1844 cm−1 for [Mn0(bpypyr)(CO)3]2 appeared with simultaneous decrease in bands at 2025, 1938, and 1903 cm−1 for [MnI(H2O)(bpypyr)(CO)3]+ (Fig. 12(e)). As the band at 1921 cm−1 became stronger during reduction, it was difficult to determine the latter two bands. The detected Mn0 dimer and Mn-hydride species were active for CO2 reduction. Besides, reoxidation of the Mn0 dimer was tracked with ATR-FTIR upon increasing potential from –0.8 to 0 V vs. SHE in reference to the spectrum at –1 V vs. SHE (Fig. 12(f)). The [MnI(H2O)(bpypyr)(CO)3]+ bands re-emerged at potential of > –0.5 V vs. SHE with sacrificing the Mn0 dimer species bands. Normalized intensity of bands at 2025 (Mn0-Mn0 dimer) and 1968 cm−1 (monomolecular MnI species) was plotted against electrode potential, which displayed the same trend but opposite signs, indicating a coupled-redox event where oxidation of dimer facilitated MnI species formation. The dimeric Mn0 species formed at higher surface loading preferred CO production, while the monomeric Mn-hydride formed at lower surface loading was selective to formate. Very recently, a similar study by in situ ATR-FTIR was performed to probe the reduction of a Mn-based complex with Mn(CO)3Br single sites in a 2D COF support (COFbpyMn) [338] during CO2RR for CO production. The working electrode for in situ ATR-IR-SEC measurements was prepared using the ink containing COFbpyMn and multiwalled carbon nanotube, which was denoted as COFbpyMn|NT. The CO stretching vibrations (υ (CO)) band of a decreasing peak at 2053 cm−1 was detected at –1.15 V vs. SCE in Ar saturated 0.5 mol/L NaHCO3, which was accompanied with a broadening peak at 2028 cm−1 and a small shift to lower energies. Besides, the broad peak at 1937 cm−1 also shifted to lower energies. These changes corresponded to the first reductive redox event of ([Mn1L(S)]+ + 1e− → [Mn1L•-(S)]0). For comparison, Mn(bpy)(CO)3Br|NT gave a different ATR-IR-SEC spectra with characteristic υ (CO) bands of a Mn0-Mn0 dimer (1860 and 1836 cm−1), which was associated with the first reductive redox event of ([Mn1L(S)]+ +1e− → 0.5 (Mn0L)2). This difference between the COF and the dimer formation was attributed to the mechanical constraints by the reticular material to avoid the dimeric resting state. Further ATR-IR-SEC investigations of the normalized intensity of the evolving bands against applied redox potential revealed that COFbpyMn|NT showed a midpoint redox potential of –1.25 V vs. SCE for the two different redox species, 50 mV lower than that of Mn(bpy)(CO)3Br|NT (–1.3 V vs. SCE). Easier reduction of COFbpyMn than Mn(bpy)(CO)3Br originated from the electronic delocalization of the COF structure. The ATR-IR-SEC spectra of COFbpyMn|NT in CH3CN confirmed the formation of a formal Mn(-I) five-coordinate anion species as the key intermediate which reacted with CO2 and water to form the CO2 reduced species. Therefore, avoiding the formation of dimeric Mn0-Mn0 dimer by designing the COF complex resulted in lowering the overpotential, enhancing the overall catalytic activity, and exhibiting excellent stability over 16 h within two consecutive recycling of 8 h controlled potential catalysis. 4.2.5 In situ attenuated total reflectance surface enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) In situ ATR-SEIRAS is powerful to identify adsorbed substances or functional groups on the catalyst surface, helping to understand the structure-activity relationship for CO2RR. For example, Liu et al. [190] performed ATR-SEIRAS to elucidate relationship between the CO2RR performance and the structure of the Fe-N-C catalysts (H2-FeN4/C, N2-FeN4/C). According to the in situ ATR-SEIRAS spectra of H2-FeN4/C (Fig. 13(a) ), two negative peaks of 2343 and 1620 cm−1 for adsorbed CO2 and H2O became more obvious with varying the potential from –0.2 to –1 V, which indicated the simultaneous consumption of CO2 and H2O on the H2-FeN4/C surface. While for the N2-FeN4/C catalyst, an intense positive peak for ∗CO3H2 (1492 cm−1) was detected before –0.5 V (Fig. 13(b)). ∗CO3H2 was probably generated via the electron transfer from the adsorbed CO2 (∗CO2) to form ∗CO2– which combined with the proton donor (H2O). But the next protonation step from ∗CO3H2 to ∗COOH didn't proceed until –0.5 V, leaving abundant ∗CO3H2 on the catalyst surface. Thus, H2O (1620 cm−1) on N2-FeN4/C was continuously enriched, different from the rapid consumption of H2O on H2-FeN4/C. No ∗CO3H2 peak was observed for H2-FeN4/C, demonstrating rapid ∗CO2– protonation to ∗COOH because of H2O activation by graphitic N. Additionally, a small ∗COOH (1430 cm−1) peak was observed for both catalysts, meanwhile, H+ was consumed by the competitive HER, pushing the CO2-saturated buffer equilibrium toward CO3 2− formation. Therefore, H2-FeN4/C could promote CO2 activation and protonation assisted by the co-adsorbed H2O on the “FeN4/graphitic N” atomic interface, resulting in high FECO (> 90%) over wide potential range from –0.3 to –0.8 V vs. RHE with maximum value above 97% at –0.6 V vs. RHE, and superior stability over 24 h. 4.2.6 Operando 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy Operando 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy was employed to identify the geometric and electronic structures of the active center and dynamic behaviors of the single-Fe-atom catalyst during CO2RR [339]. 57Fe-enriched Fe-NC-S SAC, developed by pyrolyzing the precursor with six N-coordinated Fe based on ZIF-8-S, displayed stable current-time responses at various biases (Figs. 14(a) and (b) ). Compared to the fresh sample, three doublets for low-spin (LS) Fe2+ in FeIIN4C12, intermediate spin (MS) Fe2+ in FeIIN4C10, and high spin (HS) Fe2+ in N-FeIIN4C10 with similar current were observed in CO2-saturated 0.5 mol/L KHCO3. While a new doublet for LS FeIN4 was detected at –0.3 V vs. RHE, which was accompanied by the relative content decrease of LS FeIIN4 from 63.9% to 49.2%. Additionally, the LS FeIN4 displayed gradually increased relative content upon more negative applied potential with ∼17.1% content at –0.9 V vs. RHE (Fig. 14(c)), demonstrating the in situ reduction of LS FeIIN4 in Fe-NC-S to LS FeIN4 during CO2RR. The LS FeIN4 in situ-generated under applied potentials completely vanished when removing the applied potential. These results confirmed that the active center of LS FeIN4 for CO2-to-CO conversion and the highly relative content of LS FeIIN4 in Fe-NC-S contributing to the excellent activity. Theoretical calculations also revealed that the LS FeIN4 site outperformed other isolated Fe sites (FeIIN4C10, N-FeIIN4C10) with the optimal binding strength of CO2 and the LS FeIN4 site featured by a monovalent iron Fe(I, d 7) with unpaired electron in the d z2 orbital of a pseudo-D 4h ligand field was the key factor for excellent CO2RR performances with high FECO of 93% and decent stability over 10 h at –0.4 V vs. RHE in H-cell. This work indicated the significance of the operando Mössbauer spectroscopy in tracking the Fe sites for CO2RR. 4.2.7 Operando XAS Operando XAS was employed to investigate the relationship between the activity (FECO of 93% and stability over 10 h at –0.4 V vs. RHE) and the monovalent Fe(I) site in single-Fe-atom catalyst (Fe-NC-S) [339]. Compared to the Fe K-edge XANES spectra recorded at open-circuit voltage (OCV), a shift from –0.3 V to lower energy (∼0.8 eV) was detected in Ar-saturated KHCO3 electrolyte, demonstrating the Fe2+ reduction to Fe+. While in CO2-saturated KHCO3, negligible reduction at the same potential in the Fe K-edge XANES spectra was observed, which indicated the unchangeable Fe2+ chemical state at –0.3 V (Fig. 15(a) ). Even at more negative cathodic potentials (–0.6, –0.9 V) (Fig. 15(b)), only a slight of Fe oxidation reduction was detected and the Fe K-edge XANES spectra was still close to that of FeO, attributed to the discrepancy in the coordinated environment by the Ar-/CO2-saturated electrolyte. The higher Fe oxidation state in CO2-saturated solution probably was caused by the spontaneous charge transfer from Fe to the C 2p orbital in CO2 to form CO2 δ− species. Further investigations on the changes in the coordination environment of the single Fe sites during CO2RR were assessed by FT EXAFS. The Fe-NC-S presented shorter average Fe−N/C bond length (Fig. 15(c)) and larger Fe-C coordination number from ∼0.19 to ∼0.96 (Fig. 15(d)) with potential varying from –0.3 to –0.9 V vs. RHE in CO2-saturated electrolyte, which reflected the chemical bonding of CO2 δ− species at isolated FeN4 sites. Similarly, Zhang et al. [340] utilized operando XAS to study the real active sites in a series of molecularly dispersed electrocatalysts (MDE) for CO2RR, including NiPc, electron-donating methoxy-group-substituted NiPc (nickel(II) 2,9(10),16(17),23(24)- tetrakis(methoxy)phthalocyanine, NiPc-OMe), and electron-withdrawing cyano-group-substituted NiPc (nickel(II) 2,3,9,10,16,17,23,24-octacyano-phthalocyanine, NiPc-CN). The Ni K-edge XANES of NiPc MDE recorded at –0.68 V in Ar-saturated 0.1 mol/L phosphate buffer shifted ~0.75 eV to lower energy in the rising edge region (~8344 eV), compared with that at OCV and –0.37 V. This demonstrated that the phthalocyanine ligand was responsible for the first reduction, while the nickel centers partially for the second reduction, corresponding to the two reduction peaks in the CV curves. NiPc-CN and NiPc-OMe MDE exhibited similar shifts, indicating the success of alternating the nickel electron density by the electron-withdrawing/donating groups. Fitted EXAFS spectra of NiPc MDE demonstrated four Ni–N bonds and one new Ni–C bond at 1.91 and 2.06 Å, respectively. The new Ni–C bond was ascribed to the adsorbed reaction intermediates on the nickel centers. The coordination number ratio of Ni-N and Ni-C bonds was ~4. For the NiPc-CN MED, the pre-edge peak (~8336 eV) disappeared at –0.58 V and the first EXAFS peak evolved into a doublet, which indicated the Ni-N4 structure distorted/decomposed during CO2 reduction. This Ni centers degradation was irreversible, confirmed by the partially recovered spectra at OCV after reaction in comparison to that of the fresh NiPc-CN MDE. This decomposition resulted in the instability of NiPc MDE and NiPc-CN MDE. While the NiPc-OMe MDE exhibited almost stable oxidation state and coordinated configuration of nickel centers at –0.53 and –0.65 V, which suggested its robust structure, and thereby achieving better stability over 40 h continuous CO2 catalysis at –150 mA cm−2 in flow cell. Additionally, Yang et al. [72] studied the structural evolution of the NiN4 sites during CO2RR. Compared with the Ni K-edge of A-Ni-NG in Ar-saturated KHCO3, the Ni K-edge spectra shifted higher by 0.4 eV in CO2-saturated KHCO3, which indicated spontaneous charge transfer from Ni(I) to the C2p orbital with CO2 δ− formation. While Ni K-edge shifted back by 0.25 eV during CO2 electrolysis at –0.7 V vs. RHE, attributed to the recovery of low-oxidation-state Ni(Ni(I)* + CO2 + 2H+ + 2e− → Ni(I)* + CO + H2O). Besides, the EXAFS spectrum of A-Ni-NG displayed one main peak at 1.45 Å assigned to Ni–N bond overlapped by Ni–C bond, which shifted 0.04 Å to longer lengths during CO2 electrolysis, demonstrating the Ni–N bond expansion, because of Ni atoms distortion out of the graphene plane by electron redistribution in Ni 3d orbital between Ni–C bond and the four N ligands. Similarly, Liu et al. [180] probed the active site in the Ni-TAPc SAC using XAS. The Ni K-edge XANES spectra shifted lower by ~0.3 eV at cathodic bias of 0.57 V vs. RHE in Ar-saturated KHCO3, suggesting reduction of Ni2+ to Ni+, while the Ni K-edge XANES spectra sustained its initial shape in 0.5 mol/L CO2-saturated KHCO3. In addition, when electrolysis at 0.2 V vs. RHE, Ni+ in Ar was oxidized to Ni2+. Near ambient pressure XPS was employed to clarify the CO2-Ni-TAPc interaction. The Ni 2p, N 1s, and O 1s XPS spectra exhibited same spectra (shape, intensity) before and after contacting CO2 with Ni-TAPc catalyst, which confirmed no chemical reaction between CO2 and Ni-TAPc and +2 valence stated Ni center. The Ni+ active center in Ni-TAPc presented excellent stability over 100 h continuous CO2 electrolysis. In other two studies, XAS was used to identify the structural evolution of Fe-N sites. The Fe K edge XANES of Fe3+-N-C SAC shifted lower from –0.4 to –0.5 V vs. RHE [157], indicating the reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+, which demonstrated that Fe3+ sites were active for CO2-to-CO conversion. This reduction was accompanied by a coordination number change for Fe-pyrrolic N from 4 to 3 confirmed by the fitted EXAFS spectra. Different from this reduction at –0.5 V vs. RHE, no obvious shift in the Fe K-edge XANES of Fe3+-N-C was observed at –0.4 V vs. RHE. The edge energy close to Fe3+TPPCl also suggested the +3 oxidation state of iron ions in Fe3+-N-C during CO2RR process at –0.4 V vs. RHE. This stabilization of Fe3+ ions can be explained by the electronic coupling to the carbon support. Compared with traditional Fe2+-N-C, Fe3+-N-C SAC contributed to faster CO2 adsorption and weaker CO absorption, thereby resulting in high CO production (> 90%) and stability over 12 h. Similar energy shift of Fe K edge XANES for Fe-PANI SAC was detected at –0.9 to –1.1 V vs. RHE [158], corresponding to the reduction of Fe2+ to Fe+. This reduction corresponded to the onset of CH4 formation around –0.9 V vs. RHE. The coordinative Fe+-N x moiety facilitated CHO* formation, promoting CO2-to-CH4 conversion remarkably. Recently, Jiang et al. [159] evaluated the structure evolution of Sb single atom on N-doped carbon nanosheets (Sb SAs/NC) during CO2RR using XAS. The Sb K edge XANES spectra shifted higher in CO2-saturated 0.5 mol/L KHCO3 at –0.8 V vs. RHE than that without voltage, because of the Sb sites oxidation by charge transfer from low-valent Sb δ+ to CO2, forming CO2 δ− species. Besides, the k 2-weighted FT-EXAFS spectra exhibited one peak at 1.32 Å, which shifted to 1.42 Å, indicating the extended Sb-N bond during CO2 electrolysis at –0.8 V vs. RHE. Fitted EXAFS results revealed that the Sb-N4 moieties were active sites for CO2-to-formate conversion. Because of the electronic modification of atomic Sb δ+-N4 in N doped substrate, excellent CO2RR performance with stability over 10 h continuous CO2 electrolysis was obtained. Another In δ+-N4 atomic interface [160] also underwent structural changes under CO2RR conditions, which was probed by operando XAS. The In K-edge XANES spectra shifted to higher energy after applying CO2 in 0.5 mol/L KHCO3, because of the increased oxidation of In sites by charge transfer from low-valent In δ+ to CO2 to form CO2 δ–. While the In K-edge shifted back at –0.65 V to lower energy than the original In-N-C sample, suggesting the high activity of In δ+-N4 sites for CO2RR. FT-EXAFS confirmed the main peak for In–N bond shifted to lower length (≈0.02 Å) at –0.65 V. Fitted EXAFS showed that the In–N bond length became from 1.95 Å without potential to 1.93 Å at –0.65 V. The bond length shortened Sb δ+-N4 sites contributed to high selectivity (96%) and excellent stability (60 h at –0.65 V vs. RHE) for formate formation. 5 Conclusions and perspectives Over the past few years, many efforts have been devoted to single atom-based catalysts for CO2RR. SACs presented excellent catalytic activity to CO2 reduction because of their uniform metal atoms, maximum atomic utilization, and strong single atom-support interactions. Similar to the M-N-C SACs, molecular catalysts with M-N active centers also exhibit significant CO2RR performance, attributed to their well-defined active sites and precisely alternated steric and electronic properties. These catalysts exhibited various performance upon the central metal (Tables 2–4). Ni and Fe single atom-based catalysts are highly selective to CO with Ni based catalysts achieving larger FECO around –0.8 V vs. RHE, while Fe based catalysts exhibited high selectivity to CO at relatively lower overpotentials (0.45 vs. 0.69 V). These are potential candidates for future industrial CO2RR applications. Co single atom-based catalysts are mostly active for CO2-to-CO conversion, with some cases even comparable to Ni and Fe based catalysts, consistent with the conclusion in several reported reviews about metal SACs for CO2RR [13,14,32,33,341]. Remarkably, Cu single atom-based catalysts are the unique materials to generate products beyond CO. However, selectivity of C2+ products still needs to be improved. Other metal single atom-based catalysts (Zn, Sn, Ag, Pb, and etc.) are also promising for CO2 reduction. Despite these research progresses, there are still challenges need to be addressed for their developments and applications (Fig. 16 ), which were listed as the following: (1) Rational design and synthesis of SACs. Wet chemistry was desirable and economic to develop SACs, however, some wet chemistry strategies were restricted by practical large-scale production because of complex fabrication steps and sensitive conditions. Besides, SACs prepared at high temperature suffered from atomic aggregation and migration, which reduce metal atoms distribution and make the synthesis uncontrollable, leaving difficulty in precisely constructing SACs with well-defined coordination. Furthermore, metal loading of SACs is usually low as high metal loadings tend to aggregate during calcination. Therefore, developing facile methods for large-scale synthesis of SACs with high metal loading is promising. Several studies [105,106,110,111] have reported successful fabrication of SACs at kilogram-scale for CO2 reduction. Besides, fabricating SACs at low temperatures confirms a well-defined structure [58]. Modifying the carbon support by ligands or heteroatoms and exploring other supports (metal oxides, nitrides, sulfides, polymers, and metals) could effectively suppress metal agglomeration and HER. Understanding the synergistic effect between the metal atoms and supports is necessary to the development of SACs. Additionally, expanding SACs to dual-atom and multi-atom sites is essential for CO2RR. (2) Industrial applications of CO2RR. Industrialization of CO2RR is challenged by lack of robust catalysts with durable stability and superior activity. Most of the single atom-based catalysts, in form of powders, exhibit unsatisfactory CO2RR performances in real devices. Besides, the low CO2 solubility in aqueous electrolyte (34 mmol/L) and restricted CO2 mass transfer at high current densities [32] are great obstacles for CO2RR. To solve these issues, single atom-based catalysts have been combined with gas diffusion layers for applications in flow cell and membrane electrode assembly, which helps to meet the industry requirements. Some studies were devoted to M-N-C SACs for industrial CO production with high CO partial current density above 200 mA/cm2 in flow cell [96,139,198–204] and MEA [137,206]. Decorating carbon membranes with Ni-N-C SAC [138] or designing a molecular catalyst (NiPc) [340] as gas diffusion electrodes also achieved efficient CO2-to-CO conversion at industrial scale. Additionally, combing CO2RR and HER is promising for producing syngas (CO+H2), but the electrode stability should be addressed. Furthermore, improving the CO2RR system energy conversion efficiency and optimizing the electrolyzer lifetime need to be considered for industrial applications. (3) Improvements of selectivity toward C2+ products. C2+ products exhibited higher energy densities and commercial value than their C1 counterparts such as CH4. However, the low selectivity hindered their development [342]. Besides, most Fe, Co, Ni SACs are highly selective to CO production, while only Cu SACs favor C2+ species (ethylene, ethanol, propanol) generation [29,30,152]. CO2 reduction into stable C2+ is challenging due to multiple electrons transfer, such as 12 and 18 electrons for producing C2H4, C2H5OH, and C3H7OH, respectively. C–C coupling is an important step to produce C2+ species [343]. Alternating neighboring Cu sites is able to boost CO2 reduction into different hydrocarbons [29]. The two adjacent Cu-N2 sites can couple with *CO intermediate to induce C–C coupling and thereby improving C2H4 selectivity, while other sites (isolated Cu-N4, neighboring Cu-N4, and the isolated Cu-N2) favor C1 species production. In addition, expanding from Cu SACs to other metal SACs or multiatomic sites is promising to improve C2+ products selectivity. Furthermore, introducing diverse binding sites by an inert element such as Ag to a Cu catalyst [217] could destabilize the ethylene reaction intermediates, thus promoting ethanol production. Finally, separating CO2-to-C2+ into two steps of CO2-to-CO followed by CO-to-C2+ can be effective in enhancing C2+ selectivity because of less electrons transfer and intermediates. For example, Cu-N-C SAC [344] was highly selective to acetate by applying the CO2 derived CO, another dual atomic Cu-Cu sites [345] also contributed to C2+ products with high production using CO feed derived from CO2. (4) Investigations into the molecular catalysts. Molecular catalysts (COFs or MOFs catalysts, organometallic catalysts) exhibit well-defined M-N active sites which are similar to the M-N-C SACs, as well as precise tunability of steric and electronic properties of active sites. However, several issues are challenging the development of molecular catalysts, such as insufficient investigation of the catalysts, aggregation, leaching, demetallation, and poor conductivity, as well as generally moderate activity, selectivity and stability of the catalysts. To tackle these problems, fundamental studies of electrode/electrolyte interface, mass transfer of CO2, HCO3 −, CO3 2–, and OH−, chemical states, organic structures and metal complexes should be investigated considering the complexity of these catalyst systems [42,43]. Besides, alternating the electronic environment of the molecular catalysts is effective in promoting higher selectivity. Furthermore, efforts should be made to improving conductivity and achieving good durability of the molecular catalysts [340]. (5) Detection of the catalytic mechanisms of CO2RR. CO2RR is a complexed reaction process which involved different reduction pathways via multi-electrons transfer, challenging the understanding of the catalytic mechanisms. To monitor CO2 reduction pathways and clarify the active sites, apart from DFT calculations, ex situ characterization such as HAADF-STEM is effective in probing the position and distribution of single atoms on supports, while XPS, XAS and Mössbauer spectroscopy contribute to the catalyst structure. Different from which, in situ characterizations (ETEM [161], operando XAS [339], in situ UV-vis [221], in situ FTIR [122], in situ Raman [335], in situ ATR-SEIRAS [190], Operando 57Fe Mössbauer [339]) are powerful techniques to track active sites and reaction routes of CO2RR, which is favorable to reveal the structure-activity relationship, develop more efficient electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction and lay foundations for the industrial CO2RR applications. coredata.dc:description: Electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), powered by renewable energy, emerges as a promising approach against environmental issues and energy crisis by converting CO2 into value-added chemicals. Single atom catalysts (SACs) with isolated metal atoms dispersed on supports exhibit outstanding performance for CO2 electroreduction, because of their strong single atom-support interactions, maximum metal utilization and excellent catalytic activity. However, SACs suffer from agglomeration of particles, low metal loading, and difficulty in large-scale production. In addition, molecular catalysts as another single atom-based catalyst, consisting of ligands molecules connected to metal ions, exhibited similar metal-nitrogen (M-N) active centers as that in metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) SACs, which were highly active to CO2 reduction due to their well-defined active sites and tunability over the steric and electronic properties of the active sites. Nonetheless, molecular catalysts are challenged by generally moderate activity, selectivity and stability, poor conductivity and aggregation. Many works have been devoted to overcoming these issues of SACs and molecular catalysts for efficient CO2RR, but only limited reviews for systematic summary of their fabrication, application, and characterizations, which were highlighted in this review. Firstly, we summarize recent advanced strategies in preparing SACs for CO2RR, including wet-chemistry approaches (defect engineering, spatial confinement, and coordination design), other synthetic methods and large-scale production of SACs. Besides, electrochemical applications of SACs and molecular catalysts on CO2RR are discussed, which involved the faradaic efficiency and partial current density of the desired product as well as the catalyst stability. In addition, ex-situ and in-situ/operando characterization techniques are briefly assessed, benefiting probing the active sites and understanding the CO2RR catalytic mechanisms. Finally, future directions for the development of single atom-based catalysts (SACs, molecular catalysts) are pointed out.

coredata.dc:title: Single atom-based catalysts for electrochemical CO2 reduction
